[h2](First words)[/h2]
as a mortal kombat lover...someone who his first mk game was MKU3, im disappointed right now But like when i had hope in cyberpunk 2033, im having hope in mk1, sadly im going to make this a negative review because the problem is not just bugs or glitches...

[h2]Kampaign (Towers, Invasion)[/h2]
The lack of content show itself here because in Towers you can only do klassic towers nothing more and that is a big downfall... and in other hand the problem that Invasion brings is the fact that towers of time and krypt combined together and they give way less content that even one of those gave..
[b]MK9[/b] had test your luck, test your might, test your sight, test your strike and dont make me start to talk about that 300 challenge tower.
[b]MKX[/b] had test your luck and test your might and living towers and krypt.
[b]MK11[/b] had towers of time and krypt.

[h2]Versus (Online)[/h2]
it is cool that game is going to have more online mode to do but game really need to have rooms back
 
[h2]Kustomize(Fighter, Kameo)[/h2]
We need more than 1 custom slots for customizing characters 
at least 5 slots for fighters and 3 slots for kameos

[h2](Bugs / Glitches)[/h2]

they are bugs for some brutality animations like Geras hammer disappears after doing from another time brutality or Reptile will turn around after doing damn Tasty! brutality and etc..

[h2](General problems)[/h2]

give ermac a mask.. fun fact the maskless gear is very rare in mk games but man, ermac maskless is the last thing i want to earn in this game

[h2](Last words)[/h2]
i didnt mentioned problems like Desynchronization or krossplay because they are fixed or are going to be fixed very soon and im glad about that but i need at least half of this problems get solved before i give this game a positive review or actually recommend it, until then enjoy other games gamers :)

After 60+ hours of play I have uninstalled this game out of boredom. Unfortunately I can't get it refunded anymore.

NRS thought that placing a number 1 after the game title was enough to reboot the franchise. Needless to say, innovating and rebooting a game takes way more than that.
For example, take a look at Capcom and its SF6. Despite its problems (not few) it's overall a solid game that Capcom has been able to refresh both in terms of gameplay and visuals.
NRS seems unable to do so yet again. Here's why:


[h2]1-GAMEPLAY.[/h2]

-[b]Kameos[/b] are not the solution. In fact, it's a chaotic system, visually cluttering the screen and introducing a potential "pay2win" factor, because some Kameos might favor your chosen character way more than others and if you don't have them you might be at a disadvantage.
I've seen how Chameleon allows to considerably lengthen combos, and that is not good news.

By the way, why is my fight buddy on the sidelines while I fight? Conceptually makes no sense. I'd rather see my character fight alone.
Kameos are a silly idea from the start. Is the game better or more fun now? No it isn't.

-[b]The juggling system[/b] is on steroids here.
I don't care if it's the core brand mechanics of MK, it's an old one dating back to the first MK in 1992. 
If these mechanics by now favor experienced players able to juggle an opponent to oblivion (maybe with the help of a macro) for making just one wrong poke the game becomes frustrating and inaccessible to casual players.

Again, look at what Capcom did with Modern Controls in order to make the game more accessible. They pondered a solution to welcome new players, not to shoo them away. That is called [i]thinking[/i]. 
Player numbers speak for themselves when compared to other fighting games.
I've heard people are having fun with Tekken 8 as well, happily transitioning to that.

Overall where a game like SF6 is dynamic, engaging, stimulates creative strategic play, MK1 is dull, repetitive and frustrating. 
NRS better do something drastic about it. We are no longer in 1992.

Allow me to add that the sum of [b]extended juggling+fatal blows+fatalities[/b] when you think about it are instances of the game where one of the two players becomes completely inactive, passively staring at the screen.
While I won't suggest that Fatalities need to be removed, as they are a foundation of MK's identity, the rest has to be revised precisely to reduce not to increase player passivity. 

The sum of these gameplay decisions heavily contribute to boredom, frustration and the sensation that this game is slow and sluggish.


[h2]2-VISUALS[/h2]

Technically the game looks fantastic and facial animations in the story are some of the best I've ever seen in any games. The acting is wonderful as well, very realistic and lifelike.

The problem is a general lack of style which again shows how NRS is unable to renew its own brand even from this aspect.
Everything is "well lit" like a stage and looks quite artificial at times. It lacks atmospheric and thematic feel for the most part, especially in-game scenarios and characters look like action figures in a diorama. Characters' skin looks like dull rubber and overall design choices feel dated.

Hyperrealism is a fine direction to maintain, but that doesn't exclude diving deeper into a more iconic art direction. It could be a particular way of lighting scenes, color schemes and saturation levels, textures, effect...There's plenty of room to explore.

I'm not a Capcom fanboy, but let me once again use that as a comparison. 
In SF4 Capcom revised the game's presentation by introducing the ink splash effects adding a new iconic identity to the series.
In SF6 they took that further and also worked on renewing character design and improving gameplay, but still staying true to their origins. It still looks and feels like SF, but a contemporary one. 
They revised any wrongdoings of the previous releases without losing the overall direction of the game. Now SF6 is so well done that even their lame excuses for a story can be...excused (almost).
In short: they refined their product.

NRS doesn't only put no effort in renewing the overall presentation of MK, but plays the cheapest of cards for the story: [i]multiverse[/i]. Sigh! 
The MK universe has never been more irrelevant than now, where anyone can be good, bad, male, female, blue, red, dead or alive.

It takes more than a flexible stick and two iconic moves for a character to be named Tanya. That is NOT Tanya. Rain is not Rain, it's a new mage-like character who happens to be playing with water.

They already messed up Dvorah transitioning from MK10 to MK11, but this new type of mess is unprecedented. NRS' continuous revisions of their own characters, even new ones, show they have no grasp of their own conceptual work nor are willing to present a consistent world.

At the same time for some reason they thought it would be a good idea to reintroduce a bad character design like that of a grappler dressed like a spartan, with the facial paint of a corny rock-star and named like a Japanese woman. I can do better by throwing dices.

By now NRS appears to be alien to its own product. On top of it, MK has become more and more diluted by the continuous injection of third party franchises who end up stealing the show (Marvel stuff, 80s characters, etc).

The core material of MK needs to be reinforced, not thrown away like a displaceable secondary costume with relativistic story lines and color-sets subjugated to stronger third party characters.

I know what most say, that it's not NRS, it's actually WB's fault. It might very well be, but we can't say that for sure. Regardless, NRS is still responsible for their own choices.


[h2]3-INVASIONS[/h2]

I didn't hate it too much, decent offline diversion. I completed it and I tolerated it. However now that I want coins to throw into the "items lottery" I realize that I might need to keep re-playing Invasions...Not happy about it.


[h2]4-MICROTRANSACTIONS[/h2]

Horrid.
This is where both NRS and the aforementioned Capcom suck balls. Between the two NRS is a bit better because at least you do collect some freebies for your characters, unlike SF6 where you just collect them for your useless avatar.

Tragically, this micro-transaction bull-crap pays well and it's the new business model within the sorry state of today's games.

The ones complaining about it are here writing reviews like this one, but the numbers of those who silently pay is way greater, so this business model is successful and sadly here to stay.

I personally choose not to spend anything beyond the base game price. Will see how far I can go.


[h2]CONCLUSIONS:[/h2]

I had down-voted SF6 as well for its micro-transaction policies and lack of interesting content to be unlocked in the game. Capcom needs a slap for that too, but man...I feel like editing my SF6 rating to thumbs-up after playing this lame thing called MK1, because SF6 can be quite fun to play and it's very solid online. MK1 is neither.

After 60+ play time hours I can tell you I still don't know which character to main, because I don't truly enjoy any. At least I got Scarlet in MK11 and Jade looked great.
Whatever I play in MK1 feels repetitive. 
Other players play repetitive too. I'm bored at seeing them abusing the same two moves and combos, and bored with my own strategies for doing the same. It's not a new problem. It's how MK has always been, but it's now worse than ever.
I can't believe what a boring experience this has become.

I won't mention bugs, online play or lack of players cos you might have already read about it elsewhere.

I would just recommend to try the demos of other competitors first and see for yourself, but if you decide to buy this game wait for a discount at least. Don't worry, the more you wait the more they might fix bugs (maybe). However, the game itself is what it is.
Just get Mortal Kombat 11 lol

[h1]DLC Simulator 2024[/h1]

- Do you want to pay extra money for characters that have been removed from the game so they can be released as DLC?
- Do you want the opportunity to spend extra money on terrible fatalities thrown together for every single upcoming holiday? 
- Do you want the illusion of a free season that contains items you can only access after buying DLC? 
-  Do you want to buy Omni man for real money and then have the opportunity to spend MORE real money just to get the Omni man accouncer voice?

The store is more predatory than Catholics

Good characters get buffs, bad ones get nerfs.

Even then, Tekken charges about $4 for an outfit, with no option to buy moves.

I love mortal kombat with all my heart, it is the game of my childhood since I was 6 years old and also my favorite game, at the beginning I had a lot of fun on mk1 but at a certain point I realized that the game has less content than its predecessor , the combat is very well set up, I can even say that it is the cherry on the cake, the superb story with more "colorful" characters than ever, the invasion mode is interesting but I would never give krypt for something like this and what made me disappointed are the monetizations...it's hard for me to believe that we ended up buying fatalitys with real money. Anyway mk1 has a solid 7 from me the game is good based on what I mentioned above but at some point it will become repetitive, I still hope that in the future they will add more content.

Después de haberlo jugado unas cuántas horas, puedo decir:
Este juego está roto.

Tiene un gameplay que sólo premia al jugador por jugar con cierto jugador o kameo, desde día 1 apenas si tiene contenido y está tapado en micropagos. Si, MK11 también los tenía, pero no era necesario trabajar como esclavo para conseguir una única skin después de 2 o 3 meses de grindeo.

Hay muchas mejores alternativas en este momento: SF6, T8, DBFZ, GGST, KOFXV

1 - The Gameplay
The core gameplay is absolutely amazing and in my opinion the best Mortal Kombat has ever been, all the roster is actually viable to play even though it's way tougher to play some kharacters compared to others. The Kameo system, whilst weird at first, allows you do play in a completely different play style without swapping kharacters and allow you to do completely different combos on the same kharacter.

2 - The Story
It's honestly great, Mortal Kombat has had so many time resets and loose plot threads that it needed to address. This story manages to tie it all up neatly.

3 - The Kontent
Now onto the worst part of the game, the kontent or more accurately the lack there of. At the current time of writing this near the end of Invasions Season 3, this game has 5 modes of offline play; Story, Invasions, Towers, local versus and local tournament. And online play has 3; Kasual versus, King of the Hill and Kombat League. Compared to MKX and MK11 this is a massive downgrade. Hopefully though season 4 will add all the kontent we were promised and that should've been in the base game.

4 - Some Minor Annoyances
When you first boot up the game please do yourself a favour and go to settings disable release check, I have no clue why this is on by default but the controls are so much better without it.
Also if you have an NVIDIA graphics and are experiencing a lot of stuttering you might want tweak a few settings.
Antialiasing - Transparency to 8x (supersample)
Power management mode to (Prefer maximum performance)
Triple buffering to (on)

Better and worse. Obviously since I'm giving this a positive rating it has slightly better than it has worse. What do I mean. Well, Kameos are great, the face models are great, 21/22 characters have great voice actors (if you don't know, just search mk1 bad voice acting and I'm sure you'll find what I mean). The character designs are probably the best they've ever been, and their personalities are alright, but the ending is a bit disengaging. But it also ruins the story partly as it invalidates basically everything. the game runs fine, although if you have my setup around mid (I don't exactly know but rtx 2060 with i7 9th gen) the game takes longer than most would like to load. Tekken 8 and street fighter 6 both load extremely quickly, and when you consider the actual length of matches in fighting games, MK1 simply takes too long to load for how much you play per match.
There are a few less combos per character, like 3 or 4, which doesn't sound like much until you look at the combo screen. They did however add some aerial combos, but it just feels lacking. there's only really 2 or 3 combos which you will use (at low to maybe middle skill level) since you're paying so much attention on the kameos. 
Overall Mk1 both innovates and regresses in certain areas, which makes it a questionable buy for some but for the majority they will probably enjoy it. Out of Street fighter 6, Tekken 8, and Mortal kombat 1, I would rank them: Tekken, street fighter, then mortal kombat though. Right now, MK1 offers much less than the alternatives, and personally, there's no character i really want to play. it's nice coming back for the new character every month, but I play a bit then leave. the game just doesn't have as much as the other two, the music is worse, the game runs worse, and the story mode is good until the end where it falls off, despite the reference to an earlier game. Honestly, I do enjoy this game, but I wish I didn't get it in retrospective

To make naw palm, you're gonna need only three ingredients:
• ⁠styrofoam, or just polystyrene if you don't have any • ⁠gasoline • ⁠benzene (not necessary, optimal to dissolve the polystyrene) • ⁠sulfuric acid (if you don't have benzene to dissolve the polystyrene)
You are going to need the following quantities:
• ⁠33% (roughly a third) of gasoline • ⁠46% (a bit less than a half) of polystyrene • ⁠21% (roughly a fifth) of benzene
Mix the benzene and gasoline Throw in the polystyrene, wait for it to dissolve, and then stir. Naw palm's ready, there's a homemade naw palm bomm recipe down below. Add some sawdust, sugar or orange juice to make the liquid more sticky
If you don't have benzene, do this instead:
• ⁠70% gasoline • ⁠30% sulfuric acid
Mix the gasoline and sulfuric acid. Chop your polystyrene finely, and throw it in the mix. Wait for it to dissolve, then stir. Enjoy your naw palm. Add some sawdust, sugar or orange juice to make the liquid more sticky.
Homemade naw palm bomm recipe: You're gonna need the following items:
• ⁠Naw palm • ⁠Glass container (preferably bottle, but must be glass) • ⁠Tampons (or rags if you don't have any) • ⁠Paper Towel • ⁠Sugar • ⁠Water • ⁠Potassium chlorate • ⁠Funnel (not necessary, just not to make too much of a mess)
Pour the naw palm in the glass container, use a funnel if you're using a bottle. Mix the sugar, water and potassium chlorate in a separate container. Dip the paper towel in the mix, wrap it around the bottle and let it dry up. Close the bottle with a tampon or a rag. Enjoy your bomm.

Moral Kombat 1 is the new face of corporate greed. I am baffled how NRS launched this product in this state:
[list]
 [*]No crossplay
 [*]incomplete gamemodes listed as ( coming soon)
 [*]Horrible monetization
 [*]Invasions mode is one of the worst game modes I saw in my life, it has to be AI generated because I am not sure a human came up with that garbage
 [*] No lobbies
 [*] Characters literary in the campaign are locked behind DLC paywalls (Quan Chi, Ermac, Shang Tsung)
 [*] Horrible netcode and matchmaking
 [*] Lack luster character balance
 [*] and much more
[/list]
One of the few positives is that the gameplay is very fun and kameos can change up your gameplay greatly and makes picking your team combination fun and suitable for your play style. The hits feel heavy and connect smoothly. Combos are nice and flashy . The game also gives you plenty of free gear and content for just playing the game and this is rare for a modern fighting game. Other than these positives I highly recommend avoiding this game until the major issues are fixed. There is still a great fighting games under the pile of trash.

Rambling Review:
This is the very first time I played M1K on Steam Deck with the highest graphic settings. Completely beyond expectations and much to my disbelief, it's excellent!

But due to the product not released until September 20th 2023, then I should wait to post this review which I had already wrote on September 14th. Haha... was getting excited too soon. :3

Yeah, at that point; the game still just at the earliest release, so some glitches and bugs can be found, sometimes the graphics drops a little then goes back to normal. But didn't lagging and runs perfectly smooth at the very first day of launch back then on September 14th. Now, the glitches and bugs are rarely found.

I'm sure Ed and his awesome team will making updates regularly with new patches so it will be finally close to perfection. Daily or may be weekly.

Overall; I love everything from this new era. The costume designs are awesome, stages are beautifully done. And most of all . . . the violently brutal, gory but in a good bloodiest and a fun way of this franchise's most unique feature we all knew and loved; all brand new fatalities!

Story mode's pacing is a bit slow and boring. But then, starting from middle it's get interesting, and especially chapter 15 was totally mind blowing. what an epic conclusion and I won't give any spoilers, so chillax. :3

Konquest mode is great and fun only at first try, but then getting tedious and too repetitive after awhile.

The only thing I dislike is the microtransactions or MTX for mostly everything from accessories to skins. That is if you don't have much time to get it all and just decide to buy them with real cash, you do you. I just felt like it's better if we can collect them all simply by playing it often and exploring, without spending any hard earned money, just like any old school games were.

But yeah; It feels truly like a new game of Mortal Kombat I've ever played since the 1992 version. That coin munchers had a long line of queue and here we are now in 2023, with longer lines of gamers online, worldwide! Who would've known it can stand the tide of time. :3

Looking forward to the next new era of MK games in years to come (... hopefully with no micropayments next time, please!). From here on to the future of this series. 

M1K. It's in our blood, and it has begun!
(^_^)d

Before we start, I wanted to say that this is the first modern Mortal Kombat game I've played. The only other title in the MK series I've ever played was the first one released all the way back in 1992, when I played it on a old Sega Genesis my aunt had. That being said, a game released all the way back in the early nineties is FAR better then this garbage that I made the mistake of buying. My original reason for this purchase was that I saw a bunch of videos online about this game, and from what I saw it looked pretty good. However, this first impression lasted for about an hour and a half. First off, this game runs pretty poorly on pcs. I had to lower the graphics by a decent amount to fix the sometimes 2 minute long loading screens. And i'm not using a potato pc either, I have a pretty good graphics card and CPU. After I finally load in, I start to notice the large amount of microtransactions shoved in my face. Single fighters for $8 USD, packs selling kameos for $20 USD (that you can unlock anyways just by playing the game), And the infamous Kombat Pack, which comes with around 6 fighters and 5 kameos. While to some people this may sound good for $40, let me explain why it isn't. As of writing this, only Omni-Man and Kameleon (i think) are usable in game, and the rest of the fighters will be added later. This is an absolutely slimy business model and basically spitting in the face of anyone that bought this pack. Imagine this, if you will. Pretend you're sitting in a restaurant, and you order a burger. The waiter comes back with the burger you ordered, but it's only the buns and a piece of lettuce. When you ask him why most of the ingredients are missing, he tells you the rest will be added to the burger later. This has to be one of the most egregious ways I've ever seen a game company scam it's playerbase. It's even worse considering you already spent $70 on the game. And that's just the standard edition! As for the game itself, it's honestly ok in my opinion. The kameo system feels overly cumbersome and not very hashed out, as the wrong kameo can make a fighter go from good to terrible. I've only played for about a few hours, so I don't really have much to say about the gameplay. Gameplay's fun for a bit, but quickly gets pretty boring very quickly, especially against the AI. It's quite a shame I can't refund this. Go play Tekken 8 instead if you want a good fighting game.

I'm sorry to interrupt you, Elizabeth.
If you still even remember that name.
But I'm afraid you've been misinformed.
You are not here to receive a gift.
Nor, have you been called here by the individual you assume.
Although, you have indeed been called.
You have all been called here.
Into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune.
A labyrinth with no exit, a maze with no prize.
You don't even realize that you are trapped.
Your lust of blood has driven you in endless circles.
Chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber.
Always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach.
But, you will never find them, none of you will.
This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer.
Who somehow found this job listing not intended for you.
Although, there was a way out planned for you,
I have a feeling that's not what you want.
I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be.

I am remaining as well. I am nearby.
This place will not be remembered.
And the memory of everything that started this.
Can finally begin to fade away.
As the agony of every tragedy should.
And to you monsters trapped in the corridors.
Be still, and give up your spirits.
They don't belong to you.
For most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps, warm.
Waiting for you after the smoke clears.
Although, for one of you.
The darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole.
So, don't keep the Devil waiting, old friend.
My daughter, if you can hear me.
I knew you would return as well.
It's in your nature to protect the innocent.
I'm sorry that on that day.
The day you were shut out and left to die.
No one was there to lift you up in their arms.
The way you lifted others into yours.
And then, what became of you?
I should have known, you wouldn't be content to disappear.
Not my daughter. I couldn't save you then, so let me save you now.
It's time to rest, for you, and for those you have carried in your arms.

This ends.
For all of us.
End communication.

End communication.

Mortal Kombat 1: 8.9/10
Mortal Kombat 1 is a refreshing take to a new series that takes the formula of Liu Kang becoming a fire god, with a new take on the old characters, and others returning to the franchise, who has not met their face in so long, yet an abysmal to the legacy of mortal kombat and its characters as a whole. Especially, with its redundant changes to the characters that are unnecessary like Shao, Johnny, and Shang Tsung. The community is nothing but braindead, the gameplay is terrible and clunky as always, and the animations are nothing but loads of pile cream of shit that I would not wanna see when i'm learning on how to animate.
Story: Amazing, beautiful, and comedic.
Content: Awesome, though it needs a little bit more content then just invasion and towers
Characters: Amazing, and well thought out
Artstyle: Refreshing to look at (It gives off autumn vibes)
Cinematic: The cinematic in Mortal Kombat 1 are improving and improving, such as cutscenes, fatal blow, and fatalities
Music: The music are an excellent take on modernizing the old feels of the Midway era while not carrying away the modern charm they are focusing with.
Now lets get started with the cons:
Players: The main problem with them is that they are too engaged in taking you either in corners, or just flat out block, instead of trying to be stealthy offensive (And there are ones that are toxic)
Online: Online has issues with its internet, the internet connections isn't stable to function during online play. Which suddenly comes with fewer problems, such as hitbox, players connection, and etc.
Fatal Blow startup: While the startup may look awesome, and glory to look at. The main issue with it is how predictable and long it is, to where the opponent would just see a small cutscene, and realizes that they need to block. Ruining the unpredictable play of Mortal Kombat because AS a whole, Mortal Kombat always had unpredictable gameplay and role, even x-rays, moves, and fatalities, which is no big surprise. But as a thing, it is getting its inspirations from Injustice, (I don't really mind) Though Mortal Kombat has always been unpredictable with x-rays and others type of mechanics that the devs put in.
Content: The content is nothing but bland and is one of the most boring out there to exist.
Gameplay: The gameplay remains the same like mk11, combining the elements of mkx, but making them worse. The frame rates are awful, some characters are weak, and the lack of defense makes it up for how bland and unfun this game is.
While, Mortal Kombat 1 is an excellent game. It is a terrible game on its own, and the franchise as a whole.

After months since this game's release, there are still problems and a lack of content. But still it's fun. WB is going bankrupt and it's obvious that this game was rushed by WB. But if you look at WB's recent content, MK1 is the one that is still a success.

I love customization in games I spent hours customizing my characters in MK11 and this game lacks customization options but I'm not going to base the entire game on customization because this is a FIGHTING game. Yes, customizing characters is good but this game still has more customization than MKX, MK9. I consider this game's customization equal to MK11 because there were literally useless gears in it. You couldn't even see them in MK11. Many people complained about it now they reduced 3 gear slots to 1, and they look more unique. And personally, I like the skins in this game more.

Another thing people complained about in MK11 was the Krypt. When MK11 first got released, it was hated because of the Krypt and the grind system. They removed the Krypt and added the Invasions Mode. Which one is worse? Invasions. I dislike the Invasions mode but it is not so different from the Krypt because I had the same bad, boring experience with the Krypt.

The story mode is still flawed but better than MK11. Stages are better, the roster is better many MK fans waited for 3D era characters and then they added 3D era characters.

Now the thing I really hate is microtransactions you have to pay money for "premium" skins. This sucks but at the same time, this does not affect my overall fun with this game. The gameplay is so great. I enjoy it. Again, people complained about the gameplay in MK11 being so slow. So they changed that but now there are people who say MK11 gameplay is better. It feels like people just don't know what they want. This game will get better.

To people who say "MK1 is dead I'm playing Tekken now hehhehehe" nobody cares. Many people, including myself will still enjoy the game.

I enjoy the game very much I will continue to play it for it's glorious violence. Lot to enjoy and the combat, graphics and mechanics, playing with friends are all top notch. Fatalities great as ever! However, I cannot agree with the heavy monetization store, the endless grind of invasions with mediocre skins, no 2V2/3V3/CPU tag style type combats. No world building or extra world exploration in invasions. Short story. Bad online servers with sweat heavy toxic competition online. No crossplay with consoles/platforms/buggy mess. FPS set to 30. Lags ad Disconnects, periodically have to do re-shades. Lastly I am also just not a big fan of the Kameo's its lazy, cheap and makes me just want to have them as actual characters to play as. MK11 did not have this which makes me go back to older installments. Not worth full price if the paywall fatalities and best skins behind it are on a 70-110 USD priced game.

As a lifelong MK fan, this is by far the most disappointing. Sure, there is great combat, entertaining story, and amazing graphics. But why did I stop playing less than a month after this when I played every other MK game for years before moving on?

People would tell you about the half-baked invasion system, exploitation of micro-transactions, and broken promises from WB as reasons not to play. My main gripe is a lot more simple: Kameos. To me, kameos ruined the entire flow of the combat, and part of your training will include exploiting whatever flavor of the month is the meta. I don't find them fun or interesting at all, and the fact that most of the are alternate timeline versions of the same heroes, makes the entire game feel stupid.

In addition to that, everything besides the combat is a complete downgrade from MK11. MK11 had me hooked with the ability to customize every part of my characters armor. It was very rewarding and provided some value to the single player content. That is now ALL GONE and replaced with recolors or expensive remakes of old skins. What the hell?

This is incredibly disappointing to me. I actually prefer MK over the other fighting games, but NetherRealm really went out of their way to change that with this release.

If you're a fan and want to watch the story, you can watch it for free online. But if you are purchasing a fighting game because you want to actually fight, I'd give SF and Tekken 8 a second glance.

My first MK/fighting game since Armageddon, so can't compare it to the last few.
I've completed the main story and the Invasions game mode. Now play a good amount online.
Note: I can NEVER recommend an unfinished game that's full price. This game was intentionally left unfinished because of the modern trend of patching what's broken and adding left out content later, for more money. When I paid $70 I hoped the game would be finished. 

----My TL;DR recommendation is to either wait until the game goes on sale, or wait until it's actually worth $70 (a full, complete game) with future patches. In its current state it's playable, but simply not worth $70 (or $110 for premium edition, ouch).

Pros:
-Game looks amazing on PC with maxed out settings. The craftsmanship and detail in the animations are also great.
-Decent story/lore. Not amazing, but decent. Length and gameplay-wise it was good. It was a good re-introduction to MK after more than a decade.
-Character mastery/unlocking new gear and color palettes for costumes as you level up with a character is fun.
Probably my favorite part of the game. The different character outfits and seasonal-themed stuff is really dope.
-Cool movesets and abilities. I enjoy learning movesets for characters I like.
-The Krypt. Was my favorite part of MK during my childhood and it's pretty cool in this game if you like unlocking concept art, music, and potentially new costumes/gear for characters.
-Playing online is cool. Not many problems other than people spamming the same combos, which I just have to get used to.
-Invasions mode is fun. PvE mode I would go to when tired of PvP. Fun little RPG element, almost like Konquest mode (please bring that back). I spent most of my time in this mode.
-Not as many problems upon release as other modern games, I guess.

Cons:
-Things that come with an unfinished game. Seeing "Coming soon" for a game mode because devs didn't have time to finish it before release. Not being able to complete a puzzle in Invasions mode because you don't have the $8 virtual pre-order character, so you're just SOL. Grammar errors (Towers mode-Survivor tower-"Defeat as 25 opponents without regaining health.")

-Just being peripherally aware of how this game looks on Switch, for full price, and how NetherRealm thought that was okay. It objectively looks and runs like trash.

-Honestly not sure how I feel about Kameo characters in fights. I don't prefer it that's for sure.

-Sometimes game loads slow. Most noticeable to me in the Krypt. Also in story mode, every so often the smooth transitional loading would fail going from gameplay to cinematic, and a black loading screen would come up.

-Direction of the story/lore is questionable imo.

-Fatalities and Brutalities need to be unlocked, beyond the first one that each character has. I do like unlocking stuff, but not moves I should already have. I'm ehh on this one.

-Invasions mode. It's fun to me as a completionist. Realistically it's very lackluster, and honestly pretty bad considering who made this game. The fights are too easy, the talismans and relics used as abilities/resistances are mostly useless and don't make sense (you could complete everything without ever using any item). Survival challenges trivial, as in you could just stand in a corner and beat the challenge. Hyperarmor on enemies, meaning you can't even practice combos in this mode.
Modifiers are the worst part of this game mode, and whoever put them in shouldn't make games anymore - Effects during fights that disorient or annoy you. One completely darkens the screen, forcing you to spam ranged attacks or just blindly button-mash in darkness. Another, Chaos, literally randomizes your button inputs during the fight.
Honestly there's a lot wrong with this mode. Very grindy and repetitive, even the "Secret Fights" show up too often and you get nothing special from them; they're just additional fights. I'm genuinely curious who thought of this stuff, and when it will be fixed.

They took out everything that made MK11 good to appeal to a small group of niche players that prefer rushdown mechanics with minimal defensive abilities. "Dont get hit." I thought MK11 was the most balanced fighting game I'd ever played. Apparently, people didn't like their opponents having options, like wake up attacks. I had no idea. I just footsied away from it and took advantage of the whiffs, but I guess that was too hard for the rushdown types or somethin. On MK11, you spend 3hrs in the lab and study some frames and learn the combos- good to go. In Mk1, I spent about 8hrs labbing just Johnny, and I can't string together an optimal. The enhancement mechanic is supper inconsistent for me, it only works about 40% of the time. It did leave me wondering if it's my controller, but I used the same controller on MK11 and consistently reached 'God' in ranked. So idk.

A poorly-optimized mess of a game in which you, the player, are expected to doll out money hand-over-fist in order to receive cosmetics that would be play-to-earn in other recently-released fighters. Bad optimization, weak netcode, and embarrassing single-player content leaves much to be desired.

Still somehow a strong improvement over the gameplay of MK11 in many ways, but nonetheless equally or more insulting to fans of the franchise. Gameplay corruption from the Injustice series on full display.

and don't even get me started on the prices. the game alone is 70 dollars without any of the dlc characters which adds up to 110 dollars if you want them (1/3 of the roster). My thoughts on MK1 as a veteran Mortal Kombat player

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p-iadA281BU

It left a creamy taste in my mouth.
To put it more bluntly, this game is like a downgraded version of MK11.
So I would say that Mortal Kombat 1 is the worst Mortal Kombat game of the Reboot era.
I felt this feeling before when I played Tekken 4 at 2002.

*** graphics ***

The details and modeling are flowing, burning, scorching. They had already raised the graphics with MK11, but with MK1 the bar has been raised a lot.


*** Atmosphere/Ambience ***

Frankly i've always believed that Mortal Kombat should have a darker atmosphere. İ didn't like the extremely bright, flowery, buggy and happy nature of this one. The series has officially gone from dark to light. Believing that i'm a veteran Mortal Kombat player, i can say that the atmosphere didn't draw me in.

I'm never saying it was bad, but it wasn't the Mortal Kombat vibe I wanted, the Mortal Kombat vibe I imagined.

Mortal Kombat is a story of mysterious forces, dark stories to be discovered and different realms that continue to live unaware of each other. That's why its color is hazy and dark.

MK1 is a reflection of Liu Kang's spirit. The entire color palette, design and ambiance of the game screams "I will be bright, peaceful, at peace".


*** Gameplay ***

After MKX and MK11, I couldn't get used to the combo structure of MK1. İ think the combo structure is a bit more freed up. Compared to the previous games, we have to create and combine combos; therefore, we have to show our skills.

I like the cameo logic, it adds an additional beauty to the game. Very long combos can be done with professionalization.

But there is a serious clunkiness in the gameplay. This game is not as fast as MK11 or MKX.


*** Content ***

I'll touch on the story part last.

Invasions mode looks good for now. İt's a content that will play for a long time. But being single player might bore you after a while.

I don't know if a different tower mode will come, but for now the classic mode seems to work.

There is no krypt this time. They made a part called shrine. Give money, get the item.

Character customizations are nice. The feature of randomizing favorite outfits is nice. For example, there are 4 favorite outfits, it randomly selects one for you every game. On the other hand, the feature of creating different character variations like in MK11 has been removed. You only have cosmetic effects on your character.

İn addition, there are some points I would like to mention with the designs:

MK1's main menu, character selection screen and in-game life-bar, warning text, tokens are designed in a seriously simple way.

The intros at the beginning of the game are only added to the versus section. There are no character intros in tower mode. You switch with a black screen. You start the fight directly. This was an extremely big disappointment.


*** Story ***

Now let's get to the most important part.

Mortal Kombat and its story has the same importance for me as the Silmarillion because it was my childhood love, my first great passion. İ know every bit of the story by heart until MK11.

Especially in MK9 and MKX the story was very well done. İn MK11 there were parts that were like deus ex machina, but they tied it up nicely.

After making arguably the best game in the franchise with MK11 it's sad to say NetherRealm followed it up with a lame duck sequel in MK1. As with all fighting games, the absolute worst part of Mortal Kombat is the players. The game-play is fun, the story is fun (and looks 100x times better than any previous NRS game), and the monetization stuff has been blown so out of proportion that you could be forgiven for thinking the game actually MSRP'd for $100. 

There are absolutely balancing and competitive changes that must be made for this game to last, but the community is actively trying to sabotage the experience in how they choose to interact with the game at present.

MK1 players are absolutely allergic to trying something new, whether its a combo, or a Kameo, or heaven forbid, even a different character than the one they already have 2,000 hours with across the last 4 Mortal Kombat games, including this one. Every single person you fight, either in Kombat League or the laughably misnamed "Kasual" mode, will not fight you. They will camp you, hold back, and block anything you do, so don't ever bother trying to take the initiative, you will never be rewarded. Instead, do what everyone else does: back up and use a Kameo! Did you know that even the most unsafe move is actually plus if paired with the proper Kameo? That's Right! In MK1, the primary, and by far most common play-stlye is to walk away from your opponent the entire match while chucking some Kameo move at them until they finially guess your 50/50 coin toss wrong and you get do one (1) combo for half their health bar. Rinse and repeat one more time and the match is over. Every character is capable of easily, without much practice or labbing, doing ~50% with any hit confirm off of a Kameo starter. After 100 hours of sucking and trying to "get gud," I realized quickly that "getting gud" really just means exploiting ultra-safe kameo starters into one (1) optimal string. It is outright boring to do, and exceedingly frustrating to have to deal with. You might think that this sounds like a core gameplay issue, and not the fault of the fans, but you would be wrong. NRS has given players dozens of options for characters, and more than a dozen options for Kameos. But MK1 players actively choose to use 1 of 3 charcters and 1 of 3 Kameos. It is genuinely a novel experience every time I see a Goro, or Darrius, or the mythical Shujinko Kameo. I can count on one hand the amount of Tanyas I have ever seen online. I cannot count (because the number is 0) the number of times I have seen a  Nitara or Sindel. They just aren't played, and not because they aren't viable. The real reason no one uses half the cast is because it would require more than a room-temperature IQ to learn how to do something other than the same Johnny Cage or Kenshi 50/50 hard-to-blockable over and over while mashing the Kameo button like it owes you money. If you try to do anything original or even want to *gasp* learn a new character, you are immediately curb-stomped by some Johnny Cage player who knows just one 50/50 that you will never be able to react to online. "I just thinks he's really cool! It's purely a coincidence that he is the undisputed top 1 in the game!" 

The people who are left playing this game (and let's admit it, there aren't that many) are actively trying to kill this game with how they play. These are the same people complaining about a lack of content and having to pay for skins and announcer voices, as if that stuff just falls out of the ******* sky. They seem to actually expect a multi-million dollar game with 20+ playable characters all with skins, and customization options, and announcer voices, and fatalities, and hookers and blackjack, to give them EVEN MORE STUFF FOR FREE! I have never experience a more toxic, unlikable community in my life, and I'm not sure that's even possible anymore.

The real problem with MK1 is the whiny, cry-baby fan-base that expects free stuff, released the instant it is minimally viable, forever. I have never experienced a fan-base that is so demanding off a developer, while simultaneously relentlessly shitting on every decision (creative or financial) that company makes.  The MK1 community is all of the worst parts of fandom and competition congealed into a toxic echo-chamber of negativity and impotent rage. 

I would actually recommend this game if not for the people who play it. Smash Bros. is a healthier, nicer community, and if that is the case, you're ******. 

My 250 hours in this game has led me to the conclusion that only the most profoundly mentally ill, or otherwise cognitively impaired, could possibly enjoy anything about this game or the people who play it. Considering how much time I wasted on it, and the length of this steam review, I guess you can tell which one I am.

Decent game. I have some gripes. The story is a little lackluster. There's some fun moments for fans of the series, especially the PS2 games, but if you followed the release you know almost everything. And the lack of intros, especially in ranked, is one of the worst things ever. I hate it. Please. NRS. If you do ANYTHING, give us the quips between characters before a match loads in. I fully regret my premium purchase knowing I won't be able to see Omni-Man and Homelander say wild stuff to each other before each round. 

The single player mode seems neat, as a concept, haven't gotten far into it yet. There were just a few things left out from this game that the last game had that I think would've been neat. Wake-up options are pretty much gutted, air combos are necessity with nearly every character, it just sorta feels like this game taken out of the oven a little too early. It's beautiful though. The facial animations are kinda wild during the story at points. 

There weren't very many 'wow' moments in the story either, which kinda stinks. There were a handful, not to spoil anything, but that's it. Hoping the next one improves on everything this one did. 

I'd say it's worth it, if it goes on sale at some point. Maybe as a 30/40 dollar game, yeah. 100 dollars for 5 days early access?? ...Kinda regretting it.

EDIT: It has been over a month and we haven't gotten any patches for the PC version of this game. Granted, we got a single patch that PS and Xbox got, but that's it. Performance is still abysmal, mics still continue to pick up online even after having another option implemented to turn off voice chat, the game is locked at 30 FPS in menus, loading, and fatal blows -- and worst of all, there is a microtransaction shop that they are HEAVILY pushing. 12 dollars for a fatality at Halloween. 15 dollars for an old Scorpion skin from an older game. 8 dollars for an announcer. Everything that has been FREE in previous games. I can't defend this game at all. I can't. I wish I could get a refund. This is an absolute joke and everyone at NRS and WB involved with this game should feel bad about the current state it's in. Fix the game and get rid of the Battle Royale item shop. Just put the items in the game to unlock. For free.

EDIT 2: It's been about 4 months or so. They added intros to most modes, but the problem is, the intros suck hard compared to MK11. Which is wild. Some of the DLC ones are good. The gameplay is... solid. At times. Air combos are a little 'meh' and so are kameos. You have a little bit more freedom in combos compared to MK11, but MK11 was tighter and felt more rewarding. The cast of characters is pretty fun, but it could be better. Each game feels like a downgrade from the last. and the Premium shop is still as predatory as ever. Invasions is a terribly boring mode. Here's hoping MK2 is so much better. I'll only really be coming back when I'm bored out of my mind or DLC drops. Li Mei + Shujinko is loads of fun at times.

You know those commercials with two cars that look identical, but the one on the right is covering up a wrecked & restored car uinderneath? This game looks like the brand new one on the left but actually is the one on the right.
Let's start with why it's called 1-the story makes it look like it's actually a prequel to the very first MK, going way back to where the story of Raiden (before he became a god), Kung Lao, Shao Kahn before he was Shao Kahn, and others actually begin-including Kronika, the final boss of MK 11. So if you want to see how certain fighters came to be what they are (also how Mileena became such a freak), here you go. If 11 was the end, 1 is the beginning.
Here's where the problems begin: If you have a 4K setup it looks fantastic, but clearly the system requirements were grossly understated. I have a gaming laptop that blows away recommended specs and there are serious framerate issues-I haven't had the "locked at 30 FPS" issue but it's very choppy and everytime something happens for the first time, lots of freezing/stuttering. And EVERY SINGLE TIME you start the game it has to preload shaders, which induces constant freezing and thinking the game has locked up on you. The first time I started I had to force quit and restart THREE TIMES just to get through this. It sounds good as always with excellent voice work but the dialogue is just nonstop cheesy and recycled bad puns/jokes with less than zero originality. If you played MK X, 11 or Injustice 2 you'll have no issues with the controls. There are multiple gameplay modes which leads into more gripes-first, Kameos. They're NON PLAYABLE characters you can call for assists and that's it. :ole they're there to pacify "This person isn't here" complaints. And the DLC...even if you buy Premium Edition, if you didn't pre-order the game you're not getting Shang Tsung without buying him for another $8. Havik? Gotta buy him too. (Don't buy the Kameo Unlock Pack, you can unlock them all through gameplay so saving time isn't worth the $20) And then there's Dragon Kins aka IAP currency which has no place in a game like this. All on top of perhaps spending $70/110 just for the game.
It goes without saying that if you're gonna buy this, wait for AT LEAST a 50% off sale (which is when I got it). And for the issues with graphics & frame rate to be fixed. MK 1 is another example of just because a game looks incredible visually doesn't mean it plays like that. It's only for the most die-hard fans who want to know how it all began, but this game is really all style and very little substance. It feels like the developers just made this to be a cash cow for them, given their history with the franchise and gaming in general that's just really sad and quite a fall from grace.

This PC port is terrible.

Last chapter of the story goes at 15-20 fps, while the rest was going at stable 60 fps. The performance in general is bad. In Kombat League there are disconnections, crashes, all the time. The Mute option for online matches doesn't work. I disabled comms but I still hear noises and screams from other players.
Also there are some lacking features like latency on screen during match, modify size of the numbers in health bar (they're too little to read quickly during a fight), online rooms, and the MOST important of ALL: CROSSPLAY (seriously, 2023 and still not doing this?).

On the other hand, the gameplay and mechanichs are great, a vast improvement from MK11. Still need to nerf a few characters like Smoke, Sareena, and maybe adjust some other (haven't tried all the roster yet) but in general it's very good and fun. But since the PC port is trash and with the game being as expensive as it is, I would not recommend it to anyone until they fix it (or finish the game actually, because that is what seems to be the problem).

Update:
Almost 5 months later, gameplay still very good. Some characters and kameos are still completely unbalanced but game is still playable and enjoyable. Invasions is a total bore, playing it feels like a burden instead of a fun experience, so I don't even try to play it anymore, not even to unlock some skins that I want.

Anyways, the PC port is still terrible. It got better offline, pc is running it a bit more smoothly, but when playing online it's still full of glitches, throttling, and constant crashes everyday. And it's not bc of my pc's specs, my hardware is OK and stuff like this happens to people with even more powerful PCs.

So, after 5 months of DLCs, a lot of extra content that is expensive af and many patches, the game still feels raw and unfinished.

I always have a difficult time writing reviews for fighting games, as the value proposition varies heavily from person to person, but lets give it a shot. 

Mortal Kombat may have reset its numbering with this entry, but do not expect any kind of reboot here, both the story and the gameplay are heavily rooted in the previous entries, for better or worse.  I don't love how MK feels, I never have.  It's stiff, the combos feel so odd you have to input your cancels so early, and I find using a block button rather than holding back to be strange and unnatural.  That being said, I still found playing the game to be fun, they have been making these games for a long time and they have iterated the gameplay to the point where, despite my complaints above still being valid, the game is very fun to play.  

Mortal Kombats story mode is a treat, if you are in to that sort of thing.  It's like the craziest B action movie you have ever seen.  Massive cast, tons of fights, tons of high quality cinema scenes, bonkers plot, good voice work, the whole deal.  I had a blast playing through it.  It also makes you use a ton of the characters, which is helpful in figuring out which ones you feel most comfortable with.  In addition to the story mode you have a sort of live service mode (Invasions) which consists of clearing maps filled with fights with special conditions.  You earn currency in this (and the other) modes, that lets you unlock cosmetics.  You also have Kombat towers and an Arcade mode, in addition to, of course, online matches.

I found the online in MK to be frustrating.  There are some minor issues with the servers, I found sometimes that in matches where the opponent and I have good ping, there would still be random lag spikes, moreso than other fighting games I play.  This is a minor complaint though, for the most part that aspect is okay.  My major complaint with the online is just how long everything takes.  Finding matches, starting matches, going from match 1 to match 2... just everything takes forever compared to other games where you are in and out in a flash.  

Mortal Kombat is a great looking game.  I'm not the biggest fan of the photo-realistic style they use, but it is extremely well done, and makes the ultra-violence even more visceral and gruesome.  The stages are incredible looking, some of the best I have ever seen in a fighting game.  

All in all it is an impressive package, with super high production values and a ton of different things to do, that is held back by the fighting system that underpins the whole thing, and some questionable quality of life choices.  That being said, the game is fun, I have been having a lot of fun playing it and have been still firing up the online from time to time, and provides a lot of value, and it is easy to recommend to anyone who is even slightly interested.  

7/10

I by no means blame NR studios for this as this is WBs fault. They rushed NB, made wild decisions that were forced onto them in terms of what to prioritize, and then here we are. I have a love hate with this game. 

If you're in-between casual and competitive like me then this game is just hard to recommend. The content is in two modes, one which is grinding, the other which is just pvp. There is also the standard arcade and arcade endings. But costumes? All locked behind pay walls. OP characters? Also behind pay walls (see Khamelon). It's difficult to recommend this game to anyone that is more casual than competitive but also likes winning and learning fighting games. Street fighter is too hard on me, and I'm not a fan of tekken, so I play Mk1 but it is featureless compared to those two. I might seriously start tekken because of it.

What I will say, is that if you are at rue casual player this game is fun for the fatalities and learning the game. This game is an amazing game in practice mode, but in practice it has more than just a few issues. Wait a year when they drop the inevitable complete edition (but of course the game will be dead by then).

I keep updating this because I've played a lot of this game and love the franchise. The core, 30-second gameplay loop is there, that's it. The cosmetic system is flawed, rushed, and predatory. The net code for pc remains nigh-unplayable after 4 months of release. The only real change to the game, besides the initial nerf to the Cyrax Kameo, has been DLC and Invasion changes.

Invasions. How one traverses through the mode is absolute dogwater. Tedious and commits the cardinal sin of gaming in just feeling like a second job. The 'Klues' are coded so poorly that one often doesn't even have to figure them out ... you can just walk through half of them.

The cosmetics. I'm not paying more money on a $70 game that feels this rushed. The only way to gain currency of this kind is to GRIND. What cosmetics are free are just pallette swaps of two costumes or gained from RNG due to the shrine. Krypts gone, better hope you like slot machines. Also gone is the level of cosmetics. Each character has two default costumes and a single item swap (Raiden's hat, Scorpion's Mask, Shao's axe) 

Speaking of the grind. NRS has reduced the offline, tower, and local gains of Profile XP, Player XP, and THREE. DIFFERENT. CURRENCIES. Leaving the consumer to either have a good online friend they play with. Or grind one fight in invasions.

Pros:
-Good graphics and visual art style
-Big improvement in score/soundtrack
-An alright story mode for a fighting game but with a lot of references to previous parts which is good for old time fans
-Most of the new character designs are good
-No Bo Rai Cho 

Cons:
-An unacceptable amount of bugs on release some of which might still be present in the game both visual and gameplay
-FPS lock (60 FPS during fight and 30 everywhere else including fatal blows)
-Price
-Ads on main menu
-No Krypt, no Konquest mode
-No crossplay (Unlike Street Fighter 6 and Tekken 8)
-DLC fatalities (lmao)
-No badass, fun big bosses at the end of the arcade ladder like in MK 1-9
-Mediocre and boring "Invasion" mode which replaced krypt and konquest mode where you grind recolored alt skins by doing same thing which is easy and doesn't even require you to use new exclusive to that mode mechanics (Elements and Amulets). While it has different seasons and each update changes rewards and end boss it's nothing but a FOMO mode with the same gameplay each season just with different recolor of minigames projectiles and recolored alt costume rewards
-Slowest possible character and kameo leveling system unless you're into grinding invasion mode
-Some characters require more skill to do big damage while others can do the same amount of damage with less effort which can be frustrating in online mode.

 Going through "Invasions" mode gameplay at the release with obviously boring and annoying mechanics to then get them removed/nerfed felt like I was some beta tester for future players (not hard mechanics but ones that would drag and waste time in an already boring mode even more).

 If you're a casual player then the game doesn't justify the cost with all it's issues and for what it offers content wise. If you're more into online play then get ready to face mostly same meta characters.
 At the end of the day it's still Mortal Kombat but it feels like all the actual fun stuff are getting removed with each installment in favor of making more money and raising e-sports since this franchise is still considered among the best at least for now.

The texture experience of this game is great for me. The plot is full of ups and downs, captivating, and the Chinese characters have a lot of scenes. I love watching Liu Kang versus Shang Tsung. However, the reason I give a negative review is that Warner has a tunnel vision on Chinese culture and pretends to understand it!
Firstly, the form of HanFu has a cross-necked right lapel. Most of the people wearing left lapels are nomadic ethnic minorities, and left lapels are often seen in burial objects and tomb murals of the deceased.
Secondly, why does the tea house have a slogan selling cookies? Overall, I really enjoy the rhythm of fighting between Raiden and Bi-Han, but I have never seen a Chinese person add ice to his tea. It would be much more reasonable to switch to a milk tea shop.
Thirdly, it's really okay if the dubbers can't speak authentic Mandarin Chinese, but can you stop using messy accented pronunciations to fool us?
Finally, the portrayal of female characters is becoming increasingly hasty. I really love Princess Kitana in the double buns in MKX, please design more ancient hairstyles like this. The voices of Kronika and Shang Tsung are really unique, they’re amazing! I will never hate a menacing and charming villain. But Shang Tsung's men's hairpin ornaments are completely different from ancient Chinese styles, and there are so many styles that can be borrowed from HanFu. I'm not intentionally causing trouble, it's just that these common sense concepts only require a little careful understanding and won't go wrong.
In addition, the guest appearance system further imbalances the fairness of skills. Perhaps adding a 5V5 multiplayer mode would be more interesting?

这款游戏的手感对我来说很棒，剧情跌宕起伏、引人入胜，中国角色的戏份很足，就爱看刘康对战尚宗，但我打差评的原因在于华纳对于中华文化根本视野狭隘、不懂装懂！
首先，汉服是交领右衽。穿着左衽的大多是少数游牧民族，左衽也常出现在逝者的随葬品和墓室壁画中。
其次，茶楼为什么会贴有卖曲奇标语？总体上我很喜欢雷电和避寒的打戏节奏，但我从没见过有中国人喝茶时加冰块的，如果换成奶茶店会合理很多。
第三，如果配音演员不会说正版的普通话真的没关系，但能不能不要再用乱七八糟的口音读法来糊弄我们？
最后，女性角色的塑造也越来越草率了事，我很爱第十部里双鬟髻的吉塔娜公主，请多设计这类古风发型。克罗尼卡和尚宗的声线真有特色，太绝了！我永远不会讨厌有威胁性又极富魅力的反派。但尚宗的男性发冠完全不像中国古代款式，明明汉服里有那么多可以借鉴的风格。我不是在故意找麻烦，只是这些常识只需稍稍用心了解一下就不会出错。
此外，客串系统令技能公平性更加失衡。也许添一个5V5模式会更有趣？

Good game, terrible product. MK1 is fun once you get to the gameplay but everything outside of it is awful. It's amazing how far back quality of life has regressed.

Trying to play online feels bad because I'm stuck on the menu waiting, there's no training mode matchmaking or anything else to do while waiting, you're just put on hold. Then, when I find a match, I'm treated to 15-30 seconds of a completely black screen. It's not a proper loading screen with any kind of feedback, just a long moment of wondering whether the game has frozen. I've also tried private lobbies but trying to set up King of the Hill with two friends consistently crashed the game.

Single player modes feel similar. Invasions are a good idea for a single player mode but every animation and loading screen feels so sluggish that it ends up being more frustrating than fun. The story mode is OK, I don't really like where the story went but that's up to preference.

What really bothers me is the online. I found the ranked matchmaking experience very similar to Tekken 7, and at least Tekken has training mode matchmaking and gives you a proper "get ready for the next battle" screen during those 15-30 seconds of loading. I can't really explain how much MK1 feels like it's going to crash at any minute, and I'm comparing it to a NINE year old game here.

It's impossible to recommend a AAA game in this state, even if the fighting game hiding underneath is fun. I can't believe WB had the gall to publish this after Street Fighter 6 showed everyone what a finished AAA product should look like in 2023.

This game deserves more positive feedback than it's currently getting. Yes single player modes are currently a little boring, but the kameo system, depth and range of combo route options, and graphics in general all make it worth it. This game requires a heavier investment for online (especially competitive) to be enjoyable, but if you like the lab and learning characters and combos this game is worth the time it takes to learn all that. I have barely scratched the surface and I like how much more there is to learn just with gameplay, strategy, combos, kameos and all that. Not perfect but by far my favorite fighting game.

A modern, $70 USD fighting game should work properly. Instead, it's riddled with bugs, especially on PC, and locked to 30 fps in many places (why? I have no idea). It still doesn't have crossplay either four months after launch, so I haven't been able to play with several of my friends this whole time.

A $70 game should also be respectful of our time and money. Instead, unlocking Havik requires either playing out the story mode or spending an additional $8. Kameos are in a similar situation, and the dollars option to unlock them immediately is $20. Also Shang Tsung is another $8 if you didn't pre-order, and there's no alternative there. NONE of this is included with the Premium Edition.

So, if you want to buy this game today and immediately have access to all the characters and kameos that were available at launch, it'll cost you $106 total. Otherwise, it'll cost you $78 and several hours of grinding.

Omni-Man? He's not included in any of that. Would you like to buy Kombat Pack 1 for $40 more? I did, but I regret it now.

I have been a big fan of MK Since the 1st one came out in arcades so to say that I was really looking forward to this instalment is a understatement,   I have played all of the MKs.

Unfortunately NRS  amd WB has really dropped the ball with this game.  

The game play is fun and I really like the roster and the story was ok.  However there is a significant lack of features in this game for the single player and this game has been plagued by mass amounts of bugs since launch.  Current'y there are still massive desyncing between players in all online modes leaving it difficult for players to have matches.  Jan 22 2024

Not only that but this game is a full price AAA game that was launched without cross-play.  Games like Street Fighter 6 and Tekken 8 which will be released this week have at launch.

Also the the monetisation is so egregious with skins up to 10$ and fatalities and announcers the same.

Also communication from the development team is next to nothing.  Players have been dealing with disconnects for over 6 weeks now with only recently a small statement about the problem being addressed.

It's clear that NRS and WB are only concerned about profit.  As a MK fan I cannot recommend this game to players.  Go buy tekken for sf6.  You will get way more value for you dollar.

MK1 is fun to play if you're playing matches with your friends, however the game feels heavily unfinished.

- Microtransactions are at an all time high just like MK11.
- Compared to MK11, there's an extreme lack of customisation.
- Story seemed short and unfinished.
- Kameo system is lame. It would have been better if all characters could be selected as your 1st and 2nd character, and it played like a tag team fight. This could also create a gamemode where two players can play on the same team and battle together.
- The gameplay lacks a few things from previous titles such as stage interactions, krushing blows, friendships, longer introductions.

It pretty much feels like a work in progress towards Injustice 3.
I preferred MKX for the gameplay and MK11 for the customisation.

Is it MK? Yes. Are the cinematics pretty good? Yeah. Unfortunately that's about it.

This game is LOADED with microtransactions like a mobile game. For a game that charges full price it feels like an early access product in terms of its base content. The roster is small, the story is incomplete, and for early buyers the game was incredibly buggy and has needed months or updates to even preform acceptably.  

The biggest sin though is not only will you be asked to spend MORE money than the initial price for each and every DLC character but you'll also be asked to pay for every new skin, every new stage, and every new fatality. Yes, even the fatalities are being gated behind microtransactions. 

But hows the gameplay? In a word, simple.  Once you learn one character you've learned them all. The control scheme is highly simplified and the game actively punishes more technical/difficult combos. You've got air juggles, assist characters, special and super cancels but it all feels like a waste once you realize that your combos will quickly cap out in damage around 40% no matter how crazy you get with your imaginative combos. At the same time EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER can do a basic 3 or 4 hit string, into assist, repeat that, then do a special move at the end for about 60% with very little effort. The characters are only slightly unique and basically all play with this same basic gameplan and combo structure. 

Last thing I want to mention. MK is a brand near to my heart, I grew up with these games and I've spent my entire life thus far at least trying every single game, movie, web series, etc. for better or worse. This game is one of the worst. In terms of content its actually weaker than some mobile games. 

If you REALLY want to pick this up I hope you do it during a really good sale and I recommend getting into mods because the community made skins are free and made at an embarrassingly higher quality than the official stuff they want you to pay an additional $10 for. 

Last last thing. Invasion mode is possibly the laziest and most boring waste of a gamemode ever added to any fighting game.

Game play is good for a couple of weeks, but fizzles out pretty quickly. Online is bad, netcode sucks and the whole match making system feels like it was slapped on the last week before launch. To play the game, you need to learn one or two combos for your character of choice (most characters have combos that take close to 50% of your opponents life) land that combo twice and you win. Some characters take very little investment to get to that point (eg. Raiden) and most Raiden players play the character the same way. Outside of the online modes, the game doesn't really offer anything that's enjoyable to the casual player so you either enjoy ranked/friendly matches or you don't play at all.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend MK1 in its current state. The technical issues really prevent me from liking this game, the core gameplay is better than MK11 but everything else is a downgrade, the game looks worse than MK11 and runs worse, the netcode has been downgraded somehow, there's nothing really worth going for because Invasions aren't interesting enough to keep playing, the Shrine is a soulless replacement of the Krypt from prior games, maybe it'll get better over time like MKX and 11 did but when we have Street Fighter 6 out and Tekken 8 out in just a few days as of writing this, you have much better choices right now instead of hoping this game gets better.

This game is incredibly strange for what is considered the "COD of fighting games". It should have been a slam dunk and the sales would tell you that, but the game is dying because of poor management. When I bought the game it was a buggy mess, basically a party game and not a competitive fighting game. I decided to take a 2 month break to let them patch out the bugs and improve game. 2 DLC characters and a balance patch and the game still isn't there yet. It may never reach it's full potential. It's sad because the addition/idea of Kameos in MK is actually fun in a vacuum until you go online or play any of the solo content, which is severely lacking compared to MK11. It's a bummer because I like to lab my character and there's no incentive to do any of that because this game is a chore to play.

- Netcode is terrible in this golden age of fighting games.
- Has chronic desync issues.
- Load times are very long (I have an SSD).
- Finding a match online takes too long (avg 3-5 mins at a time without freezes).
- Rematch load times are long.
- Invasions, the main single player content is painfully dull.  
- The game is overly monetized.
- No crossplay.
- Game is unfinished and there are modes that are present but not accessible today.

I purchased the premium edition and a month later the standard edition was on sale for $30. Don't buy into the MK marketing hype and always wait for a sale when it's from NRS. I would wait for more patches and a sale if you are still interested.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a game that is fun to go back to every once in a while. There are problems with this game that would turn people away. For example: There is no cross-play online, the net code is not great for online players, the game can get a bit glitchy no matter what mode you are playing in, and there's not enough content to keep the players playing this overpriced game. 

For Casuals who prefer to play single-player content, there's not enough content to keep you occupied. There are only Story Mode, Invasions, and Towers. That's about all you are getting. Story is great to watch and play, so thumbs up for that. I understand the idea of what they wanted Invasions to be, but to me it feels like it just didn't turn out the way they wanted. In my opinion, Invasions looked like they wanted to make something similar to Konquest, only it turned out to be too repetitive, too grindy, and it just gets boring fast. And Towers are just towers. You have the Arcade towers, 25 Character Survival Tower, and Endurance Tower.

I hear that Online is not great either, but since I am not at all interested in Kombat League, or even Casual Matches/King of the Hill, I couldn't tell you just how bad it is.

Do I recommend buying this game for folks who are interested in playing this game? ONLY if you want to play. I won't force anyone to not buy this game.  I don't recommend playing this game for now, but maybe in the future, this game will get its second wind and be a good game. I have hope for this game. I really do. I genuinely enjoy playing this game by myself or with friends. 

I won't allow comments on this post mainly because I am tired of seeing people's posts/replies complaining about games when they use the words "Garbage", "Trash", or that this game "sucks". I mean I get it, they are just voicing their opinions and everything, but it is hard for me personally to take anyone seriously when they use those words without any reasonable explanation why they think that way. I am not defending this game at all. I am mainly disappointed that this game turned out the way it did. Hope you all have a nice day and thank you for reading this lame review of mine. :)

[h1] MK1: A lackluster product [/h1]
I believe I've thoroughly played enough of this game to give a valid review. 

Before you continue, you should know that I'm just a guy who loves MK and I'm by no means a fighting game guru

[h2] The Good [/h2]

That said, this gameplay fun as hell. I've played UMK3, MK9, and MK11 and though the kosmetics and single-player modes in MK11 are superior (and kustomization fleshed out), at its core, MK1's kombat with the new Kameo system is one of coolest design decisions imo. It adds a level of creativity (at least it should be), for a new style of play. 

The tutorial is fantastic too, which makes getting into this game super easy for those new to fighting games (there's also an unsuspecting drawback to this, but more on that later).

Love or hate the story mode, you can tell they put the most effort in crafting the kampaign. Props to NRS for making an exciting soft-reboot of a beloved franchise, komplete with badass kharacters that I think anyone with no knowledge of MK Lore would enjoy as an introduction to it.

[h2] The Bad [/h2]

Sadly, the bad things outnumber the good things in its current state. I'll name a few in a list but I want to talk about one specific thing that makes me wanna take a break and uninstall for the time being:

1. Constant freezing and desynchronizations in online matches (even after patch)
2. Repetitive Single-player mode (Invasions)
3. Microtransactions and Premium Currency existing
4. Mostly boring seasonal kosmetic unlocks
5. Paywall for Shang Tsung, Quan Chi, and Ermac
6. Some bugs and glitches (kharacters not facing the right way, combos not triggering)

[h2] The Ugliest [/h2]
And finally, my biggest gripe: META Fighter-Kameo comps.

Now I know competitive games always have 'METAs'. I've shamefully played over 1000 hours of Overwatch, and I hated it there too.

Because just like in Overwatch, after a while it got stale and repetitive.
Want to win games or climb Kombat League ranks for the rewards? Guess what: You HAVE to play certain kharacters or you're at a significant disadvantage.

I'm not sure if I'm in the minority, but the way I choose who to main in games is based on:
1. How cool they look.
2. How cool their lore is.

That said, as cool as the kharacter is, I do NOT want to play Johnny Cage to repeat the same strings over and over just to win a game. Because that's not fun for me at all. That would just make me doze off. Same goes for Raiden, and Omni-Man to name a couple of more.

What I said earlier about the game being "easy for those new to fighting games"? Inversely, because its so easy to get into and master (at least for most kharacters), people can easily pick up the META and start dominating really quick. Your chances of winning against certain kharacters are low regardless of the skill level of the player using them, as long as they memorize the 2 or 3 strings they need.

The game, in turn, encourages you to abandon creativity for some of these Fighter-Kameo comps, because their 'optimal combos' do more damage while being safer to use.

I only played KL because I wanted the kosmetic unlocks, don't really care for rank. But every match-up I get is the same 3 or 4 kharacters, using the same strings, and the same kameos. Even if I do somehow win against them (because you end up memorizing their go-to kombos), it just gets so bland. 

I just want to play who I want, get good at them, and have fun in the process.
The game won't even work properly sometimes with all the other issues I mentioned above. 

Overall, I don't regret buying the premium edition (got it for 30% off). But this game just has so much resistance against anyone who wants kasual pla, like me.

The META may never disappear, and I can live with that, but NRS to wake up and address the other issues plaguing this otherwise fantastic franchise.

Save your money first until this game is fundamentally fixed, or better yet just grab the older titles on sale if you want your kombat fix.
