Where do I even begin...? I'm an MK fan, but I gotta admit, NRS fumbled the bag real badly with this one. I enjoyed MK11 a lot and I think it was a worthy successor of the franchise, Ik a lot of people hated it, people thought it was bland and much more restricted comparing to MKX but at least it had some good online play, tons of content, tons of customization, and some variety of game modes, MK1 brings nothing new to the table, or does it? Ok, let's talk about the elephant in the room... Kameos, this is one of the dumbest ideas I've ever seen in a fighting game, ruining the essence of MK's nature 1v1 Kombat to this weird hybrid of tag team, but instead of 2v2 It's still 1v1, but both players use a main character and a side character? Very bizarre choice, but the mechanic is so badly implemented as well, moves that are unsafe can now be safe on block when you cancel into a kameo, and it's insanely boring to play against or even use it in the first place, special moves or kombo strings that are unsafe there's a reason for it, maybe it's a launcher, maybe it resets the opponent, maybe it extends the kombo for more damage, meaning the high risk - high reward is literally thrown out the window with this new kameo system, this mechanic is so bland and flawed that at some point is turns laughable.
As for the gameplay itself, I genuinely like it, they got rid of the bad things from MK11, and got fixed in this one, no more krushing blows (I still liked some of them, but the requirement sometimes was frustrating and straight unbalanced, specially the 50/50 failed grab ones), no more breakaway, Fatal Blows now start an animation before the hit meaning players can now predict better to punish and made it less spammy, and lastly characters in this game don't need offensive meter to begin kombos, I see this as a very good plus to me, I enjoy some more rushed down aggressive play style as opposed to the more strategic, zoning and slow pace from MK11.  
You only have pretty much 3 game modes as I write this review: Story, Invasions and lastly Towers, the Towers are the same old klassic arcade ladder, Story works exactly the same since MK9 (each character have their own chapter and the fight ends, cinematic begins etc.), and a new game: Invasions is so awful, how do I even describe this.... It's a Map fighter with some elements of RPG and you go ahead and fight against CPU opponents with some modifiers that mostly came from MK11? Whose idea was this?, it's insanely boring, and it gets old pretty quickly, at some point I need to take a break and stop playing Invasions because how boring it is.
Now this section is more about the problems with the PC Port, how can we in 2024 have companies that launch games at 30fps, but oh "the 30fps create a cinematic feel", it's stupid and very out of touch in today's standards of technology, if Smash Bros can run at 60fps on a Switch, or Tekken at 60fps in every platform, absolutely MK1 can run at 60fps on PC (and even consoles), this is laziness at its peak.
And with all of that, there you go, that's MK1, people pay 70€ (or more if you want dlcs) to have this unfinished and broken game, I genuinely think the MK franchise will die once more like Armageddon unless NRS makes a drastic move and changes the game entirely, maybe add more game modes? Create a second versus mode with kameos disabled? Mini-games? Even the krypt is missing for f*** sakes, also why is Test Your Might can't be played by 2 players like in MKX? This is such a waste of opportunity…
I want nothing but success to this franchise, but I really have to put this game as negative, MK9, MKX AND MK11 are 100% superior games to play as opposed to MK1.

This game isn't worth a quarter of what it costs. The character roster is the smallest I've ever seen from a MK game, which could be forgiven if the characters were each unique and varied- they're not. Character designs are unbelievably bland, from their appearance to their boring movesets. Previous fan-favorites are just made uglier and generic. There are fully-programmed characters within the story, like Ermac, which for whatever reason isn't within the roster and is completely unavailable for players.

Half the roster is locked behind paywall, costing $8 EACH on top of a $70 game. I understand the DLC costs for other IPs like Omni-Man and Homelander, but even central, base game characters like Quan Chi and Shang Tsung will run you that $8 price tag. 

While MK of course isn't known for spectacular stories, characters, or voice acting, this game brings it even further down. Absolutely miserable performances from many characters, none more so than Nitara voiced by Megan Fox.

So you shouldn't buy it for great gameplay nor a satisfying story. Are you here for great visuals and fatalities? No. While it's certainly a subjective opinion on this last part, I don't think you'll find anyone saying they liked MK1's visuals over any other entry in the last decade. Graphics are visually passable yet unsatisfactory given the absurd price tag, and the fatalities are simultaneously more cartoonish and unoriginal than MK10 or 11.

I genuinely cannot think of a reason why you should waste your money on this game.

Review is written based on the playthrough of the story. After quite some time i return to a MK title and honestly this did not dissapoint. An intriguing story in a new timeline that offers a new start in a non-Mortal Kombat in a world restarted by Liu Kang offers a feeling of content as, as expected, the plot thickens with the return of some old evil-doers. 

The fighting in itself is smooth and the two fighter system gives it a nice addition in comboing. Graphics are beutiful with a lot of detail, the world is filled with ingredients that make it feel real. The fighting system underwent some changes (i.e. X-ray attack) and feels somewhat simpler to previous titles which is not a bad thing. In my eyes MK was always the simpler fighting title for casuals like me and also more hardcore fighter game players to enjoy. 

The game has some minor issues, the switching between cinematic 30fps and then 60fps in Kombat is a bit straining on the eyes, more sensitive people might have a problem with that, and sometimes the loading times are a bit too long as one would expect them. I think with some further updates the developers will iron this out. what I am missing is also the option of high frame rate that some would argue might be very important in a fighter title. Also the story is a bit short in my opinion although I cannot say it is not enjoyable except for the final climb, that part was a bit lackluster for me. The choice of fighters is more than suitable though I am of the opinion that a triple-A title should not lock characters behind DLC's. In this regard some studios might learn a thing or two from the God of War developers. 

In the end the game still offers quite a bit of enjoyment and those minor faults can be corrected with further updates down the line. And maybe we can hope for a free story DLC with some origin stories of our new-world fighters. If you are a hardcore fan of the MK series you will buy it at any price, in general I would say wait for a sale.

MK1 feels like an unfinished beta, and it seems the companies behind it don't care and/or actively express mockery & sarcasm towards players & fans for their legitimate criticisms. This has gotten so bad that the larger community surrounding the game are in an outright revolt currently, feel free to check the game's socials if you don't believe me.

There's [b]constant[/b] desync issues online. The character grind is [i]absurdly[/i] slow. The gameplay is simple & already stale. The 'Invasions' feel entirely half-assed, and the content included does not justify lasting as long as each Invasion does. They nickle & dime you for costumes that are either uninteresting or worse versions of what past games had- don't get me started on the awful bodysuits & Netherrealm's snark surrounding them, I really could go on & on.

Without any real spoilers; there was great potential with the story mode and the big reset, but it's filled with nonsense and uninteresting high school level melodrama. Then it quickly fizzles-out & rushes to the out-of-left-field finish. The timelines shit has [i]really[/i] jumped the shark, and I'm not alone in feeling that way. If you're really interested, I'd recommend watching it on YouTube as many have instead of playing through it.

Maybe they'll fix it someday, but for now it feels [i]far[/i] below what many players including myself expected.
This review was written purely out of sheer frustration with the state of this game.

I almost forgot to mention this is a $110 game with the first pack, but it sure isn't worth that price at all.

Go play Tekken in a week, it's leagues above this game in almost every regard by the CBT & demo alone.

TL;DR: Fuck this game.

My first time back playing mortal kombat in over a decade, likely two in fact. MK1 is a game that is easy to learn, but a legendary one to master. You can get by as a beginner, and face reasonable competition as one. As a master, you will find much more skilled combo demons, that will show you what can be done when you are rhythm master playing guitar hero or rockband. Its very nice that you can look at your abilities mid match against a cpu and start in the basic section and remember a few at a time. Do those a few times, then move down the list. Once, that list is done, move to the next section and so on and so on. Its very easy to learn this way. Also the combos just seem to make sense as you will quickly memorize most of the abilities and combos, much quicker than i remember when i briefly attempted to play a match awhile back, but that was it, just a match or two. The invasions mode is what i mostly play. It adds a little openness and uniqueness to just spamming fights. Theres level ups, skill points, kaemo fighters, various unlockables, such as relics and pendants that offer var2ying levels of strength as well as stats, from pretty normal, like fire resistance, and shoot fireballs, to wildly unique. One talisman i add actually passed gas at a fighter. Another spawns a bunch of little guys that charge and explode on hitting your opponent. this you can trigger during battle, and has 1 to several. Relics do alot of stuff, from adding passive buffs, to sucking your life, to taunting. They have multiple things that are actively, but passively. The game is amazing. If you have any urge or inkling to buy it, its definitely a safe buy, even if the buy was impulsive. Its Hella Worth it. Thers tower modes, and theres also tower modes within. It has a pretty decent sized cast,awesome kameo fighters that u can triugger to jump in and do once of several moves. Resistances play an important role in the game. So does stats, potions, and other consumable. I left somethings out, but theres quite a bit more, happy suprises!
to make things short, its a Shit game, absolute shit.

Don't listen to the "good reviews." Sonic fox got cooked a few days ago on twitter/X the other day for saying that he wished mk did a little better comparing it to the likes of Tekken 8 knowing fully well that NRS asked him and other pros for insight and feedback during development of the game. MAYBE he didn't know this was going to be mk1 in totallity but that is the current state of things. 
   MK1 players, I mean PLAYERS, not casuals who like watching fatalities have plenty of issues with this game.  People like characters and franchises and remain loyal despite flaws. I get it. I LOVE mortal kombat. I was excited for it like I was for elden ring after years of dumping HOURS onto dark souls 1-3. I played the crap out of MK11 and don't regret one single bit. Despite my unwavering loyalty for female ninjas and cool ass bruce lee archetypes, I decided not to pre-order this game. IM GLAD. IMAGINE PAYING $100 (i think more) for a incomplete game that ASKS YOU TO SPEND MORE FOR THINGS THAT WERE WIDELY AVAILABLE FOR FREE IN MK11. 

   Guys, I spent my weekend playing mk11 for nostalgia. I played kombat league to demigod with skarlet for fun. In between ranked matches, I'd go to look at ALL THE NICE SKINS EVERY CHARACTER CAME WITH. They all had nice gear. After thousands of hours played, I have yet to unlock everything or at least most things via the shrine. I will never forget this particular moment as a gamer till I die. I'm a very tolerant person in the sense that I don't care about alot of details. IF a game is garbage. I'll play it and find some fun in it or overlook things. However, mk1, literally had me say "Wait, that's it?" when the shrine told me "come back next season" or whatever. My wife turned to me as I said that and told me, "well aren't you glad you didn't preorder it?"

   Want to be a franchise slave? Buy it. Maybe they make something better in like 5 years or something.
Want a good game? Maybe wait for Tekken 8 or go back to another fighter that you love. Idk man. Im going to play mk11 until they drop skarlet in mk1 (RIP not happening). OR maybe I'll just go play elden ring till the dlc comes out. That may be an abysmal time to wait but I WILL LOVE EVERY SINGLE SECOND because it's fun and has tons of content. Tell me I'm wrong. I'll just assume you think 6Arakin is good.

MK1 is the first Netherrealm Game to not immediately grab me unfortunately. I hopped on the MK bandwagon with the MK9 reboot and was hooked on Netherrealm Games ever since. It sucks to see a once great company be reduced to what it is now, between the micro transactions galore, pre-order bonuses, and scummy tactics it really does feel like a whole different beast. 

You can only get Shang-Tsung, the villain of the game, through pre-ordering or handing over real money. On top of that 4 other characters/Kameos are also purchasable from the start, however you're able to unlock them just by playing the story which they very sneakily leave out. So not only is the game $70, but you also don't get access to all the characters that you technically ALREADY payed for as their characters downloads are required to play the game. 

Online matchmaking is actually wild, as I currently have a W/L of 20/11 and am being matched against actual gods with a W/L in the 500/300s. Why. 
They bring back Kombat League, which can be a fun way of unlocking new outfits for your favorite characters, you just have to be able to recognize frames at the speed of The fucking Flash, and react accordingly, or you'll get wiped from one screen to the other by guys doing 50% combos with ease and calling you a slur for even daring to hop in the ring with prime Mike Tyson.

The big gimmick of this MK is the new addition of the "kameos" as they couldn't be bothered to actually include playable fan favorite characters and instead made them your sidekick and gave them 2 moves to do as combo extenders. Good luck finding anyone not using Sareena for her blade attack over and over again. They also made this game a lot floatier, with the addition of air combos and air specific moves, they just forgot to give everyone more than 2 combo starters or any launcher at all, making half of their move set completely useless for some. 

Instead of towers this time they have "invasions" which is their way of getting the community off their back about bringing back conquest mode from older titles. And instead of The Krypt this time around, you get to just piss away 1000 hard earned coins at a time into a dragons mouth and watch it burn it all away in the random hopes of getting something actually cool aside from a yellow color swap for Goro or something stupid.

All in all its got a little something for everybody, 10/10 really makes me FEEL like Scorpion. Cant wait for Injustice 3

(usually i don't post reviews but i care a lot about MK and i want to see it improve) The trajectory of game development raises concerns, evoking a sense of undue haste that is palpable in the gaming experience. NRS's pricing strategy for skins introduces a disconcerting dynamic, as these cosmetic enhancements, priced significantly, disappointingly lack substantive alterations to the characters' apparel. Instead of offering a transformative visual experience, these skins merely tinker with color schemes, leaving players yearning for more meaningful customization options. Moreover, the audacious move of charging $10 for a cut-scene, readily available for passive consumption on platforms like YouTube, raises eyebrows within the gaming community. The invasions mode, laden with untapped potential, falls short of expectations, delivering an experience that feels lackluster and burdensome to engage with. The game's mechanics beg for a more refined and immersive gameplay design to fully capitalize on the richness that the concept of invasions holds. The disheartening aspect surfaces when hard-earned skins lose their exclusivity, promptly making their appearance in the in-game shop in the subsequent season. This renders the arduous grind for skins during invasions seemingly meaningless, as the allure of exclusivity dissipates. The dichotomy emerges starkly when considering that individuals with disposable income can effortlessly bypass the grind by resorting to real money transactions. This strategic maneuver raises questions about the game's ethos, seemingly driven by corporate greed rather than a commitment to enhancing the gaming experience. The juxtaposition of prioritizing profit over rectifying fundamental issues within the game speaks volumes about the overarching motivations at play. Despite these reservations, the enduring connection to the game persists, anchored in a nostalgic bond with a beloved franchise from one's formative years. The reluctance to witness this cherished franchise tarnished by profit-centric decisions underscores the tension between the passion for the game and the disenchantment with the corporate interests steering its course.

Warning: Mortal Kombat 1 unfortunately seems to have issues with some people's hardware - mine included - which results in very severe stuttering during gameplay. This appears to happen on both very high end systems as well as lower end machines and although some online seem to have found fixes, many, myself included, have no way of making the game run properly. Even with a top-of-the-line CPU and graphics card, I find the game borderline unplayable in multiplayer. 

I think the story mode is very silly, very fun, and has some great cinematics. However, the gameplay is definitely worse than MK11, and the online experience and competitiveness of the game does not hold up to the likes of Strive and SF6.

Putting all of that together, I don't think this is worth the buy at full retail price unless you are a die-hard fan. But, if it goes on a big sale and you've like the previous MK cinematic story modes, give it a shot.

Underwhelming is the right word.

-janky performance. Acknowledged by the devs.

-The story is fine but the ending is like the writers were like "fuck it! random dude fights the final boss and wins 'cuz power of friendship!"

-Tutorials explain the basics of the game and how the Kameo system works. But nothing specific character wise. 
For example: this string is good for whiff punishing, use this as an ati-air, use this for punishing a recovery heavy attack on block, etc.
No fast scrolling the Move List. No way to tag special moves nor combos.

-Multiplayer menu is a joke: you select your team, the mode & you enter matchmaking. Can't practice in the meantime. Gotta love looking at the fire spinning thing. Ranking per account, not fighter used (like SF6).

-Kustomization is one accesory (mask, weapon), the outfit (skin and their respective color pallette). Which is an improvement compared to MK11 imo.

-invasion is just filler material.

-We could be getting cross-play soon (tag was removed from store page). Doesn't have a ping meter during a match.

Edit: play it on console if you can. Players lag switch on this shit.

The story is pretty fun, there are some great characters and cool cut scenes. For single player everything ran smoothly but as soon as I transitioned to MP my frames dropped exponentially and it is very hard to play. I'm well above the min requirements so I'm pretty disappointed and might just hold off playing anymore tell there is a patch or something.
Edit: I really like the idea of this game and sometimes enjoy playing it but i just cant devote dozens of hours of learning character combos. Unfortunately that is exactly what is needed to even think about touching multiplayer. out of all my matches and lots of practice I still couldn't win one match. I have not ran into an account with less than a total of 60 matches under their belt and I no longer feel any enthusiasm about trying multiplayer as there simply is no one near my skill level to play against. If you like fighting games and have spare time I definitely recommend it, as I still recognize it as a great game.

the 1st MK in years I won't play much... sadly... I am a huge fan of the franchise but it lacks all the good stuff 11, 9 and 10 had... good game... but WB turned out to put too much money in greedy mechanics / systems + massive promotion.. for a game that does not deliver ..except on the single player story mode..

Story Mode :   9.5/10 
Good reboot and connections and winks to previous MK titles.. fun ride overall 

Gameplay : 7.5/10
Its is definitely a watered down version of Mk11...  

you can no longer configure your characters moves leaving less space on that front, where you gain variety is with the kameo fighters you pick that can add to your main character playstyle and patch some weaker points... 
its a bit messy / clunky and visually overstimulating when 4 characters are on screen throwing powers... 
this said, gameplay is as tight as you can expect from the MK franchise, 
with more aerial combinations then the previous titles... roster is small but solid and kombat pack will give us full fan service I don't doubt it.. 

Visuals: 8.5/10

Story mode is pretty overall and well directed
Environments are gorgeous (using the full potential of UNREAL ENGINE) ... 
its very colorful and pink and purple , but some other environments can be dark and gore too.. so it balance in a way. 

character designs:  7/10
for most of them, they are less detailed and a bit more uncanny than MK11, 
some designs are better than others

Fatalities : 6/10
 They are shorter and faster.. still super gore as expected but very buggy at times.. 

Extra : 

As all else, the gear system is minimal, 
and reduced to one item customisable per character, which leave barely any room to customisation, 
which is a bit sad, 
skins are rare but nice but you can no longer change skins in the local fight menu before a fight or have many choices... so you stick with what you chose in the Kustomisation menu.. 

INVASIONS: 4.5/10

Meh.. its kind of the only way to unlock stuff.. 
appart from throwing your gold to the shrine.. 
its an ok but very minimalistic long tutorial with many fights... 
with very basic, almost cheesy mobile game app mechanics.. pepperred with rpg components that you barely control

If they bring DLC'S, hoping they add to the gear system or bring tag team.. 

Feels like a watered mk11 variant with some good and bad stuff

overall a fun game, good story, but not a step up... even a step back in some spheres..

In the original review I wrote for this, I was very upset as I actually tried to refund the game and get rid of it despite being a huge MK fan. The reason for this was because even though I spend lots of cash pre-ordering the game for early access and access to all the DLC content it would not work on my computer. This game was plagued with horrible stuttering and frame-rate issues at launch that finally subsided for me a coupe months ago (that was in Nov. 2023). PC players to this day are still having similar issues that I was having when I first got the game. Second, the new invasions mode is boring, repetitive, and either too easy or bullshit depending on the level/fight you choose on the map. The invasions map is uninteresting, the leveling is boring, and the challenges and challenge fights are usually confusing or unnecessarily difficult and test patience rather than skill. What makes this even more unfortunate is that leveling up characters is faster when playing the invasions mode, and new unlockable cosmetics for each season are usually only earned through invasions.

How do I say all this and put this game as "recommended"? I have seen other reviewers on Steam say this for years so this is not a new complaint, but I wish there was a "mixed" review option. The gameplay and story mode are great. It is awesome seeing the characters have their stories reset especially since this is the 12th main line game in the franchise. This allows for newcomers to enjoy the story and for fans to appreciate the new character development and compare it with past entries. The fighting feels solid enough and is better than MK11 in my opinion as the separate offensive and defensive bars have been merged into the EX meter again which is a much better system. Fatal blows still exist which is frustrating if you play the game a lot because you will see one almost every fight. You are encouraged to use it as it has armor to go through opponents attacks, they need 3 EX bars and their Kameo to combo break it, and it plays a flashy animation that is cool the first few times but gets old the longer you play the game (this has been an issue since X-rays in MKX, though fatal blows are better in my opinion as players cannot spam their "ultimate" ability in MK11 or this game). The Kameo system is also a bit silly in my opinion and only changes up the game slightly. Most characters I play I use the Kameo system to make up for shortcomings of the main characters I play instead of experimenting with different play-styles. For example, with Omni-Man why would I use any other Kameo besides Kung Lao? That Kameo makes up for his lack of low moves and allows for full screen mix-ups. Some may argue that there are other character options for lows such as frost but frost is objectively a worse pick as Omni-Man already has great pressure and just needs some more ways to mix-up and break his opponent's guard. I often find myself forgetting to use Kameos or just spamming the one ability I actually picked them for instead of trying new things, and this happens in towers, practice, and ranked games. I wish we got more playable fighters instead of the Kameos as balancing is a bigger issue (which NRS does not need, they already have a hard time getting the balance right without assist fighters).

Despite all of this I still think this is a fun game if you play it for the story, play it local/casually with friends or family, or play it to get better online and rank up. You will not be able to level everything up very easily if you stay away from invasions, but at least you will have a more enjoyable time with the game actually playing the modes that are tried and true to this series. MK1 story and fighting is a 8/10 while invasions is a solid 0/10 piece of shit mode that needs to be re-worked or changed completely. Or they could just do character and rotating towers like in MK11 but not hide it within the invasions menu and make you sit through BS load screens to access. Thanks for reading.

I'd like to preface all of these issues will be forgiven if they add Kabal as a playable character

The shrine is the worst thing they could have added to this game, pay 1000 koins for a long ass animation that's essentially a slot machine for one random thing that might not even be a skin. How did it go from the amazing Krypt in MK11 to this. Another extension of this issue comes from the severe lack of customization, you can choose from palettes for certain skins, and you get one choice of gear to change, which half the time is either a mask or a characters weapon, another downgrade from MK11s great customization. 

The menus even on a good system take as long to navigate as it takes for your opponent to pull of their long ass combos. You have to wait a solid 5 to 6 seconds between each menu, which it an extreme turn off especially for a game made in 2023. Also for some reason the game is locked at 60 fps and the menu and fatal blows are locked at 30, and there's no cross play yet, which is unfortunate.

The Invasions mode and single-player options in general boring and inferior to other games (except for the story, I actually enjoyed that very much). Invasions is a glorified conveyor belt of fights like the tower but you can walk on the map and do "challenges" for boring skins. The reason I gripe about the lack of fun single-player options is due to the fact that the multiplayer in this game is without a doubt one of the most absurdly annoying things I've ever had the misfortune of playing. Also the main towers that serve as a source for cosmetics are a chore to navigate through and don't even show you the rewards that you get.

The DLC prices are pretty bad, like really bad actually. Kombat Pack 1 costs almost as much as the full game which is insane for just a few characters. And then there's the fact that Shang Tsung is blocked by paywall, which is also dumb considering you can play him in the campaign. It's like they were literally teasing your balls with it.

Hopefully in the future most of the issues I have get ironed out so I can enjoy the game as much as I did previous titles, but as it stands, even barring the ridiculous DLC prices, the game doesn't feel as fun as it should be. Hopefully they add some more enticing single player content in the future, something like MK9 or MK11.

With these reasons I can't in good faith recommend this to any sane human being, but I'm a cuck so I'm probably still gonna play the game a shit load anyways. Ok bye

This Mortal Kombat is one of my new favorites!

The legendary Mortal Kombat series has returned, following up on the story of Mortal Kombat 11, after the events of the previous game Liu Kang has restarted time and stunted the power of the malevolent forces from the previous time line.  The realms are living in peace, or as peaceful as the realms can be.. BUT Keeping with tradition it's time for a new Mortal Kombat competition, and this time Outworld is the host.  The game follows the events of the competition  and introduces some new or could it be familiar villians.. time will tell..

The Story - Wow, the story is amazing, it plays like a movie, you watch a really interesting set of stories, and then you are introduced to a fight, then more story..  This could be the setting of the next movie and it would be completely awesome.. in fact the whole storyline seen the previous few games has been really amazing.. This one follows suit.  I don't even really enjoy fighting games but managed to actually play this one all the way through.

Gameplay - If you've played one Mortal Kombat you've likely played them all..  They pretty much all play the same with some minor alterations.  The game is broken down into a few different sections. 

The first one is Story mode, where you play through the amazing story.  

The second one is Invasion, which sees you play through a bunch of different battles, level up characters, level up Kamoas (various fighters from previous game that act as your helper during battles) and level up your account.  

The third is towers, which is your traditional Mortal Kombat experience, you pick the tower you want to tackle of various sizes..  You can also select the difficulty level. A great way to level up characters and kamoas, and if you enjoy the old school Mortal Kombat this will be for you..

Last and certainly least is the Multiplayer, while I say least, that might not be the case for everyone, but it is for me.. I'm just not a big multiplayer guy, especially in fighting games, so this was never going to be my cup of tea,, although from what I hear it's exceptionally good this time around, but for me, I'm on the shallow end of the fighting game pool.

Pro's

Great Story, like literally amazing (did I mention I hate fighting games)
Easy Controls and Fatalities (In older games I could never do a fataility, in this one they were super easy.. not brutalities on the other hand. OUCH)
Awesome graphics 
Easy BUT Grindy achievements (100% this game and I hate fighting games lol) 

Con's 

I suck at multiplayer (not really sure it's a con, but one for me)
Certain battles are complete cheese
Quite a few crashes when doing towers 

Recommendations 

I recommend this game for the story alone, it was probably the best 8 hours I ever spent playing a fighting game.  Also for those achievement hunters you can easily 100% this game, although be ready for a fairly intense and boring grind, getting 5 kameos to max level, going to take ALONG time and doing the same invasion over and over and over again.  The price might be a bit steep if fighting games aren't your thing, so keep that in mind.  I bought the Premium Edition, but at a steep discount.  I felt like my money was well spent. BTW nothing more fun then using Johnny Cage and punching people in the Go Nads.

I've been hesitant to post my feelings about this game because I know I'm in the minority on this. 

Lets get the obvious points out of the way. It's a Mortal Kombat game, therefore it is awesome by default. Compared to other fighting games, MK1 awesome. The game looks great, has awesome game play, a lot to do, and has continued support updates. Everything you'd want to have in a AAA fighting title. 

HOWEVER, I feel this game really shows a lack of compassion. Which is very unusual for this studio. It feels like left over ideas, and characters from MK9, MK10, and MK11 where all compiled into this game, and the story line had to make sense around these limitations. (Ex. Why does Havik have such a large role in the story? Isn't Havik viewed as a more humorous character in the series? It makes me wonder if Mokap was unavailable for this role?) MK10 and MK11 both had fuller rosters and better story lines. If you are a long term fan of the series, it won't take long to realize MK1 is a retelling/rehash of MK: Deadly Alliance, and MK: Armageddon. It is very clear. Which is a shame because the previous three installments have done such a good job establishing a new timeline. These games where able to completely reinvent the series and separate it from the darker PS2/XBOX/GAMECUBE days. Why return to this time after all this effort has been put in to separate yourselves from it?

I do like the idea of Tag Kombat, and I thought it worked well in MK11. Unfortunately, MK1 does not pull this off as well. By separating the roster into "Fighter" and "Tag Partner" (whatever they are referred to as in game) groups, it limits the fighter select screen. Additionally, by separating the roster this way, it relegates iconic characters (Jax, Goro, and even Sonya) to merely minor, background, assisting characters. This could have absolutely been optimized better. It's really disappointing. What pushes this complaint over into frustration is some of the characters can be used as both a fighter or a partner (Sub Zero, Scorpion, etc.) If this is the case, why aren't all the playable characters interchangeable? This just shows a lack of effort on the developers part.    

ADDITIONALLY, paying full price for a "complete" game only to have to wait for each additional character to be "revealed" is marketing nonsense. It's greedy, and it really shows. If I pay full price for both the main game and DLC, I expect the content to be there. I basically spent an extra $40 on 1-2 characters. The other characters will not be released for months.  if the developers have no issues uploading new costumes and minor cosmetics for additional fees, then please put the content I already paid for in the game. This seems like a very reasonable and understandable request. 

Will I always love Mortal Kombat? 
Yes. 

Will I put a lot of hours into this title? 
Absolutely. 

However, when the next installment is released, I will not be buying any "deluxe" editions. I will get the base game and wait to see how they decide to "unveil" the complete game. This game is the product of what happens when marketing people get involved with video games. Everything is about making money, not about satisfying your customers.

Pretty Disappointing. This game is a huge step down and backwards from MKX &MK11. Weak roster, almost zero customisation of the characters, limited finishers. The Kameo system is a fraction of what Modifiers gave us in past games. And if you liked the Cyber-Ninja, Special Forces, High Technology aspect of past games, you can kiss that goodbye; this story is straight up Kung-Fu with a touch of Fantasy, by way of Outworld. 
As a fighter it's great, and plays tight. MK always delivers there. However, a lot of what worked so well over the past couple of MK games, and drew players back to the series, seems to have been tossed out the window.
My advice: wait until all the DLC is released and you can pick it up for $25 - $30. 
Until then, enjoy the far superior MK11.

I was really excited for this game, it took something from every other NRS title in a way that I thought would be extremely fun. A dash of MK9's movement, slight amounts of MKX's meter system, and a refined flawless block system and fatal blow system from MK11, all things that would make this game extremely fun when combined with how MK games played. Combos are fun to pull off when you finally learn them, frame data is meant to be respected, as it should be (instead of the crappy flawless block launchers into fatal blow dealing 50% in MK11 when you clearly had your turn), but everything feels slow and grindy elsewhere. Pay 10$ for 3 fatalities, pay 10$ for these really cool skins, or deal with the repetitive grind for the same recolours in Invasions. After the first season I was thrilled, my ADHD brain felt really excited with how fast I was earning all these skins and whatnot, but when the 2nd season hit and I had to do the SAME thing again, instant turn off, per se. You just jock your Strength stat up and uppercut your way through everything, its boring as hell after you've already done that the first time. 

Other problems have included the Player 1 bug which has long been fixed, online is full of people abusing the most OP setups (or just abusing that one Sareena move. Also, people probably being toxic as fuck because why not), and you can't just go to unranked because chances are you'll find people even worse because theres no SBMM, and people complaining about Crossplay (I can see why, personally it never bothered me with this game, but its definitely a bummer when you can't play with your friends on different consoles). 

A big fix to some of these is to make various purchasables earnable at a reasonable amount, maybe even through Invasions, that way Invasions gives you even more and would probably make it feel a lot less slow and grindy, while still providing the option to pay for it that way the people that still wanna spend money to get it faster (or to support the devs) can still do that, and people who can't do that can still obtain it, that way the greedy company still gets their monetary value and people can actually get what they want. Again, the player 1 bug has been fixed for months now, and Crossplay is actually coming. And... people will be people, I guess. The only way the game is TRULY enjoyable is by fighting AI, but even then that'll eventually get boring.

TL;DR, greedy company scams everyone EA style, the only positives is the gameplay, but even then its ruined by repetition and other people being assholes to gain rank.

Another installment in the Mortal Kombat franchise, what else is there to say. It's a great series.

First and foremost, while this game is playable on PC, it isn't fully optimized framerate-wise. Until it's fully fixed, my suggestion is to buy this game for any console that isn't the Switch (unless you have no choice).

That aside, TL;DR for those who don't like to read: there are some definite caveats to MK1, such as being lacking on QoL features, but it offers a much better gameplay experience than that "thing" we called MK11 ever did. A purchase you will not regret at all.

-----

This game is an interesting situation, because in comparison to their previous titles, it's highly apparent that Mortal Kombat 1 is an incomplete package. It comes with a full-length story mode, towers, an all-new Invasions mode, and a number of online features that are fewer than what NRS typically puts out. On top of that, there are some quality-of-life features missing from things like the training mode, though these are gradually being added in via updates.

Hopefully the Krypt makes a return as well, because I'm not feeling this new idea of churning out thousands of coins at a shrine just to unlock stuff. Similar to Invasions, it's dreadfully dull. At least the skins you unlock are cool as heck.

Of course, the most important aspect of just about any game is the gameplay itself, and it pleases me to say that after their disaster with Mortal Kombat 11, NetherRealm has redeemed themselves in my eyes. Unlike with 11, I can pour hours into this game and not feel as if I'm wasting them.

I'm surprising myself with this verdict, honestly, because when the Kameo system was first disclosed, I was irritated. With all due respect to tag-based fighters, they were never exactly my cup of tea, but now that I've put almost 200 hours into this game I can say that I'm not so skeptical about Kameos now. Other than serving as a means of adding in more characters at the cost of full movesets unlike with the main lineup, Kameos offer a multi-layered experience for one-on-one fights - or should I say, two-on-two?

At least I don't have to memorize two full movesets with main characters before getting into a match. Instead I only have to learn at least one main character AND a Kameo's three-, four-, or five-move list before jumping into the action. Spares me some effort.

Anti-airs have improved since MK11, especially with the addition of the up block mechanic, which grants a full combo if used on a jump-in OR a grounded overhead. I still prefer using my jab or uppercut for this purpose, but since there are still some jump-ins that are hard to challenge this way, at least I have something else to fall back on if necessary. Just be advised that up-block loses to lows and throws, the latter of which will deal increased damage.

While Flawless Block makes a return, it no longer offers reversal options like it did in MK11, it just reduces chip damage dramatically. This makes the mechanic much more tolerable as it now rewards excellent defense WITHOUT overly punishing the offender. Excellent change.

Breakers are back, but they cost three bars now. I think block breakers should make a return as well, but alas, no sign of them yet. Would sure help in balancing out the massive chip damage and abundant meter gain, but still, I'll take what we've got instead of that abhorrent Breakaway mechanic we had to use for the last four years.

With how Fatal Blows have retained their role as each character's practical super move without being tied to your meter, you now have two reasons to spend meter instead of three: enhancing your special attacks and allowing you to use your breaker. While saving meter for your breaker is an optimal strategy, you should know that you build meter like candy in this game, so you need not feel shy about enhancing your specials here.

...actually, I misspoke: you have three reasons for your meter still, because the Last Breath mechanic has also returned. If you would die from chip damage, you spend meter to keep yourself in the game, and unlike in MK11, it doesn't permanently delete a block from your meter, so assuming you manage to make a comeback, you can rebuild that bar still.

However...I "have" noticed instances where I would block while still having meter and the Last Breath mechanic does not activate at all. The cause of this eludes me right now. So don't rely on this too much as a safety net.

Some things about this game could be improved still, but frankly, I'm more optimistic for this game than I ever was for MK11. I look forward to seeing what else NRS will do for this game...provided they don't make any missteps.

The story mode, you say? Well...this is NRS. Sindel's retcon in MK11 aside, they've had a good track record with their stories, and now is no different. Go play through it, or give it a watch.

That's my thoughts as of now. There may be adjustments in light of whatever content NRS adds to this game, in which case I will rewrite this review. But for now, BIG thumbs-up from me.

Casual gamer here. I've enjoyed MK1 so far and I've been playing every season of Invasions since launch. Main thing to note is that most of this games value will be wrapped up in the story mode for those who enjoy/are invested heavily in the MK lore like me. 

Invasions can be a mixed bag depending on the level of grinding you are comfortable with. There is mixed reception however I have found invasions to be a bit repetitive, but that is also comparing the experience I had during MK 11 and MKX when dealing with the Krypt. Here you'll find invasions to be a more straight forward experience then the complexities of MK 11's Krypt when achieving goals season to season or in the hunt to unlock items.

The micro transactions can be a bit overwhelming however I find there is enough content season to season and from the shrine aka the MK Koin roulette wheel and have picked up many of the items I actually value such as the maskless ninjas in season 2. The micro transactions I find are really geared towards those who want to add extra features to their main champions such as skins from previous MK games (e.g. Deception or Deadly Alliance), but so far I have found the game to have enough content to satisfy my needs that I don't turn to the store often outside of browsing. It really does feel that the game is having its free content spread out throughout the seasons which for better or worse will probably mean it'll take a bit longer to get everything and removed a bit of the wall I hit with MK 11's Krypt. Though MK 11's krypt was vast it just became a little too tedious for my enjoyment at a certain point.

Hope this helps, happy gaming!

[h3]A really good fighting game that sadly fails to reach the standard set by the recent competition when it comes to features and quality of life.[/h3]

EDIT: I originally gave the game a thumbs up, but since launch. most of the problems I talked about in the review below were not addressed (some are very much ingrained in the games structure), and while NRS seems to be committed to patching the game, they are also releasing new characters at what feels like break-neck speed, while the game itself still has deep issues in matchmaking, weird menus and layout decisions, and a lot of "time wasting" outside of gameplay (why can I only activate the shrine in single steps? Why do I have to navigate seasonal towers with the invasion interface?). I must also say that after more playtime, I do not enjoy the Kameo system as much as I did in the beginning. Many characters only have one or two Kameos that are clearly optimal, there is little choice or customizability, and when said Kameo gets changed in any way, it has a huge effect on the characters using that Kameo.
But most importantly, the competition for MK1 has gotten even stronger. Street Fighter 6 is still incredibly fun and has a large active community, even though DLC rollout has been very slow. GranBlue Fantasy Versus Rising was released and is simply great, with fast snappy matchmaking, great netcode, fun gameplay and a huge roster. Tekken 8 is about to launch, and if recent impressions from Betas and Demos are any indication, will be awesome as well (as long as they don't fumble the Netcode). So right now, I just cannot recommend MK1, as there are just better alternatives, no matter what you are looking for in a fighting game. Very disappointing.

[b]Original Review below:[/b]

Look, it's a fun game, it's beautiful, it's Mortal Kombat. If you are a fan of the series or of fighting games in general, check it out. However, if you only have a passing interest and want to play a new fighting game, it is very hard to recommend MK1 over Street Fighter 6.
Yes, they are very different games, but SF6 has delivered such a full package that almost anyone can find something fun to do. Almost every aspect, from gameplay to presentation is fine tuned in SF6. MK1 on the other hand delivers what you expect and is still an entertaining and well-made game, but so many parts just fall short. It is frustratingly close to being great.

Almost every part of this game has a small part that feels slightly undercooked: 
[list]
[*]The worst offender is surely the (ranked) matchmaking that might as well be prehistoric in the current state. Once you are in the match, everything feels good and stable, but waiting times are too long, no crossplay at release might hurt the playerbase in the long run (although it was promised to be added later), and the fact that you cannot wait for online matches in training mode was already unacceptable 5 years ago.
[*]Graphics are great and the facial animations (especially in cutscenes) might be the best in the industry. But small visual glitches during gameplay and especially during KO screens are frequent. Cutscences, Fatal Blows and Fatalities are locked to 30 fps
[*]NRS still makes the best cinematic story modes in the genre, but this one feels slightly short and rushed towards the end, as if one or two chapters were not fully explored.
[*]While unlocking outfits, brutalities, etc. was a catastrophe at the launch of MK11, I'm not convinced that the total removal of a Krypt was the right choice.
[*]Core gameplay is SUPER FUN and the Kameo system seems well thought out, even if there are some balance problems at launch. However, I personally don't know if the loss of old mainstay character like Jax, Sonya or the Kombat Kids as playable characters was worth it (but this is a very subjective thing)...
[*]Menus are well structured and easy to navigate, but especially the custumization menu can fell sluggish and frequent (if short) loading pauses make everthing feel unelegant and tedious.
[*]A lot of options for single player content is great, from the story mode to rotating towers to the new invasion mode. But why do I have to navigate the seasonal towers with this slow, clunky board game-esque interface, instead of a single menu where I can see everything on offer at one glance?
[*]Having a day 1 DLC character (that you could also get as preorder bonus) does also not induce any goodwill.
[/list]

P.S.: This might just be me, but with one or two exceptions, I feel the fatalities in MK11 were significantly more entertaining and avoided the awkward "posing with a corpse" that has made a return in this game...

"MK11 was better!"
Now don't get me wrong I love MK1. But there are some things that it lacks. First things first, it feels very rushed. Graphics-wise, it doesn't feel very different from MK11. It has a pretty good story with more character development than any other MK game. Some characters like Reptile or Baraka aren't punching bags anymore. Gameplay-wise, it's a good idea to bring cameos, but sometimes they feel very useless and dull. And it doesn't feel as balanced as MK11. Customizing characters once again is only for the looks of your character and doesn't change anything. Speaking of customization, MK11 had a far more detailed system for it, but let's not forget that there is also the cameo characters roster for it. Speaking of the roster, It has one of the best rosters I've ever seen in MK. I just want to find and shoot the guy who thought having Megan Fox as Nitara was a good idea. Overall, MK1 is a good game. It's just a little underwhelming.

[h1]Mortal Kombat 1 Review: A Brutal Reboot with a Price[/h1]

[h2]Overview[/h2]
NetherRealm Studios, under the banner of Warner Bros. Games, has released a hard reboot of the iconic fighting series with Mortal Kombat 1 on 19 September 2023. While I'm giving it a thumbs-up for its gameplay and presentation, there's a caveat regarding its length and DLC approach.

[h2]Gameplay: Fast, Fluid, and Fiercely Fun[/h2]
This reboot stays true to the Mortal Kombat legacy with combat that is both fast and fluid, demanding precise timing and a strategic mind. It's easy enough to pick up for newcomers but offers a steep learning curve for those looking to master its depths. The controller is your weapon of choice here, as it plays best with tactile feedback in your hands.

The movesets and combos are intricately crafted, providing a satisfying combat experience. The addition of tagging in combatants adds a fresh twist to fatal blows, keeping the fights interesting. If you enjoyed MK 10 and 11, this one's right up your alley. However, be warned – the unlockables are plentiful but the grind is real. And yes, it's DLC heavy, so be prepared to shell out more for the coolest features.

[h2]Story: Short but Sweetly Campy[/h2]
While the story isn't the main draw for many players, it's well-written and performed, with a delightful dash of campiness. The narrative may be on the shorter side (wrapped it up in under 6 hours), and although it gets a bit wild towards the end, it manages to pull through without losing its essence.

[h2]Graphics and Audio: A Gory Feast for the Eyes and Ears[/h2]
True to form, the game excels in its visual and audio presentation. The settings for each stage are both beautiful and imaginative, providing the perfect backdrops for brutal battles. The gore is exactly what MK fans expect – over the top and in your face. The reimagining of existing characters is nothing short of brilliant.

[h2]Conclusion: Great but Greedy?[/h2]
[b]Mortal Kombat 1 is a well-crafted reboot, offering everything a die-hard MK fan could ask for – stunning visuals, fluid gameplay, and that adrenaline-pumping action the series is known for. However, the game's reliance on DLC, combined with a grinding mechanism and a steep price tag, does leave a slightly bitter taste. It feels like the game is setting up players for future fleecing. For the hardcore MK fan or those catching it on sale, it's definitely worth your time and money. Casual players, though, might find the investment a bit too steep post-story mode. In short, it's a fantastic game shadowed by its commercial strategy.[/b]

Let me start off by saying that I usually don't enjoy fighting games. HOWEVER, it has nothing to do with my review, because I do quite enjoy the fighting part of this game. My issues stem from all the other things that are wrong with it, namely:
- Menus, invasions, animations (x-ray/fatalities), basically everything except combat are locked at 30 fps. Biggest offender tbh, there is no excuse for that in a 2023 game. Everything looks choppy to the point where I thought my laptop (Ryzen 7 6 gen + 3080) can't handle the game when it obviously can. More importantly, it's nausea inducing having constant switches between 60 and 30 fps. While on the topic, I can't really tell if the game is optimized poorly or it's just the result of fps cap, which is frustrating in and of itself, cause I know it should run good on my hardware but it doesn't feel like it.
- Monetization and shrine: I guess it's kinda inescapable now in modern games, especially live service ones, like MK, however it's still frustrating how much in-your-face and inescapable it is here. Worst offender: main antagonist as a dlc character even for the "ultimate" or whatever edition. Also, why in god's name cannot I skip shrine animation and just get to the fucking common cosmetic straight away?
- This one won't be universal, but frustrating tutorial: yeah, yeah, GIT GUD, but some of the tutorial combos have REALLY tight timings, which is fine for character challenges/mastery/whatever it's called, but imo it's a bit too much for the actual tutorial. As a newcomer to fighting games, I thought tutorial would teach me how to play properly, and instead it frustrated me to no end trying to get the tight timings down for 3 hours straight, when I just wanted to learn the mechanics
- Next one's minor, but "new" notification dots everywhere and you have to specifically click through every single new item for them to disappear. I may have mild OCD and it just drives me nuts. Shrine dot whenever you have more than 1000 koins is the whole other level of annoying too
- I've encountered multiple bugs, most notably and frustratingly the one where in Invasions when switching character there's always wrong elements displayed. As a new player, I want to have any advantage I can, and I should be forced to memorize every character's element instead of the game properly displaying them
- There's definitely more, but I'll have to go back in game  to remember what else I thought off when playing and come back here after to update this

On the flip side, the game looks beautiful, x-rays and fatalities are top notch, special moves and combos are great, and I liked this one waaaaay better than MK11 gameplay-wise, so it's not all bad.

But to me MK1 is a great example of a victim and representation of everything that's wrong with the industry today: unpolished rushed release (I don't know how else to explain unnecessary fps cap, when 11 had it patched later anyway, and glitches I've encountered), extreme monetization, FOMO inducing live service elements, etc.

The gameplay of MK1 is so much fun. The kameo system gives your fighter very disctincs possibilitys depending on who you chosse as kameo. The story is refreshing and gives a really good impression on what direction MK can be moving foward, but the game is unfinished.

Idk what NRS has been doing but this game shouldn't have been release like this, it's full of visuals bugs and lacks the basics of a fighting game, especially a AAA title that costs more than my kidney. 

I'm not talking about more gear or the krypt or different game modes. I'm talking about the possibility to view replays of my matchs, to see my W/L ratio outside rankings matchs, pin moves on practice mode, been able to play the fatalitys on kustomization. Just look how polish SF6 was at launch and how Tekken 8 is advertising every function of its practice mode. literally basic stuff that should be in every fighting game on release.

I'm not writing all this to attack the game, but it's unbearable the state its in now. and i not even touching the subject of not having crossplay at launch or the poor optimization on PC... its a idiotic move from NRS releasing a game in this state.

So... If you love MK buy it. MK1 has the best gameplay since MKX and has one of the best roster since MK9. Its fun as hell when it works propely. 

But if you just like MK save your money... wait until game has all his issues fixed. Let's just hope that MK1 wasnt killed by NRS before it even release.

EDIT 01/01/24: The game has been working very well since the last patch, not 100% but it is almost there. Buy it.

Mortal Kombat 1 on PC, despite its iconic status, presents mixed experiences. The game requires a robust PC setup to optimize performance, which may not be feasible for all players. The story mode is adequate but doesn't stand out. For those interested in competitive online play, the game disappoints due to poor netcode and character balance issues, leading to a less enjoyable experience. The cameo system, intended to add variety, detracts from the classic 1v1 format, further diminishing the game's appeal for traditional fighting game enthusiasts. Players might find better alternatives in other games or on console versions. If there is a rating out of 5. I'd give MK1 around a 2.5-3 of out 5. Probably worth it, if the game is on sale only. Full price, especially in 2024 in outrageous.

Pretty darn good! As a long time MK fan ever since the classic titles, through the weirdly experimental PlayStation titles (I loved the Kart racing in Armageddon tho ngl), to MK9 oward, this is a welcome change of pace for me.

The story has had an interesting reset while maintaining continuity from the previous title. In typical NRS fashion it gets a little out there but it's totally followable and the character performances, while still being a *touch* reminiscent of kung fu cinema b-film (bog standard for this series) are way more humanized in this story mode than in previous titles. I found it compelling and slammed it in a couple of sittings.

The Kombat has been reigned in quite a bit, thank God! Comparing this to something like MK9 where everyone has ridiculous superpowers and teleports are more common than not, MK1 has really tightened up the focus towards martial arts and the fighting genre tech (counters, getups, punishing, etc) and it feels really good! It has a buttery smoothness compared to its chunkier predecessors.

I am honestly glad kombatant variations are gone as well, although they were an interesting mechanic I never really cared for them. Replacing that Kustomization is the Kameo system: Think tag fighter rules but you can't switch to your supporting kombatant and they don't have a health bar, there's a recharging meter that determines when you can utilize their Kameo specials (it's just a couple special moves from that character's kommand list) and they assist with kombo breakers as well if you want to burn some of your special meter for that (you should).

All-in-all I'm enjoying it so far and will be taking a few kombatants online and seeing how I fare. Cheers!

So, I say this as a Mortal Kombat fanboy; buy when it’s on sale. The game isn’t bad by any means, the combat feels good; though I do miss a couple features. The fatal blows feel a little lackluster, I think they were trying to streamline the fight so fatal blows weren’t so dragged out. They are still fun but don’t scratch quite the same itch. The cast of characters we have to select from feels kinda small, and that’s from someone with the DLCs. I can accept cameo characters and certain characters not being focused on or playable, but man. For a game over 100gbs, I’d personally like a larger selection. MK11 as a whole felt more cohesive and thought out from a big picture standpoint. The story is great, took me approximately 8 hours to finish in a single play-through (with small breaks). I will admit the ending was very disappointing, this is the only part of the game that feels unfinished. I’m fine with a cliff hanger, but to have no real boss fight is insane. The ending seemed to cool but felt so rushed. It definitely feels like the next story DLC will have the true grand finale; which feels lame. MK11 had story DLC but the original story at least had an ending. The story has always been more movie than gameplay and I am fine with that to a degree; that being said; great movie except the ending. Fun story but I definitely don’t feel as important as I did in MK11. I haven’t dug too deep into the customization of characters but so far I’d say I prefer MK11s customization set up. 

Overall it’s a fun game. After Baldurs Gate 3s release it’s difficult to pay $90+ and not feel a little cheated, especially when the game is missing quite a bit of content that will be released later for another $40+.

Get the game on sale, begrudgingly 8/10

[b][i] Mortal Kombat 1... after 4 years we have waited for this. And again the story is restarted. What happened this time?[/i][/b]

[h1]Restarting a restart - what is it like?[/h1]

💢 ACHTUNG 💢
[b]Spoilers ahead.[/b]
[spoiler][b]🥷 It takes place in a new timeline created by Liu Kang. All the same heroes we know. But with different destinies. Sub-Zero (Bi Han) and Scorpion (Kuai Liang) are now brothers. Raiden is no longer an Elder God, but a default farmer. Liu Kang is now a demigod, Kung Lao does not know him. Baraka has this appearance due to illness. Mileena is now a positive character who also suffers from Tarkata like Baraka. Reptile got a name and also returned to his human form. Shao Kahn is no longer the mighty Kahn and conqueror of worlds, but the supreme commander of the Outworld army, ruled by Sindel. Speaking of her, now Sindel is also a positive character.[/b][/spoiler]
[b]In general, the plot is cool, addictive, but sometimes ridiculous and predictable. It will go great with beer for 4 hours.[/b]

[h1]Forgotten novelties[/h1]

👉 [b]How is Mortal Kombat 1 played? Just great: it's still a very fast-paced and technically sound fighting game. Against the backdrop of Mortal Kombat 11, battles have become less chaotic - even with lightning, fireballs and other projectiles flying across the screen. At the same time, purely visually, the gap with the previous part is not very large: in some places MK 1 even looks poorer. Each character still has special moves (obviously) and Fatal Blow, which has the same activation conditions as in MK11. By the way, about Fatal Blow, now it’s not a sudden attack, the animation of which you won’t see, but a cinematic cutscene, during which the enemy will be able to put up a block. Yeah, no more sudden Fatal Blows, now we just have to hope that the enemy will stick and miss FB, or connect with a combo.[/b]

👉[b]We also put emphasis on aerial combinations - now you can send your opponent into the air and hit him there, making some good combinations too. Two Strengthening scales and two Defense scales have been removed. The downside is that the interactivity of the arena has been removed. Now you can’t hit the enemy with anything heavy, or push off the wall to get out of the corner. The ability to create your own list of moves has also disappeared (Mortal Kombat 11) - this significantly reduces the variability of attacks. Why these features, available since Mortal Kombat X, were removed is an open question.[/b]

[h1]There are many of us, but you are alone[/h1]

🦐 [b]Cameo... The same mechanic, the main gameplay feature that made a lot of noise about Mortal Kombat 1, even before its release. But what is she? These are characters that can be added to battle with the click of a button. One click and one of the fifteen heroes appears on the screen - a cameo. They are needed to start a combo or interrupt an enemy attack. In fact, this is additional damage and the ability to suddenly poke the enemy. Cameo fighters also participate in grapples and Fatal Blows. Cameos have their own brutalities and fatalities.[/b]

🦐 [b]Personally, I was waiting for the same 2 on 2 that was in Mortal Kombat 9, when you could change the fighter in the middle of the battle and go on to beat the enemy, but the cameo system is also not bad (because they nerfed the fucking Cyrax, hooray). [/b]

[h1]Old - new heroes[/h1]

😈 [b]There are currently 23 characters available in the default roster. Shang Tsung could be obtained by purchasing the Premium version of the game or by pre-ordering the regular version (until September 19), or for a fee (6.28 bucks). You can also play as Havik only after completing the entire story (you can pick him up in notifications) or for an additional fee (6.28 bucks).[/b]

😈 [b]It's ironic, but there are no new characters in the new Mortal Kombat. These are either old men Scorpio, Sub-Zero, Kitana, Mileena, etc., or well-forgotten characters from old parts of Mortal Kombat - like Ashra, Reiko, Nitara or Li Mei. A fresh universe with old characters is an obvious reluctance from NetherRealm Studios to give up on characters that the fanbase is fanatical about. Everyone knows Scorpio, but do you remember Jackie Briggs' face? Instead of introducing new fighters, the studio refreshed the stories and abilities of the existing ones. For example, Reptile received a name and rediscovered his ability to transform. Shao Kahn lost his title and hammer, but received a giant axe, new motivation and special moves. And Baraka now has a clear backstory and the title of the most furious fighter of MK 1, because it’s very difficult to get out of the combo of this bullshit, no matter how hard you want.[/b]

😈 [b]Another metamorphosis was the appearance of the level of the main fighter (level 35 max.) and the cameo fighter (level 15 max.). Now most of the equipment, brutality, skins and backgrounds on the combat map can be obtained by reaching a certain fighter level. But still, the roster is significantly smaller compared to the Mortal Kombat 11 roster. But I hasten to reassure you that fighters from Kombat Pack 1 are slowly starting to appear.[/b]

[h1]“Invasion” that didn’t happen[/h1]

😴 [b]NRS did not move the Krypt from the eleventh part, where you could wander through dark locations and find varied loot. Instead of this they introduced the “Invasion” mode, in which you need to fight invaders from other worlds.[/b]

😴 [b]Everything works according to the principle of seasonality. Every six weeks, players are thrown into a new location and to a new villain - in the first season (September) they had to break Scorpio's face (who, by the way, is Hanzo Hasashi), in the second - to beat Nitara. The camera in “Invasion” moves up, and outside of battles the game turns into an adventure game where you can collect various amenities in the form of game currency and various loot. Well, to fight - what are we here for? But, of course, this is far from the same Krypt from Mortal Kombat 11, which was the most jerking mode. It would be more interesting if we could wander through locations just like in the MK11 Crypt, but as a selected character from the roster. The Towers of Time, in which I spent most of my gaming time, were also removed from the game, trying to get good loot.[/b]

[h1]Your money is MINE![/h1]

✏️ [b]Still, should I take the new Mortal Kombat 1 or not? In fact, the game is still crude, with very little content. This will be the song when the DLC is delivered, as well as the promised story addition, just like in MK11. The previous part acquired all this goodness in 13 months. I think it will be a similar story here. But, of course, the main disadvantage of the game is the astronomical price. Now Mortal Kombat 1 can be called a good, but not perfect fighting game. The relaunch was not soft, but cautious - with the desire to hold on to the old school players, and not to attract a new audience. We hope that in future updates they will deliver a sufficient amount of content, otherwise the game will not last long.[/b]

[h1]Result - 9 restarted timelines / 10 FPS on release[/h1]

Took me a while to decide how I wanted to review this, but overall I'm a fan of Mortal Kombat 1.

Some neutral things about the game:
[list]
    [*]The skill ceiling has increased since MK11
    [*]The kameo system is revitalizing but can be confusing and difficult
    [*]The game plays a lot faster than MK11
[/list]

Some great things about the game:
[list]
    [*]The fighting feels solid across all characters
    [*]Multiplayer plays well and it's a great game to enjoy with friends
    [*]The graphics and performance of this game are amazing, averaging above 40 FPS on Steam Deck with relatively good settings for the device
[/list]

Some bad things about the game:
[list]
    [*]Micro-transactions are littered throughout the game this time around, including event fatalities
    [*]The single-player modes feel incomplete compared to MK11, with a repetitive board game-like mode where each season brings a new boss and set of maps
    [*]No cross-play with other consoles, making it difficult to enjoy with non-PC friends
[/list]

I really really wanted to like this game. MK1 is such a downgrade from MK11.
I want to start by saying the cutscenes in the story mode are top notch. The writing is very similar to the stale Marvel movies with as many low grade quips they could muster. The animation, though, is fantastic. Really well made fight scenes and the quality of the graphics was fantastic.

Beyond that, the game itself is so poorly optimized. The beginning of each fight in the story mode is so choppy and sometimes need a load screen. It doesn't take long but it is a fighting game. MK11 felt completely seamless in comparison.
Of course, as many others have pointed out, it feels more like a live service game than ever before. MK11 at least had more options for customization that pushed you through playing through the ladders and bonus stage.
Previously you could choose 3 different parts of each character's costume to change, along with the overall color scheme/model type. Now you have 1 piece of equipment and fewer options for color scheme. The lack of options gives me less of a drive to continue with the newer Invasion mode. 
Which brings me to invasion mode. I don't understand why they changed it from the other challenge mode that would bring in new daily and weekly challenge ladders (similar to the Injustice games).
They also removed the Krypt which was a fun, slower pace exploration/collection mini game with secrets and references to the different characters and history of locations throughout the MK series. Now it is a "shrine", a glorified gashapon where you pay a flat rate of coins for a random collectible. 

From the rebirth of Mortal Kombat and Injustice through MK11 I thought Midway were on a great trajectory for the quality of these fighting games. As a Mortal Kombat fan I cannon in good conscience recommend this game at full price or even its current 50% off discounted price. With the fighter pass, the game comes to $90 pre-discount. I paid $50 for the full game and the fighter pass and I still feel ripped off. I wish I hadn't left it running while I was busy around my house because I would have asked for a refund. 

If you want a great MK experience, just play MK11.
It's great fun in some aspects and if you are a MK Fan of course it worth it, but C'mon you need to optimize it better for best experience, poorly optimized, but in general great!

Honestly the game is pretty good gameplay wise but the performance at launch was atrocious on PC and even now it could be better, the lack of krossplay several months after launch is kinda wack when other AAA fighting games have this. Major glitches for story mode and the cut scenes make me not recommend this.
I like it and it's fun. I will say the story is fantastic and beautifully crafted.

3/10 wait for more of a sale. Wish I could refund...

That said, the story mode (especially the last part) could be better.  Also, I miss the old Krypt mode. But overall, this game is awesome imho.
