Imagine a really huge tasty looking cake, with colorful icing and little sugar figurines on top, that makes you stare in awe when you first see it on your birthday table. But then you slice the cake open and find that it is made from horsedung on the inside, because it seems the baker really hates you. You can't possibly eat it now that you found out. That cake is Mortal Kombat 1.

[u][b]K[/b]onspiracy.[/u]
The game started out strong for me: It has by far the best visuals of all current gen fighting games. The fighters look ultra realistic, the stages are vibrant, immersive and just stunningly detailed. The story mode, which lasted around 9 hours for me, felt like watching a movie and I loved every second of it.

But once I was done with story and looked at what else there is to do I went into Invasion mode and things took a turn into the abyss. Suddenly I'm running around inside a topdown mobile game, clear checkpoints to receive money and cosmetic rewards, upgrade gear (with a chance to fail on later levels) and pick counter elements to enemies. Who in the world thought that was a good idea? It's already trash on mobile, but those games do it a lot better. On top of that the game mode seems unfinished and drops frames. Walking around the world topdown is locked to 30FPS, then the fight starts and should be at 60 but is high 40s instead until I tab out and back in when it becomes 60 as it should be. How is an issue that big in a tripple A game?

[u][b]K[/b]runch.[/u]
In general it appears as if MK1 did not spend enough time in development. Some parts of it work perfectly like Versus. Some parts contain questionable design choices such as locking character select, fatalities/teamwork xray moves and invasions at 30FPS. It's 2023 and those things should be a thing of the past. There simply is no reason for pre-rendering parts of your game at 30. 

And for story mode in particular it feels very good, very smooth like the forementioned watching of a movie for a long time, then suddenly has a bit rougher transition from movie parts to gameplay parts towards the end. As if the team had run out of time.

[u][b]K[/b]ustomization.[/u]
Now, the devs thought how to make money from this game and so on top of the hefty launch price and the 40€ character pass they also made unlocking things ingame as inconvenient and grindy as possible. You can ofc pay to skip to unlock all the Kameos if you want to. 

The character customization is equally horrible: You can find cosmetic items as drops. Either a weapon (or something else like for example a helmet for people who don't use weapons), a finishing move, brutality, or color palette to paint your default costume with. These items all got senseless rarity ratings so some are more often found than others. Good luck completing that, especially with seasonal content disappearing! And obviously you can also spend some of your earned ingame currency on praying for a loot box at the dragon shrine, which contains a random cosmetic.

Another thing to watch out for is the story. I said earlier I loved it and I really do. But I can see how it rubs people the wrong way. The story of MK1 most follows the schematic of a superhero game or movie, both logically and how things are put in scene. It's like playing the next Injustice (also WB games) or watching the next Marvel movie, but with a Mortal Kombat paint job. It's nothing like the dreadful atmosphere of some of the older titles, just flashy and cool with lots of blood. A... deception if you will.

[u][b]K[/b]ontrols.[/u]
There is a recent trend of making fighting games more accessible by offering alternate easier ways to execute moves and highly customize the gamepad layout. It's an important step to gain new audiences, but MK1 is not taking it. You can't even use backwards walking to block, like in almost every other fighting game ever. Some people will instinctively respond with "yeah but that would change the gameplay too much" and to those I say: Look at Streetfighter and Tekken - they completely revamped everything and it's working out just fine. There simply is no point in insisting on an outdated control and learning system anymore.

Oh and you also have to be online at all times even for offline game modes. If your wifi stutters the game gets interrupted with the Mortal Kombat logo flashing until you got re-connected. How very consumer friendly.

[u][b]K[/b]onclusion.[/u]
I feel like Mortal Kombat 1 was designed only to entertain for a very limited period of time, and only when you approach it very casually. This sadly means it can not compete with any of the other fighting games on the market right now: Streetfighter 6, Tekken 8 they will draw most players by being modern and accessible. And the rest will probably be picked up by Granblue, KoF or other smaller franchises.

The times when you mentioned Mortal Kombat along with the other big names are over. It could have been possible given the great visuals, great story and fun combat - but the devs lacked the balls to try out new things, while the sales department pushed for mobile style assets. And that ladies and gentlemen is how you end up on the pillar of forgotten games no one talks about.

Mortal Kombat has been a great game from its inception. MK2 and Ultimate MK3 took up entirely too much of my teenage years. In hindsight that time could have been better spent, but I was having an absolute blast. 

Returning to it all these years later brings back memories. It has come so far since then that at 43 years old, even though I've been in the technology industry my entire career, I am stunned to see what these systems are capable of, and I have to be careful not to let it take another decade from me. 

For those with some self control and time management skills, this is a worthwhile entertainment expense, but if you're prone to addictive behavior, you might do well to keep your distance because this game is designed to get you hooked.

This game is currently in Beta Access
You're paying to Play their Beta and be their test dummy. 
Game is NOT FINISHED and extremely inconsistent with combat interactions.
ALSO - Character animations do not properly match hurt boxes. i.e. what appears to be a overhead is actually a mid. This is across the board, like someone made a LAST second decision saying "Hey Thats too strong, Change it. Not enough time, just change how the attack hits the person and leave the animation"

OVERALL - Game is LAZY Devving
Money Hungry
A direct MIDDLE Finger to all the NRS Fans. I don't recommend supporting NRS or Ed Boon in General, they don't care about their player base ESPECIALLY IF YOU'RE are on PC - All your content and patches will come LATER then Console.

I cannot recommend a full price game for BETA Access.  This is honestly SAD that NRS tries to ploy off that WB put them under time constraint when they have Unlimmited funding and the game could be in a much better place. 

Lastly Pro players being involved in development is a terrible decision, large amounts of downplay and influence on character kits which result in poor gameplay, and poor balance decisions. 

2/10 Do not recommend even if 80% discount

I'm putting yes as my answer to recommending this game even though I really would not. The only reason I would recommend Mortal Kombat 1 is because Homelander and Omni-man are in this one which was my deciding factor in buying this game. Mortal Kombat 1 is a good game and obviously follows the story and plot to it's Mortal Kombat 11 predecessor which is pretty good. Although, Mk1 really is an enjoyable game, I would personally recommend Mk11 over this one for a multitude of reasons (listed below).
- More gore. I think what makes the Mortal Kombat games stand out is the gore. Mk1 does not have as much gore as Mk11 or MkX
-I also think the character selection could be a lot better in Mk1 but it's following the story to Mk11 so I understand why these characters are chosen. 
- The characters looked better in Mk11 and MkX. The characters in Mk1 almost look copy/pasted. 
- There is a lot more variety in Mk11. For those of you that have played Mk11 you will know what I'm talking about. For those that haven't and are thinking about getting into this game or are coming back, buy Mk11 or previous. With every character in Mk11 you were able to choose certain "aspects" that determined their ability/move set. In short, LOTS of variety for each character
-Now I do not know if it's my PC or not, but MK11 seemed to run a lot better than MK1
- Lastly, there seemed to be a lot more activities in the game outside of multiplayer. In Mk11, yes, there were towers but there were so many different towers that had buffs/negations that made the towers more fun and/or challenging. Secondly, the Krypt. I think it was a good addition to the game that allowed you to take a break from the fighting and just aimlessly wander and collect rewards.

Ultimately, this game lied to us.

This is NOT MK 1. They pitched it as a complete revamp of the game. Its Not. Its CLEARLY MK12. Within 2 hours of the campaign, it full on went multiverse and RIGHT back to being MK12. We were lied to. 

This is NOT a redo of the series. This is full on continuing as MK12. There is no redo at all. Really annoying.

i literally have to wait 3 minutes after pressing a button on the main menu, the game  doesnt even start half the time, and the CPU's spam the same overpowered moves over and over and over and over again and you're dead. so many improvements to be made. unironically one of the worst games i have ever played in my life.

Other than that i have enjoyed the game a vast amount.

This game is EXTREMELY broken. Achievements randomly do not unlock when conditions are met, making several of them permanently unobtainable. There is lag even in single player mode and with reduced graphics despite my machine being more than well equipped for equally advanced games and handling them at max settings. The invasion mode improperly resets each night undoing ALL progress, even the things that are supposed to be saved (and it is only supposed to reset each season, not each day) Random crashes to desktop.

Technical issues aside, the main villain is in the game, fully playable in the story mode, but price walled for any other purposes. An extemely scummy move.

To say I am disappointed is a vast understatement. And unfortunately many of these problems are not detectable within the usual 2 hour window for steams return policy. Spare yourselves.


Side note: From what I have seen on reddit, ALL of these issues are common across ALL platforms. This game is poorly made. It has pretty graphics when it isn't lagging and that's it. Not even omni-man (the whole reason i got the game) is enough to make me want to keep playing this garbage. Not at this price. Maybe if they make the game $5 I'll get it again.

Сюжетная кампания огонь. Она и в MK11 была длительной, шикарно поставленной. Но тут крайне бесшовные переходы от диалогов к мордобитию. Мне нравится. Я теперь не вообще понимаю, зачем нужны фильмы.

Геймплей как всегда на высоте, ростер персонажей непривычный. Много что поменялось. DLC героев пока мало, чтобы делать выводы.

То, о чем хочется поговорить — это санкции для России и Беларуси. Я не понимаю, чему способствует блокировка IP-адресов моей страны. Я считаю, что бить по игрокам это странно и глупо. Кто-то на верхушке Warner Bros. явно превысил свои полномочия.

Я запустил игру через Steam Deck, где на стандартную OS нельзя накатить Outline-клиент, это возможно только через Windows. В общем, посмотрим, насколько быстро консольщики освоят VPN и DNS. Пока ощущение, что игра, в том числе за счет конской цены, проходит мимо нашего региона.

Обратите внимание, сколько абзацев в тексте посвящено политическим решениям, а сколько содержимому MK11. Так не должно быть.

TL;DR. MK11 вполне может быть и отличная игра, но ее издатель принимает крайне идиотские решения. Посмотрите на то, чем сейчас занимаются авторы Batman: Arkham Knight.

I'm just a casual MK player

Overall, the direction and execution deserve praise [i](live-action actors, especially Shang Tsung, were impressive)[/i], and even the length of the main campaign is commendable. I breezed through the storyline in one go over several evenings [i](just avoid asking too many questions about the plot; otherwise, you'll facepalm yourself endlessly)[/i]. While the finale suffers a bit from yet another "multiverse," I enjoyed the diversity of chaos the game offers towards the finish line. The visual style is stunning [i](probably like all newly released MK games at the start)[/i], bloodshed and effects, everything we love and expect.

Maybe my mood finally aligned, but I enjoyed the combat in this MK the most. Pulling off combos, executing fatalities, and even managing to win some random online matches multiple times.

The invasion mode somehow spices up the familiar gameplay seen in fighting games. Can't say I'm thrilled about the daily tasks, but at least there's some progression happening. Not sure if I'll fully commit to clearing this activity. I'm too old and have too little time to endlessly grind through such activities. But I'm sure there are people who enjoy this, especially because here you're honing your skills whether you like it or not.

The only downside for me is that Shang Tsung is playable in the campaign, but you can only buy him with real money. It feels like a punch in the gut.

MK has always been a long-term investment. Sometimes, at least once in a blue moon, you gather with friends at home, and it's time to challenge someone to a round of the new MK.

Well, that moment hasn't arrived yet! :D

With a 50% discount, I don't regret the money spent overall. I'm sure I'll drop by here occasionally. At the very least, I might wait for discounts to buy the complete pack of released characters. I really want to try out Omni Man's butt.

p.s. B B Y B Y

I have a really mixed up feelings about this part of MK.

Cons:
- small roster
- "kameo" is rather annoying. Why removing x-rays? Why putting characters into kameo, instead of game itself?
- feels like giant step down compared to previous part
- reptile transformations are so low in frame count that looks like he is instantly transforming
- this is year 2023 (still) and game is locked to maximum of 60 fps!
- ...even so I have this on 60fps, fatalities and cinematics feel like 30fps! no fluid transitions and hardware is absolutely not a problem... And it looks like only PC have this problem. 
- Sareena only as kameo :(
- old characters missing! Jax, Sonya, Kano, Stryker as kameo only
- no playable freaks like Goro, Motaro, Kollector... only humanoids
- Shang Tsung behind paywall in addition to "Kombat Pack"
- absolutely terrible port!

pros:
- it's Mortal Kombat
- story is quite enjoyable (especially the way how characters are developing over time)
- huge potential (not there yet) if it comes to customisation (temple stairs fights with "fused" opponents was fun)
- new characters fit game perfectly, no "out of place"  (maybe except Nitara, but I blame actress playing her. Havik FTW!)

This game was released laggy and unfinished. It can be entertaining to watch, but it's not worth the ten minutes it takes to load the game and navigate the menus. I play with an i7-7700 and 16GB RAM and this is still the most unplayable slow game I've played in recent years. Don't support this company. Don't waste your time or money supporting unfinished bad products like this. I play an online match and through no fault of my own I disconnect before it starts, that counts as a ranked loss. Next game, my controller comes unplugged for 2 seconds, then as I plug it in it kicks me. Another loss through no fault of my own. How can this game expect to have a thriving competitive scene? It's unplayable. I feel bad for anyone that has grinded towers or invasions or spent money on in-game currency or bought DLC. Maybe Netherrealm can only afford a skeleton crew, and they only fix the issues that recieve a lot of negative press and attention on twitter. I have 248 hours played total as of now. I think it's fair to say that 10 hours of that were enjoyable. The story mode, practicing new characters, and the few working online matches were the sauce on this poop sandwhich. That still leaves 238 hours of poop sandwhich I had to eat though. Check back in a year when the dlc is out, and maybe some of the developers have crawled out of bed and done their jobs.

I do not recommend it at all. I was so hyped for this game ever since its teaser trailer. I really enjoyed the kombat mechanics and the kameos were fun, some were stupidly broken, and some were bad. It was okay. That being said, I seriously regret buying this game, as a person who loves playing Mortal Kombat as a casual/semi competitive player.

My criticisms of the game are:

1. Story Mode. It could've been better, especially having Baraka, Reptile, and Ashrah being shown more, with the last two exploring more of [spoiler] their relationship that was explicitly mentioned in vs dialogues [/spoiler] within the story and have other characters like them be utilized more. I also didn't enjoy having Bi-Han [spoiler] betraying Kuai Liang and Tomas, being a huge jerk to the latter. [/spoiler] I was hoping big changes for him and doing his character justice. For one thing, he isn't [spoiler] killed or turned into Noob Saibot [/spoiler] but they couldn't stop him from being an egotistical, power-hungry, rude guy. If he has to be power-hungry, sure. Whatever, just tone it down and make him be likeable. Tone down his ego too. I'm okay with him being cold-hearted, but not a full-blown jackass. Finally, the whole timeline shenanigan is getting old. Personal gripe, but I wish MK1 has a better title.

2. DRM. Enough said. It's seriously annoying to be forced to connect to the internet to play the game. PS5 didn't need to do that, and so does MK11 (it had DRM before until it was removed on March 22 of 2022) so why on the three goddesses of Hyrule does it need to have DRM? Please remove it already.

3. Expense and greed. Yeah, yeah... I shouldn't be the one to talk because I purchased the game but I still have to address the issue as to why is the game so repulsively expensive? Over $100 for the base game and DLC. But it gets worse from there. For one thing, the costumes and fatalities are over $10 bucks? Why is everything so expensive and greedy. I haven't bought any of the costumes after getting Sindel's costume when it was launch day. I really liked Scorpion and Sub-Zero's Deadly Alliance costumes and Nitara's classic costume. It's just so stupid that its overpriced and that we're forced to pay for them in order to get them instead of grinding in-game to get them.

That's all of the criticisms I can list of this game. I'm honestly shocked and disappointed that NRS and WB still managed to make it disappointing. One thing I can say is that I love seeing Reptile and several other characters returning to the series and I especially love Li Mei and Ashrah. Honestly, I don't recommend buying the game if you're new to Mortal Kombat. If you REALLY want to buy it, get it while its on sale. It's not worth full price, at all. Otherwise, stick to other fighting games.

There's a lot of issues with this game but this main one is the reason why I'm even going to leave a review.  I don't know if it's because I use a fightstick to play this game or if anyone else have the same issue, but this game's online input registration is just NOT GOOD and turning on the online delay option in settings, doesn't help either.  Canceling Omniman's Forward 4, 1 into down back 3 just never works for some reason and the game just almost always skip over it or just straight up ignores it for some reason.  I know this because: 1. I watched my replays and everytime, the inputs always come out but nothing happens for some reason and 2. confirming into down back 3 after the first hit of Forward 4, 1 is pretty easy to do so there's no reason for me to drop it consistently or at least this much.  I really do hope I change my mind as I keep playing this game, and if I do, I'll remove this review.  But for now, it's fucked up. >::((

140 hrs in edit: love it even more than when i originally posted this.

PROS 
- Amazing story mode that brings new life into the series while also keeping traditions alive 
- Gameplay is a massive improvement over the previous installment of MK11 
- Kameo system allows you to still remain dedicated to a singular character while being able to create new play-styles, get creative, and create combos without having to spend time on another "MAIN" character
- Legacy characters still have traditional feel and gameplay, but are re-imagined
- 3D era characters do NOT DISAPPOINT and are a treat for any long time fans of the series
- system mechanics and complexity are good for beginners, but have a high skill ceiling that can be achieved if said amount of work and practice is put into the game 
- open communication from Ed Boon and the developers of NetherRealm Studios and have active engagement in the community

CONS 
- Online issues: Only recently added a WiFi filter with an option to decline high-ping and de-synchronization issues that shouldn't occur given the company's resources and reputation 
- Microtransactions are out of control: Doesn't really make sense how Omni-Man is cheaper as a playable character than he is as an announcer for in-game audio.

Simply put: I believe that this game is extremely fun, worth your money and time, and there is something for everyone. However, there are things in this game that I wish I didn't have to worry about that do exist. I wish I could play this game without having to worry about these issues, but those issues don't overshadow the fun factor of the game for me. Excited to see the direction this game goes and the improvements that the fans will see along the way.

THE DEMO OF TEKKEN 8 IS BETTER THAN THE PREMIUM EDITION OF THIS GAME LOL! 

Ok, let's start by saying that this is my opinion on the game and nothing more. With this I am not looking for you to change your opinion or anything like that. I've played every MK that's come out since the first one in 1992.

The graphics are beautiful, very colorful and vibrant, it doesn't feel like a franchise game.

The user interface is as if they had been designed for mobile devices, they take up a lot of screen space and when you see them in 4K they are huge.

The music, like in other installments, is very bad.

Online: ON PC THERE IS NO CROSSPLAY, is REGIONLOCK and the same as in previous installments, the netcode is good. You can't create a lobby to play with your friends (at least not at the time of this review).

Gameplay: Too slow, a combo can take you forever, just like a grab, if they open you up, let go of the controller because you'll have to wait a while for it to be your turn again. The fighters feel heavy as if they were "glued to the floor", some have very dirty and unfair options. The new Kameos system (in my opinion) does not go or does not combine with the style of play that has always been 1v1 on the screen, you did not see 4 fighters at the same time and it became a bit confusing. The towers and the story are great, the new invasion system is interesting but you get bored of so many things you have to do just to unlock the rewards, the missions "TEST YOUR MIGHT"  are designed so that you destroy your controller (same as MKX).

Another thing, you pay full price for the game and YOU DO NOT HAVE ALL THE FIGHTERS AVAILABLE (Various Kameos + Havik), you have to unlock them or BUY THE DLC to get them immediately... this is one of the dirtiest practices that exist in terms of DLC, from day 1, are showing that what they want is to squeeze and squeeze this game monetarily and not make a quality game.

As if that were not enough, PC users did not get BETA or early access with the pre-purchase (everyone else was able to try it before), the game takes a long time building shaders at startup, and they ask for SSD and a lot more high performance requirements for the animations being locked at 30FPS in the year 2023, are you kidding?

In short, and in conclusion, wait a year or a little more and buy it at a discount, it is not worth paying full price for this game.

In my opinion, the game is designed more to please professional players than the entire community that grew up playing it. I say this because the amount of content for a single player is large, but the mechanics can be very complex for a casual user.

NOW THE BIG FINALE: There is an archivement where you need to tbag you opponent online to get it, so... YOU NEED TO BE DISRESPECTFUL TO PLAY THIS GAME ONLINE, what a joke, instead of promote a fair and respectful play, they promote what they are, they promote online bullying instead of respect.

--------------------------------------------------------------

Ok, vamos a empezar diciendo que esta es mi opinion sobre el juego y nada mas. Con esto no estoy buscando que cambies tu opinion ni nada por el estilo. He jugado cada uno de los MK que han salido desde el primero en 1992.

Los gráficos son hermosos, muy coloridos y vibrantes, no se siente como un juego de la franquicia.

La interfaz de usuario es como si la hubiesen diseñado para dispositivos móviles, ocupan mucho espacio en pantalla para lo poco que son. Cuando los ves en 4K son enormes.

La música igual que en otras entregas, muy mala.

Online: EN PC NO HAY CROSSPLAY, REGIONLOCK y lo mismo que en las entregas anteriores, el netcode esta bueno. No puedes crear un lobby para jugar con tus amigos (por lo menos no al momento de esta reseña).

Gameplay: Demasiado lento, un combo te puede durar una eternidad, al igual que un agarre, si te abren, suelta el mando porque para que sea tu turno nuevamente vas a tener que esperar un rato. Los peleadores se sienten pesados como si estuvieran "pegados al piso", algunos tienen opciones muy sucias e injustas. El nuevo sistema de Kameos (a mi parecer) no va o no combina con el estilo de juego que siempre ha sido 1v1 en pantalla, no veias 4 peleadores al mismo tiempo y llega a ser un poco confuso. La torres y la historia estan geniales, el nuevo sistema de invasiones es interesante pero te aburres de tantas cosas que debes hacer solo para desbloquear las recompenzas, las misiones que son del tipo "TEST YOUR MIGHT" estan diseñados para que destruyas tu mando (al igual que en MKX).

Otra cosa, pagas precio completo por el juego y NO TIENES DISPONIBLES TODOS LOS PELEADORES (Varios Kameos + Havik), tienes que desbloquearlos o COMPRAR EL DLC para obtenerlos de inmediato... esta es una de la prácticas mas sucias que existen en cuanto a los temas de DLC, desde el día 1 estan mostrando que lo que quieren es exprimir y exprimir monetariamente este juego y no hacer un juego de calidad.

Como si fuera poco, los usuarios de PC no obtuvieron BETA o acceso anticipado con la precompra (todos los demás si pudieron probarlo antes), el juego tarda un monton conrtuyendo los shaders al inicio, piden SSD y un monton mas de requisitos de alta performance y las animaciones estan bloqueadas a 30FPS en año 2023 estas bromenado?

En fin y como conclusion, esperen un año o un poco mas y comprenlo en descuento, no vale la pena pagar precio completo por este juego.

A mi parecer, el juego esta diseñado mas para complacer a los jugadores prefesionales que a toda la comunidad que creció jugándolo, esto lo digo porque la cantidad de contenido para un jugador es grande, pero las mecánicas pueden llegar a ser muy complejas para un usuario casual.

AHORA EL GRAN FINAL: Existe un logro que para desbloquearlo necesitas tbagear a tu oponente en un match online, asi que... NECESITAS FALTARLE EL RESPETO A TU OPONENTE PARA OBTENER UN SIMPLE LOGRO, en vez de promover el respeto entre oponentes y darle la espalda al bullying en linea, promueven lo tóxicos que ellos son.

MK1 is a game you should avoid.  Especially if you played MK11.  Mk11 was fantastic and very fun to play.  MK1, however did away with the fun parts of combat and replaced it with painful combo mechanics, overly complicated support calls, and terrible controls. 

Overall this is a failure of a game and players will leave soon to go back to SF or to the next new shiny fighting game.  Don't waste your money on MK1 until it is extremely discounted. 

The good:
Story mode stands out as a fun nod to the history of MK which is nice, easily the best part of the game.  
Omni-man is broken, but at least he is true to character which shows a lot of care went into that.

The bad:
Online play is trash, abuse of broken attacks and the OP characters is most of what you'll see.  Just really boring to play against the same few characters. 
  
Combo practice is trash since combos have been made insanely difficult.  Previous game I was able to get through them with practice and just "getting good".  MK1 has such terrible timing checks for combos.  Too fast and it won't even register the button, and too slow by micro-seconds means the move doesn't go off either.  That make that worse, the input buffer is garbage, easily the worse in any fighting game I've ever seen.  Sometimes it keeps your input and sometimes it doesn't.  Sometimes it overwrites your input with the next move, and other times it does not. 

Invasions is interesting but not good enough to hold attention, and definitely not long enough for the high cost of the game.  

Still no way to auto-skip fatalities in online play.  it's a feature people have been asking out of MK forever since no one wants to see the same fatality for the 100th time.  People just want to go to the next match.  So if you want to play online be prepared to waste hours having to watch fatalities over and over again.

tl/dr: Mortal Kombat 1 is unreasonably priced for what it offers.
MK1 is a 2d fighting game. Compared to previous titles, this MK has extremely few combo starters per character, leading to repetitive combat. The roster is fairly limited, which didn't stop the developers from locking 3 base game characters behind pay walls. This game on its own is not worth the $70, but if you want to play as the main villain? 8 bucks. Quan Chi? 8 bucks. Ermac? 8 bucks and unreleased. Even when you pay extra for those characters, they each have 20 mastery levels and two of them don't have any other skins at all. This game greedily uses in-game currency, which has no place in a 70 dollar game.
As far as graphics, mk1 does alright when it isn't bugging all the way out. unfortunately, this game constantly bugs out. Variety of gameplay? there is none. 
My recommendation is not to buy this game or any DLCs until NetherRealm decides to fix their bugs and include what is expected of the base game and DLC. (announcer voices should not cost more than the character they belong to.

[h1] TLDR [/h1]
Despite the number of hours I have in this game MK1 is the most disappointing Mortal Kombat I have ever played, and I've been playing MK since the SNES era. This is a hard avoid, even if you are curious about the game, I would recommend waiting for the game to be over 50% off before even looking at it.

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
The base game has less content than MK11 did at launch, but there are other issues such as:
- the characters don't feel finished, multiple characters have holes in their intended playstyle for kameos to fit into, but this makes them feel lacking in an inorganic and sometimes frustrating way
    - several characters are redesigned, which is expected, but some characters don't have the basic tools one has come to 
    expect from mortal kombat. many of the combo tools that players enjoy have been removed entirely and move lists feel 
    barren. The combat got stale in the first week of playing, and the game is dominated by the same two or three optimized 
    strategies with little variation. There is nothing to explore with the combat at this point.
- there are bugs that majorly impact gameplay, such as an input detection bug and several moves not behaving correctly
- there are obvious physics bugs like objects clipping into one another, special moves not disappearing off the screen when they should, and brutalities/fatalities not animating correctly because the physics objects are not tuned correctly
- there are several mechanics that seem to serve no purpose whatsoever, like the uppercut cancel, which has a high cost but doesn't reward the player for using it in any discernible way. It feels like it's there just so they can say there is a new mechanic, but not actually have to use it. The game AI never uses it, players never use it, and it doesn't add anything to gameplay
- Kameos are poorly implemented, making them boring to play around and not giving the player any real incentive to protect them or use them in any interesting fashion

But that's all minutia if you aren't super into fighting games. If you are a big fighting game fan, there's nothing here for you. 

[hr][/hr] 
[h1] STORY [/h1]
If you were here for the story:
- Several of the plot elements set up in MK11 Aftermath are completely ignored. Liu Kang's new timeline isn't explored by the story, and instead the plot quickly bait-and-switches the player with a multiverse plotline that completely invalidates everything up to that point.
- The story is poorly written. Tension isn't allowed to build unless it's one of the designated villain characters, and any potentially interesting aspects of the lore that would have been changed are literally thrown out so that they can do the same storylines from the previous games but worse. The rewritten versions of several characters are completely bland and without any notable personality traits, just the suggestion that they have them.

- Even the pre-fight dialogue is bad. The characters make small talk with one another in a way that makes the fighting gross and uninteresting at the same time. Baraka and Smoke, for example, have a conversation about having lost their family before fighting. This isn't done in a way that gets the player excited for the gameplay, it's just sad and inappropriate. The dialogue is nothing at best and makes the game worse in almost all instances outside of that. It isn't banter, it's filler.

- The story is short, bland, and aside from a few set pieces, doesn't add anything to the story or the characters in any meaningful way. Any damage done to any characters is just an unneeded explanation for why they were disfigured to begin with, such as with Havik or Baraka.
[hr] [/hr]
[h1] OTHER [/h1]
In no particular order:

- The music is generic and uninteresting, and a lot of it feels like bad muzak covers of music from previous MK games.

- The game, despite costing $70 already, tries to bilk the player for more money at every opportunity. The game launched with $50 worth of DLC, then another $20 worth was added to the in-game shop in the first month of the game running, but major bugs have yet to be fixed.
- The single player Invasions content uses psychological manipulation tactics and game theory to grind the player to maximize "engagement" without actually rewarding them for sticking around.
- You can't directly choose your character's appearance in local or solo play. If you want to change a skin you have to go through multiple menus and save your new appearance each time. There are no slots or loadouts, you can only make changes one at a time per character.
- Several of the monetization tactics are similar to abusive mobile games, even down to the multiple currency type to make it unclear how much someone is spending on the game. A single skin for one character is ten dollars.
- The game only recently began to inform the players that the free currency could also buy premium items that cost real money, meaning people were tricked into purchasing free content in the game.


[h1] THE FUTURE OF WB GAMES [/h1]
What I'm getting at is that this game isn't just bad, it's a clear message from WB and NetherRealm Studios: Bilking the players is their top priority, and they have no intention of making quality products going forward. If people continue to buy this game, they will continue to find new ways to make that a worse experience for everyone, no matter what.
These are not just my words, these are theirs. They plan on making all of their games like this going forward because their profit margins went up, as stated in an earnings call.

[i]"And similar to the leaders in the industry, we've led with multiple key franchises, each of which is $1 billion gaming property. Harry Potter, Game of Thrones, DC, which is mainly Batman today, and Mortal Kombat, whose most recent release, Mortal Kombat 1 has sold nearly 3 million copies since its launch in mid-September. So we've got the proven IP and franchises, the world class studios and publishing talent and we intend to continue to invest more capital and more resources into the business.

[b]Our focus is on transforming our biggest franchises from largely console and PC based with three-four year release schedules to include more always on gameplay through live services, multiplatform and free-to-play extensions with the goal to have more players spending more time on more platforms. Ultimately we want to drive engagement and monetization of longer cycles and at higher levels. We have put specific capabilities. We are currently under scale and see significant opportunity to generate greater post purchase revenue.[/b]"[/i]

DO NOT BUY. TELL OTHERS NOT TO BUY.

[h1] I played 1000 hours of MK11 on PS4 and started playing back in Deadly Alliance (PS2, 2002). [/h1]
I got the pre-order as my birthday gift from the family. I've already finished Invasion season and the story mode (no spoilers) which is basically all singlepalyer kontent. 
I love Mortal Kombat but the business practices and the downgrades can't be excused. This released as if it was an Early Access game and it's Mortal Kombat ffs. 
They really shit the bed with this game releasing earlier than intended and it sucks because I've been playing since Deadly Alliance on PS2. I want this series to be succeed and be fantastic but the state it released has been awful.
I don't want to blame the devs, I'm almost positive this is a result of other Warner projects failing or being delayed as well as the strikes that where happening at the time.
And regardless of that, the PC port is awful. Every day something new comes out about it. 
I can only recommend this to people like me, who have played so much MK11, they need something fresh. Otherwise, hold off on this. Go get MK11 ultimate edition on the cheap and wait for updates and price drops here. 

Things I Dislike: 
- It leaves 1GB crash logs on your PC every time it crashes and doesn't delete them. They're in AppData. 
- Their newly released MK mobile game had more content than this. 
- They release seasons broken, so when you come in ready to play, all the rewards unlock for you. They've just shut down the servers to frantically fix this glitch FOR THE SECOND TIME. 
- DO NOT BUY THE KAMEO PACK, DRAGON KRYSTALS OR HAVIK!!! - you can unlock them in-game, easily, for free. Even the Dragon Krystals and Scorpion skins. Very scummy practice. 
- Film Grain always on, as well as other unchangable screen effects. 
- There's an unfinished Tag mode in the game's files that they didn't complete or release. 
- Gear System downgrade: Now you can only kustomise one piece, instead of the previous 3. At least the skins are awesome. But I like more kustomisation not less. 
- It's 90% Online Connection required: Invasions requires internet connection. Same with all your unlocks, including specific characters, character endings you've already got and kustomisation. That's right. Mortal Kombat went 'Games as a service'. 
- AI is awful. Glorified punching bags that, unless you're playing Story on Hard, actually WAIT THEIR TURN after hitting you. No pressure or unpredictability. Their excuse for difficulty in Invasions Mode is modifiers and giving the opponents "armour" so they dont stagger. This shit isn't fun. 
- Kameos: Almost the whole game is kameo fights, I just prefer the klassic experience or even tag-team would be better. Even the kompetetive mode is kameos. I just cant get excited for shit coming in off-screen, interrupting the match, when we could've put that effort towards two or three more fully-fledged characters.
- Invasions Mode: Progression is broken because you can just purchase level ups and kurrency is really easy to get. I was max level really soon and it became a chore to get through to the end, which was the only real challenging fight after the starting areas. Now I have a Talisman that can insta-kill any enemy. It adds a 'Fart' move that kills max level enemies in 2 seconds. I'm literally shitting on what I love here. 
- Technical Issues: The game stutters and lags heavily at completely random times. In menus, important 
story cutscenes and during matches, which has lost me multiple rounds. It's just really annoying and unprofessional. It's worse in the Story mode, the ending scenes especially laggy which is a shame because it was good! The 'always online' thing constantly stops the game for a few seconds to reconnect also. 
- Kontent: Story Mode, Towers, Invasions, Online....That's it! They said live, on air, multiple times before the game came out that 'this game has the most features we've put into the game'. Nope. Not even close to some previous titles. I finished the Story, and Invasions. I don't care about online. So when I finish the Towers I'll only be playing season to season. And if your internet connection cuts out, you cant play Invasions or Online. That's right, singleplayer mode is online only. 
- XP Progression: Kombat League progression is super slow. I've played 10 matches, won 7 and I'm still below halfway through the first level. They want you to grind online to keep the game alive and the rewards just aren't worth it. Invasions is the only real way to get XP because you get 0 for quick matches vs CPU and the Towers give you way less. 
- One of the most powerful Invasions relics have been...farts. Get it? It's supposed to be funny! Twice. 
- Cant change costumes in character select. Cant view kurrency totals unless you're about to spend them. They're only now adding the intro dialogue to singleplayer modes. 
- Glitch with kosmetics coming up as N/A and when you select them it freezes and crashes your game. 
- Lied at least twice so far about DLC release dates and kontent. 
- They set up microtransactions before smoothing out all the above. I hope this doesn't have to do with WB and the Hollywood strikes. Because you could've delayed the game a year, with the excuse being what else is coming out around the same time. The game would've benefited from that time. 

Things I Like: 
+ More Mortal Kombat! I played so much MK11 I got tired of it. Having something new and fresh is great. And this 'new timeline' thing could've been the absolute worst, but they stook the landing in the Story mode and still give old fans lots of easter eggs. 
+ The story is one of the best of the series so far. Some cutscenes look so goddamn good, me and my sister kept saying how realistic moments looked. Some genuinely funny moments and lots of easter eggs. And the ending is super fun. 
+ The music is solid. 
+ The whole roster is a win for me. It's not often I can say 'I want to try out everyone!'. I got my mains, but I'm also playing as characters I never thought I'd like. 
+ Megan Fox's voice acting is laughably bad. Jean Claude Van Damme flirts with her in their intros and it's just funny to me. Did they both sign off on that? Anyway, here's the video: https://youtu.be/JUtjereYB1o?feature=shared
+ The fighting has been further improved, might be the best so far, but you wouldn't know unless you're playing Story or Versus another player. 
+ The little things: Grabs look more cinematic. Tutorial now teaches you insane kombos for each character. There are air kombos for each character. Dedicated overhead block so you can punish them if you're fly enough. Lots of 3D era easter eggs. 

Overall, this feels like an early access base. You can get more bang for your buck with MK11 Ultimate Edition right now. But if you're an MK fan who is done with that and previous games, this one is a fresh experience and fun, when it isn't constantly stepping on it's own feet.

Overall this game is great, gameplay-wise its the best fighting game I have ever played and definitely the best MK so far, but its missing some features from previous games.

Pros:

+ Amazing gameplay and characters
+ 10/10 graphics
+ Story mode had stunning cutscenes and really well executed
+ Online - The game feels smooth and I have an amazing time playing other people
+ Every character is fun to play and the Kameos are a great addition to the game

Cons:

- Invasions mode feel repetitive and sometimes the bosses are annoying but overall is a fun break from online matches although "The Krypt" was better imo
- The shrine feels pointless and slow
- Character customize is not as good as MK11
- Some online disconnects here and there (Black screen after an online set)
- No crossplay
- No 60fps manu, invasion mode and fatal blow cutscenes

7.5/10

This game seems 100x better on console which is what the developers made it for before outsourcing the port to another company. If you own a console that can play MK1 I'd reccomend getting that version before PC port for any NRS game. 

This game is great, PC port does seem to have a fair share of problems online for me but when I boot it up for offline casuals it never fails. Ignore people complaining about "broken characters", every NRS game has broken characters obviously. Ignore people complaining about the "small base roster", this game has tons of assist characters that add way more depth than a few extra characters on the base roster would. 

If this is your first fighting game you'll probably love it, NRS has a pretty dedicated casual community so you'll have no problem finding people of your skill level or working up to a skill level where you can have fun. If you've played other Non-NRS fighters, you might struggle getting into this game as it is wildly different from games developed in Japan. Small things like the block button, strings, block dashing movement, lack of projectile clash, etc, all add up and make a game that can feel absolutely alien to the typical Street Fighter/Anime Fighter player, Tekken players seem to love this game however (probably because they feel at home doing strings, ducking highs and throws, and learning complicated dash mechanics). 

If you've played other NRS games and loved them, you'll feel right at home here. MK1 has a bad story, stupid grind mode for unlocks, and some of the saltiest players saying the dumbest things on the microphone. Fortunately NRS sticks to their guns in making some of the weirdest character designs and archetypes in modern fighting games. Invisible 50/50's, full screen normals, wakeup armored launchers, stance characters, puppet characters, and JK Simmons. Don't come here for honor, glory, or a name. Come here to get salty you're stuck in the dumbest mixup of all time, and have a laugh. Maybe you'll get good along the way.

Some parts of the game lack polish (e.g. not being able to select P2 skins when playing locally, not having access to DLC or skins when playing offline), the patch notes lack detail, and you may encounter random crashing and minor annoyances/bugs with the UI. While I have enjoyed it overall, I can only recommend it if you're willing to look past all these points.

This game is a vast improvement over MK 11 they made it simplistic again. MK 11 is not a bad game it's just not a great game like compared to 9 and X, 11 just came off as kind of slow. Yes the character roster is nice and all, but what's most important factor is the gameplay speed and performance. There was so many issues I had with 11 that this game fixed and executed much better. The combo system isn't so cryptic and broken and seems to be easy to learn to play each character naturally. And unlike 11, its much more fun in Mortal Kombat 1 to unlock stuff and not like a hassle to get skins because you want your main fighter to look presentable. 

Everyone actually looks cool in this game so I have no issue with the default skins. Like for example I remember playing Mortal Komabt 11 for the first time playing Liu Kang and I was pissed off that they made him and several other characters revenants for their default skins "Like great my favorite character Liu Kang looks like a Zombie and now I have to jump through a bunch of hoops to give him a classic skin..." I absolutely hated that about Mortal Komabat 11, but even when you got the skins you wanted the game just seemed so slow and off I felt Liu Kang's combos were pretty weak and broken in that game. I also felt that way about Raiden. MK X had the best combo setup for Raiden and he was pretty overpowered. Mk 11 just had way too much stuff in it that game, and I felt like the game play wasn't well polished. 

That being said this game did so much justice for Liu Kang by making him a Fire-God, he's practically the most overpowered character in the game and they made his moves set sick. This is the most fun I've had playing Liu Kang since MK 9. Some people may not agree with this, but I'm kind of relieved they did away with the variation capability. The variation worked for MK X, but with MK 11 not so much. Especially with the option with adding another variation I don't really have time for that I really just want to play the game. Honestly the variation was really a one hit wonder for X. I don't mind it for one game, but having to learn several move sets for every character is practically like learning 3 characters in one and it gets time consuming. 

Compared to this game Mortal Kombat 1 just seems more polished and enjoyable. The new feature they introduce is "kameo" characters where you have certain side assist fighters that pop out and attack your opponent to give damage so that's pretty cool. There's no krypt so this time they added the conquest invasion mode where you kind of go on maps in different realms fighting just opponent after opponent while unlocking skins and adding points to characters you use while leveling up like an RPG. Eventually you fight an invasion opponent which is basically an invading alternate Mortal Kombat character from another timeline you battle and unlock their skin so that's kind of fun. 

SPOILERS:

Honestly I prefer Hanzo as Scorpion, but Kaui Liang is a pretty good, and it's handled well with his sibling rivalry with Bi-Han (Sub-Zero), and also Kaui Liang's move set is so good. Hanzo does make an appearance as Kuai Liang's first pupil so that's cool.

Story's pretty good I'm just kind of tired of the multiverse stuff.

My Only Problems:

I mean I like Shang Tsung,  but making him the main big bad is kind of redundant at this point I would've liked it better if they brought back Onaga. Maybe they'll bring Onaga back in story DLC idk.

Like I said i like the story, but it's the same problem I have with making Shang Tsung the bad guy again. The plot went from tournament to MK 11 Aftermath, Armageddon, and Multiverse of Madness.

Recently I found a few other things I had a problem with this game. It seems to have far to  many bugs that need to be fixed. I notice a lot in invasion mode. When equipping certain characters the game won't let me save what I have equipped so I have to fight the game just to get it to cooperate.

And again they're making the same mistake they made with the last game by forcing micro-transactions down our throats. If you can't put the skin in the game to unlock it in a challenge don't bother with the skin at all. I'm not going to bother stocking up on dragon crystals or spend $10 on a skin if I can't unlock it in a certain challenge. It kind of takes the fun out of it. How I see it gamers bought the game they own it now... when you make a game you need to provide more content to put into it for players to enjoy it more instead of trying to get more money out of them. DLC fine but put an end to the micro-transactions. 

Last thing I'd like to address is the lack of sub bosses, I was kind of disappointed that they didn't at least have a signature sub boss in this game. They got Goro and Motaro in this game, but only as Kameo fighters so it really comes off as a tease you don't even get to fight them. I really wanted to fight Motaro. 

All that aside it's a really fun game I highly recommend it.

Imagine Warner Bros. Games was a restaurant. Warner Bros. That means quality. It means brilliant cartoons like "The Looney Toons", a cultural phenomena with characters like Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. A cinema giant with a hundred classics spanning decades of cinema. Warner Bros. uses quality ingredients. They wouldn't shovel heaping piles of manure onto your plate, right?

Outside, it's a steakhouse: maybe it's Montana's.
  "Welcome in," the building whispers in your ear. "We get you."
 A shiver down your spine as the warm breath of cheap, pressure treated wood hits your nostrils. [i] Finally, a restaurant that gets me. [/i] 
Or, maybe it's the kind where a half-clothed man sprinkles salt through his chest hair onto your plate, and foils his steak in 24k gold.

 You order that Mortal Kombat you've been craving. You know it's bad for you, but you like it anyway. But each time you go back you realize, "this one's sprinkled with a few more turds this time." Each time you pay more, but you get less. Soon you're getting sliders: tiny slabs of beef hammered into waiver thin burgers, sprinkled with the secret seasoning: seasoned salt. When you put it in your mouth, it tastes like nothing. "Flame broiled," says a balding corporate executive with a rotund little ass. "It's flame grilled."

You few hours later you've got sliderrhea. You're 300 pounds. And it really didn't taste like anything: "but it's flame grilled...." will be your last words.

You can hear St. Peter's bell. Until it goes mute and a voice whispers in your ear. A drunken, stroke-victim slurring micro transactions into your ear. "Only 15.99 to unlock Shang Tsung's nipple-clamps."

No, WB, I don't think I like green eggs and ham, and done eating your nasty sh*t I am.

As I ordered.

The Good: the graphics are phenomenal, i swore sometimes the scenes were live action. the story, writing, acting and music all fantastic. the controls work amazing everything is responsive and does what i want it to

The Bad: The Kameo System, overall not a terrible mechanic but poorly implemented, all Kameo characters should be normal roster characters and all playable characters should be usable for Kameo. I find the violence has been fairly watered down, lack of x-ray opportunities, the environmentals are gone. the distance listed for moves required range is terrible there is no "far" range just "close" and "mid" because mid starts at like 10-15 to the other edge of the map >.<

The Ugly: with all the effort they clearly put into this game it's sad that it feels like a cash grab $90 CAD for the base game with a roster of around 23 characters give or take 1 or 2 depending on your pre-orders 2 less then the last two games base roster, $50 CAD for the "Kombat Pack" for the playable fighter DLC and $30 CAD for the "Kameo Pack" for extra support characters (that honestly don't really add a lot to the game aside from an added animation for the fatal blows and fatalities). Finally the last thing i will mention the Roster Jax, Sonya, Kano, Goro, Cyrax, Sektor, and a few more all Kameo only characters so you cant actually play them they're supports only, and all the new generation fighters they introduced in 
x and 11 are either gone or don't exist yet

I don't understand why companies still use Denuvo when it significantly affects performance. I mean, most players buy this game to play online, which means that whether with Denuvo or without it, players can't play without buying the game so that there is no need to keep it. The only thing that can be played in a pirated version of the game is the story mode (which, I can tell you, isn't the best). Also, I have loading times in story mode due to Denuvo, even though I have installed the game on an NVME. Seriously, WB should think about removing Denuvo; it affects performance too much. I only hope there will be crossplay for the PC version; otherwise, it will be evident that this version is not treated the same as the console version.

Definitely a bonus that getup delays don't cost meter.

Game is decent, gameplay is more dinamic than mk11, characters and specials are interesting, but a couple things earn the negative review.
The input is completely broken. A lot of times you can't press buttons more than one time for them to work, but if you don't do it the exact frame, it doesn't work either. Sometimes it's even worse, lets say you want to do "↓+X" followed by "→+↓+←+B" and the game consistently understands the second button (the B) as an X. A complete mess.
Also, online is all about not allowing your opponent to move, and instead of punishing spamming, it rewards it. I guess that applies to most fighting games, but anyway, I can't enjoy it.

Edit: the input is definitely the worst thing, makes the game a complete disaster. And one would guess you eventually get used to the BS, on the contrary, it gets worse.

After 19 hours of game play some would say, it might be too early to write a review. Sadly I think I've seen it all after 19 hours. Spending 230+ hours in Mortal Kombat 11 I really had a blast, but the same feeling won't come up for Mortal Kombat 1. Is it a bad game? No, definitely not, it is diffrent and here lies the problem for me. But let's start with the pros. The cameo system is nice, knowing there is always a second fighter backing you up. Plus there are a lot of combinations to find out on how one can use the cameo fighter in certain situations. The story mode is again awesome and could be a full featured blockbuster movie in itself. The towers are simple and it feels like more "back to the roots". Well, I guess that is what MK1 tried to to in the first place, going back to the roots. Test your Might activities are back, which formed a  big smile on my face, but going back to basics is also where the problem starts for me. Regardless how cool and versitile the cameo system is, fighting itself is also back to basic. You have one "getting out of a bad situation" move, which burns all of your meter at once. In MK11 one had 2 bars of defensive and 2 bars of offensive moves at the ready. Properly used, one was able to strike an opponent in a wake up move to get an advantage, or one could roll out of a combo string, to limit damage taken. Not so anymore. There is only one combo breaker move in the game. Ask yourself everytime, when you consider using it, if it is worth losing all your built up meter for it. Of course there are still, enhanced moves in the game, but they do not look that spectacular anymore as they did in MK11. Well, let's talk about invasions. Imagine you have a playing board in front of you with a figure of your choice from the MK Universe.  You roll a dice and your figure moves from one point to another. At any point there is an opponent waiting for you to beat the crap out of him, and you earn some goodies in the process. Sometimes keys, which you'll need to access another area of the play board. Well that is invasions in a nutshell, absent the rolling of a dice, for you control your charakter via controller. The Krypt in MK11 was so much more fun to me. You could explore Shang Tsungs Island, open secret passages, solving riddles etc. to unlock new regions of the Island and new gear for your charakters. There was a forge, where you could forge Items for tower play and so on. The Kollector had each day diffrent nice items for sale or would exchange them for certain items you found within the Krypt. All of that is gone..... Yes, there is a forge to be found within invasions, but it's only purpose is to upgrade your talismans, which you'll find along the raod. You also remember the shrine in MK 11 where you could spend your money on new skins or backgrounds etc..... Well, yes there is a shrine in MK 1 too, but getting something suitable out of it, is a gamble on it's own. What I'm also missing is the variety of customisation, one had in MK 11. There is only one Item to customise on your charakter. Gone are the days where you could change your figjhter into an awesome looking bad ass. Customising your fighting style? Forget it, just not possible anymore. As I mentioned before...... BACK TO THE BASICS.  What really blew me away in MK 1 are the backgrounds and charakters. They are lovely crafted and spread out an atmosphere and charisma, which outpaces even MK11. If you are a true Mortal Kombat fan this is a no brainer, and you have to buy it. If you like fighting games and you are searching for a challenge, MK1 is definitely your game. Should you find yourself more on the casual side of fighting games, well you can have fun, but keep in mind that others, especially online, will often wipe the floor with you. You have to put some effort in to it, to stand a chance online. Yes, I recommend Mortal Kombat 1, although finding myself in a tough spot having fun with it. I'll just keep going ;)

Where to start?

Story/ setting (environments)
Firstly, I played the original MK1, back on the Sega Genesis. So? In being partial to the first three games? I was blown away! To see a reboot that didn't suck and/ or wasn't mediocre, as literally every MK game felt like, past MKIII (with some periodic gems that would surface, here and there, in the past two decades). It is incredibly inventive and love how they pulled off the timeline thing, though, I do wonder how these demigods and gods are so freaking absent minded and helpless, at times. It certainly does better with its timeline story than any Marvel movie does. I think it could even make for a fun game/ content spin-off, where maybe NetherRealms does a story mode where we are playing on the side of Titan Shang Tsung.  However? It had moments where it felt like it got a little out of hand, when it began combining characters. I can't think of immediate examples because they were all perplexing to pick out, but as a random example? For instance? Seeing a Raiden/ Sub Zero hybrid type character, and several other weird combinations. It did make me wonder if they had some procedural engine whose aim was to randomly combine characters. Since we are talking multiple universes though, it works and it was kind of funny to see this stuff. It was also very interesting, to see a version of the universe where Outworlders weren't horrible, and seeing everything in a more utopic light (Outworld as it might have been if there were no Shang Tsung). But this is also what sort of made it feel "not Mortal Kombat"at times. Similar to how Doom Eternal completely changed their art style and made it feel less horrifying and gritty and more vibrantly colored and high fantasy. I'm used to most MK matches being set in a grim environment, yet most of them are very utopic now. 

Combat
The combat definitely has evolved and I ultimately enjoy it better than any before it, from a combat perspective. Although? I did like those MK games over the years that attempted to introduce a 3D environment, such as you might find in games like Tekken, or Soul Calibur and I do wish we could get an MK game like that again, but I can certainly see why they kept to the original formula...it jsut works. But some of the advantages of a 3D combat game opens the doors to many more potential moves. For instance, side-stepping your opponent and grabbing/ throwing them results in a different move than you might get when facing straight on, or behind them...and the same with countering. I also haven't seen the old interactive environments! To the likes of other MK games, like MKII, Killer instinct and Injustice. Knocking people into environment 'stuff' and having environment fatalities? Super fun stuff! Although? Maybe not quite to the extent of Injustice, where I think the environment stuff maybe does a little too much damage. In fact? It wouldn't even have to contribute to "more damage" and just be kept as an aesthetic. 

Consumables
I love the consumable approach to buffing your powers/ resistances. I just wish that consumables were stackable and/ or that you could carry more than 5. I.e. Keys, for instance, should even be kept in a consumable slot...or, if it really must be? It should be stackable. I should not have to choose to ditch treasure keys, in order to keep gameplay based consumables. These are two separate things having to do nothing with gameplay. I should be able to keep more than one Chaos Armor consumable in my inventory, stacked. 

Node navigation
Walking from node-to-node, in Invasion mode? Is completely nonsensical and especially infuriating. Assuming your character is facing forward (12 O'clock)? Somehow, pushing forward on the stick results in them turning around and walking back the opposite direction, and yet? You can push forward for your character to return to the prior node, while they are now facing the 6 O'clock position. Yet, walking back to the prior node and continuing pushing forward on the stick results in turning around again. So, as logic would have it? If while the camera is faced 12 O'clock, and my character is facing 6 O'clock? Then logic would dictate that if both my character and camera are facing 12 O'clock? Then pushing my stick in the backward (6 O'clock) direction should result in my finally moving forward, correct? Nope!!! Let me see if I can explain better: 

You are facing 12 O'clock and want to continue to the next node, which is also 12 O'clock from your position. You push the stick in the 12 O'clock, which, again? Is the direction that both the camera and character are facing, yet? The character turns around and walks back to the 6 O'clock position. So, now he/ she is one node opposite the direction you wanted to be, except now now facing the 6 O'clock direction, while the camera continues statically facing the 12 O'clock direction. So, you instinctively push back on the stick, because you want your character to turn back around and face/ head back 12 O'clock, but this only makes them walk further in the 6 O'clock position, so clearly it must be based on which way the camera is facing, if back makes them walk forward and so one might think: "Okay...so...it must be going off of the direction the camera is facing, which? If that's the case? Why did pushing forward make me turnaround in the first place then?" So, sure enough? You push 12 O'clock on the stick and it sends you back one node in the correct position, but since you have now ended up two nodes away from your original location, you need to do this once more, to get back to where you started: "Good! So? Let's push forward once more and get to the node I want to be at!" So, with the character and camera both facing 12 O'clock again? You push forward and rejoice because now you are back to where you started. So, in retaining the same logic, you pushing 12 O'clock on the stick, once more and the f'ng thing turns around and walks back again!!! Grrrrrr!!!
I've never met gameplay that made me want to throw my controller over such a stupid thing! 

Node navigation - workaround
Well? The workaround that I found? Is that when you push the stick the direction you want to go, keep snapping the stick in the desired direction, as you approach the next node (So, like "clack clack clack clack clack") and continue doing that as you approach the node, and your character "should" continue walking forward...but not all the time, as, if your timing is off? And one of those stick pushes didn't occur as you approached the next node? The character will still turn around and walk the opposite direction.

All-in-all? I love what NetherRealms has done with the game, but I wish it could feel a little spookier/ grittier again. I think the colors of the characters armor are often too utopic and brightly vibrant/ vivid...and even the narrative voice that says "Fight!" and "Fatality!" Doesn't sound as deep/ scary as the MK 1-3 versions of the game. But from a gameplay centered perspective? However? If they just fix the clunky node navigation and how consumables/ inventory are stored? They could pretty much do nothing else to the game from here on out and I'd be happy.
It's fun, but not fun enough. Way too much stuff locked behind DLC, and Invasions Mode is boring and repetitive.

I genuinely tried to force myself to enjoy this game, I spent over 100 dollars on it so I didn't have much choice. But oh my GOD, it's a genuine mess. Everyone already complains about the monetization issues and lack of content, but nobody mentions that the PC seems like it's held together with boogers and fucking string. The net code is abysmal to the point where two people with a wired connection can have over 150 ping, and even offline there's a chance the game will randomly stutter while running on my 4070 as if I was playing with someone on wifi. Some of the bare minimum shit is even broken, for example, if you want mute people online because of the mess of a community this game has, it's pretty much a dice roll on whether it'll work. That's not to mention the random crashes that can occur, crashes that will create a crash report that can take up AN ENTIRE GIG, so there are some people blissfully unaware that they're currently carrying about 20 extra gigs because this game was made by a fucking intern, I cannot recommend enough to stay as far away from this garbage as possible until it's at least made very public that they've replaced the string holding their game together with some fucking tape.

Pros:
-Story is a big improvement compared to 11, towards the ending it gets a bit worse in my opinion
-Roster is pretty good
-Invasions mode is interesting
-The combos feel fun to execute
Cons:
-The game has way too many paywalls. For example, you have extra fatalities that cost 10$ each or something like that. I'm one of the people that bought the kombat pack, and I have to wait an unknown number of months if not years to play takeda
-Neutral is beyond dumb. Once again nrs decided that it's really cool for the person who mashes pokes the most to have his turn for the whole game(d1 being punishable is a complete lie, good luck doing it on 100+ ping)
-The kameo system straight up sucks. It doesn't feel like there are any intended synergies made. There is one kameo in the game that is better then all the others and that's the one that everybody uses. At first it was cyrax, now it's kung lao. It just feels like every character uses the same strategy and it gets boring.
-It feels like the characters have been intentionally given less tools. My guess for the reasoning would be that you would have to rely on kameos. We know how that worked out.
-Punishing moves feels very difficult. Blockstun is really high sometimes, combine that with the sluggish movement and you can't even punish moves that are -15
-The movement is very strange. Indeed, it feels fast however it's really clunky. I tried so many times to dash and use a mid to catch my opponent just for it to whiff and get full combo punished.
-There are a bunch of archetypes missing from the game. I know mk never had specific archetypes, but there was a bit of everything. In this game there are only two grapplers, one of them is played more like a zoner the other more like a whiff punish character

In conclusion, this game has a lot of potential, however in it's current state it's really disappointing. There's a pretty good reason for the playerbase dropping so hard. The only possible solution I see would be a lot of touches on the kameo system, but i think we all know that's not gonna happen.

I've been a die hard MK fan since the arcade days, but after 32hrs of this shit, I'm all outta copium. I wanted to like it, but this is by far the worst MK since before the last reboot. And I'm talking about the game in general, not just the PC port, tho I'll get to that. This MK feels more rushed than the 2021 movie. Not even gonna try to list everything that's been stripped away since MK 11. The customization of move sets, the various intros and outros, augmented gear, and too much other shit. No more Krypt, bc now we got "Invasions," which is a terrible trade-off. No sense of wonder and exploration there, it's just mind-numbing repetitious busy work. Grinding away hours while contemplating your life decisions, wondering how it came to this. There's these occasional "Survive" sessions that they should've just called "Test Your Patience," I don't wanna talk about it. "But what about the kameos," you ask? Ever use those 'Summon' Konsumables in MK 11, like in the ToT? Yeah that's basically all it is. Everything about this game just feels phoned in. The fatalities/brutalities are all weak AF, and mostly recycled. Just like the kameo character designs. "No, no time for concept art...Let's just reuse old shit and call it...nostalgia!" ...and... "Let's speedrun through the promotional period before they figure out that this game is really more like a work in progress!" ...are just some of the things I imagine NRS saying, at some point. But yeah, I went ahead and bought the premium edition on Black Friday, at a whopping 30% off, so it was just over 70 bucks. Felt like I was getting a sweet deal bc a lotta big dummies preordered the game for that price and all they got was a stupid Shang Tsung lol XD...I didn't get any Shang Tsung tho :(  He'd cost me another 8 bucks so he's an NPC as far as I'm concerned... BUT... what I did get, was 6 whole guest characters and like 5 kameos instead!!! ...Well, technically I only got one of each, atm...Not sure how long it'll take for NRS to drip-feed me the rest...since they're still in development. They don't yet exist...but I paid for them. Hmmm...wow. Perhaps I, too, was a big dummy. Gonna beat myself up far more than any in-game opponents, that's for sure. But that's just the game in general. The PC port is...well, better than the Switch port at least. That's something, I guess. But get ready for some frame-dropping cutscenes that will often look like stop-motion animations. Even on low graphic settings, on a PC that meets the recommended specs, and then some. it really makes no difference at all. But the actual fights do seem to run smoothly tho, so I guess QC was like that'll do. But that's just a minor gripe in comparison to how I feel about this game, on the whole. Currently, it's overpriced and undercooked. You really shouldn't buy it yet, if ever. Hopefully this D'vorah of a game will some day transform into...idk, something that doesn't just make me sick to look at.

It's not fun on PC. The game caps your frame rate at a maximum of 60 fps so you can't even get the most out of your hardware, and the optimization is the worst I have ever seen for 70$. I use a RTX 3080, i7 12700k, 32gb of RAM, and 2tb NVMe SSD. Its really bad performance and there is a bug with the keyboard controls where you can't use your abilities when your fighter is facing the left area of the screen. I have heard that if you use an AMD gpu you wont have stuttering issues but I'm not sure if that is real or not. Don't buy this game until they fix the terrible optimization or else face wasting your money for a crappy experience.

Edit: Some things were fixed recently but it's been a long time...
w game

>>Third edit: The issue of frequent crashes seems to have been solved, so I change the review to "recommended", as I said before. HOWEVER, the extra amount of money they request for the game content is absolutely crazy and I am not happy with it. Selling fatalities in a Mortal Kombat game is a whole new level of greediness. I am not planning to buy them and other overpriced content anytime soon and I recommend other players not to buy them, too. This is disrespectful to the fans.

>>Original review:

I was excited for this release, mostly for the new designs and the story. I was surprised to see that the fighting mechanics were significantly changed and made more fluid/intuitive. I am loving the game so far. Let's see how long it will last!

One final note, (playing at 1440p) it is either the game is not optimised well or my RTX3060 is having difficulties keeping up with the requirements of our time. I hope it is the first one, ironically, so I only need to wait for a patch and not to change my graphic card.

Edit: Finished the story mode. The game was crashing constantly at the end battles, sometimes even in the cutscenes. Also, I could not complete a single tower yet because the game randomly crashes between fights. It should be fixed at once.

Second edit: Finished the Invasion mode. I am experiencing crashes despite the patch, especially in the Towers. Imagine like you reach half the tower in hard mode and the game crashes. It becomes the Tower of Babel. I am changing the rating to "not recommended". I promise the developers once they fix the optimisation and frequent crashes, I will re-change it to "recommended".

- Rotating Fortnite like item shop.

- Live service like.
- A kombat pack that almost matches the game price.
- Shang-Tsung and Quan-Chi costing money despite being present and functional in the main story.

I'd say this game is worth it if you like downgraded versions of previous titles. Have fun!

It's a good game. The story is a continuation of MK11 but it's also rebooting the series, which they did pretty well. The graphics and art style are amazing. The gameplay is great and hits on enemies feel very satisfying. The invasions mode is a nice touch for having something story-like to do after the main storyline, but it does feel a little bland at times. There are some performance issues, like FPS drops when there's a lot visual effects happening at the same time, but the game is very playable (used to be way worse according to earlier reviews I read, so they're actively working on performance).

The roster could've been a bit bigger, but I guess that's a result of the reboot theme. I hope that as the story progresses in DLC or new games, the roster will become larger (Noob Saibot pls). But there's one thing I absolutely HATE, which is having to buy characters like Shang Tsung, Quan Chi and Ermac. Unlocking them through the story would've been logical, but why do I have to pay for characters that play a big part in the base game's story? It's just blatant cash grabbing. They cost 8 euros a piece or 40 euros for the Kombat pack which consists of only 6 characters. I could buy a whole other game with that money. Making those DLC characters so expensive was lame in the previous games and it's still lame now.
