Definitely the worst release of an MK game ever, and it's been 2.5 months already with one patch that arguably didn't improve the game by any degree. This game was clearly rushed and is still unfinished. No online practice, no competent ping or wifi filter, tons of bugs for some reason, and all for the cheap price of 70 base, or 110 if you're like me and wanted all the characters, which will eventually add up to 150 or more by the end of the game's life. Piece of garbage money grubbing WB ruined MK for the foreseeable future. If you can get over the obscene price and lack of features, the balancing of the game is just sad. You simply can't play the characters you want. Sure, you can play some of the worse characters but in this state of the game you really only have one kameo to use with each character. MKX had 33 characters with 100 variations, and you could pretty much play any one of them and get good and have fun. This game is the opposite. I try so hard to like this game because of how expensive it was, but I can't. I can recommend the story though, that was almost a 10/10 for any MK fan. The rest of the game is still in beta and should have never been released. I'm sure the game will be better in a year or maybe even six months, but I don't have a time machine. Maybe for the price of the game they should have sent me one in the mail. More disappointing than MK11, and I didn't think that was possible.

My Personal Thoughts and Opinions: As a dedicated Mortal Kombat fan who has been playing since day one, I approached the latest installment with a mix of excitement and nostalgia. However, after spending considerable time with the game (+200 hours), it pains me to admit that Mortal Kombat 1 falls short of the high standards set by its predecessors. One of the most glaring issues is the lack of content compared to previous entries in the series. Having been a part of the Mortal Kombat community for years, I've witnessed the evolution of the franchise and its ability to deliver robust and engaging content. Unfortunately, this latest iteration feels like a step backward in terms of variety and depth. Beyond the story, the game's additional modes feel like mere afterthoughts. The Towers lack the variety and creativity seen in previous games, and the absence of certain classic game modes is a letdown for those who have been with Mortal Kombat since its inception. The frequency of game crashes is another major concern. As someone who has invested countless hours into the Mortal Kombat franchise, the frustration of having the game abruptly freeze or close is hard to ignore. These interruptions not only disrupt the flow of gameplay but also raise questions about the overall stability of the title. In summary, Mortal Kombat 1 leaves a bitter taste for this day one player, as the abundance of bugs, frequent crashes, and overall lack of polish create an unsettling impression. The game's technical issues, reminiscent of an unfinished beta release, cast a shadow over what could have been a triumphant addition to the Mortal Kombat legacy. As a devoted fan, I can only hope that the developers address these concerns promptly and deliver the necessary updates to bring the game up to the standard of excellence that the franchise is known for. Until then, it's challenging to view Mortal Kombat 1 as anything other than a missed opportunity and a disappointing departure from the series' illustrious history. I just have to say that invasions is quite possibly the dumbest fucking game mode NRS has ever created. 

IN ITS CURRENT STATE: 5/10

After an additional 30 hours of playtime I felt the need to add on to my original review. 

One glaring issue is the time it takes to ascend the ranks, which seems to defy all reason. Despite going on crazy win streaks, the progression feels more like a marathon than a thrilling race. This extended grind not only tests the patience of players but also dampens the excitement of rising through the ranks.

Adding to the frustration is the repetitive nature of each match, with Johnny Cage becoming a ubiquitous presence in every encounter. It's disheartening to witness the lack of variety in character selection, turning what should be a diverse and dynamic fighting experience into a monotonous routine.

Johnny Cage's overwhelming popularity raises questions about game balance and the need for adjustments to encourage a more varied roster. The monotony of facing the same character repeatedly diminishes the overall enjoyment of the game, leaving players yearning for a more diverse and challenging set of opponents.

2/10 in its current state.

In my opinion a really good game. The story is fun, invasions seem to be decent and so far no bad experiences playing "online". Most fighters feel really good when playing them and the kameo system is also fun after getting used to it.

During early access there were a couple of problems with performance, but for me at least they are mostly gone. There are also some flaws and bugs, but nothing that more than a minor inconvenience.

I assume most problems/bugs will be fixed in the near future and more content will roll in, so I think you can't go wrong giving it a shot. Otherwise wait for a couple of stability patches and try it in a couple of weeks.

UPDATE: Turns out most problems were fixed over the last couple of weeks or at least i experience far less problems.

Hard to say but I cannot recommend the game as it currently is. There's just nothing to do. With MK11 I would play Towers of Time constantly. The Gateway Invasion Towers in this game are god awful. The modifiers are absolutely abysmal. Fire Floor, Fire Smoke, and Heating Up are the absolute worst BS I have ever experienced.

Ever since the update that was supposed to fix the PC issues, I've had nothing but problems. Fights now take up to 20 seconds to start. I have this on an SSD, 64GB of ram, and a GTX3080 with an i9. Unacceptable.

The AI is the most borked crap I have ever seen in a fighting game. I'm not talking about the cameos, I'm talking the actual AI. The game goes into what my wife has coined "Ape ShÌt Mode" where it just 1 frame dodges everything and you cannot land a hit no matter what you do. I'm so sick of this button reading, lazy shit in fighting games.

The gameplay itself is smooth and fun, but when there's nothing to really do...what's the point? I can't jump on and play a few towers because the towers are god awful and are usually 1 to 3 fights long...because honestly, that's all you're going to stand thanks to the modifiers.

Fatalities are time gated behind your character level with the specific fighter...so if you want to get a second fatality and other brutalities, you have to grind to level them up. Yeah, you read that right...you have to fucking grind in a fighting game. Unlike MK11 where you could just do the fatality input and get the fatality unlocked, you have to get the character to a high enough level to unlock it. Fuck...that...

Oh, and I forgot to mention there are NO stage fatalities. Why? Why do they keep doing that when they're going to add them later?!?!

The invasion mode itself is fun for the first board and a half...then it's just tedious. All you need to win is put most of your stats into attack, then into health, then special and then defense. The enemies in this faux RPG mode are armored 90% of the time so you have to time your attacks to actually hit them without them just powering through your attacks. It teaches REALLY bad gameplay mannerisms. There's also no map, which you think wouldn't be a problem, but the boards meander all over the place and you can't zoom out far enough to see where you need to go.

Online connection errors are pretty frequent as well, but I don't bother playing online since the FGC is pretty toxic.

If they fix these issues moving forward, I'll change my review from not recommended to recommended. Some things have been fixed...but not enough.

Garbage netcode, constantly forced to play against people with >100 MS ping or <60 FPS, can not decline ranked matches unless the ping is over 150. Both wired and wireless connections feel like trash when you cross 80ms. No WiFi filter either. 

Oh, and frequently you will get matched against someone that supposedly has ~100-130 ping, but when the match starts the ping won't come under 170 -- so you're effectively forced to accept a match that will spend the entirety of its duration over the actual threshold for rejections. 

The gameplay is good, it's just a shame that you can not properly enjoy it due to terrible matchmaking and netcode. (don't even bother looking at the game if you're not planning to play online, there is no content)

I am a huge fan of the Mortal Kombat franchise and Netherrealm in general. Yeah their stories are pretty mid often. Cough cough MK9, X and 11. This is my first time owning a Netherrealm game on PC and I was a bit worried about how it might go since as you might all know Netherrealm doesn't make their PC ports in house and thats had a mixed bag. MK11 didn't get cross platform and so that didn't help for the games health but it had the Towers of Time which was good for Singleplayer content in my opinion. Invasions is interesting its a nice concept and could be really dope with some tweaks such as those goddamn Secret and Ambushes they become a bit tedious when you just want to get through a mesa. I've never really been too hardcore at fighting games but I understand them and I'm half decent so I've dipped my toes online of course since I'm on PC I don't have to pay to play online anymore thank god. Online reminds me of most MK's you got the top tier really strong characters where you can mostly spam the same thing and be safe so that gets a bit frustrating but ever character does feel viable and one slip up and you can take the game granted you know your strings. The Story mode was nice too I actually really enjoyed the story and the new universe, some of the plot feels weirdly rushed in some parts and just feels weird but game is fun enough to ignore it. The gameplay is so solid and fun I'm actually in the minority of MK fans about MK11 and I enjoyed its a bit slower and more grounded based gameplay. If you come straight from MK11 to 1 the first difference you'll notice is that the game is a bit faster and aerial combos are a big thing in MK1, you even get dedicated air strings for kombos now its really great. Kameo system is nice too but like always online is dominated by the same kameos over and over again. My biggest gripe with the game is the Singleplayer content seems very limited compared to MK11, far fewer cosmetic choices for characters most of it being in the shop instead of DLC characters releasing with skin packs they seem to only appear on the rotating shop now which is not cool in my opinion since there is no way to earn Dragon Krystals like you could with Time Krystals. And so far with Season of Blood starting sadly the skins you earn in it are the exact same as the Season of the Specter but red this time. It also feels like a punch in the gut that Omniman only has one skin. He doesn't even get a Viltrumite outfit or bearded Nolan. He gets a small handful of gear and some colour swaps. I'm hoping its not like this with all the DLC characters as MK11 was so nice having guest and DLC characters to have multiple skins. Pre fight dialogue is my other problem. We are now on two lines instead of MK11's three. The dialogue can only be heard on Versus against AI (Which doesn't reward XP) or you have to play online. It doesn't even play on Towers or Invasions, I guess thats because the Dialogue in this game is a seemless transition from select screen into the match without an obvious loading screen. But if the trade was to have a loading screen just for dialogue on Singleplayer content I'd take it. They really couldn't make the characters at least clash for towers? 

Overall I do really enjoy the game. Its faster than MK11 and zoning isn't the dominate playstyle. The graphics look great and the game runs really well since well its capped at 60fps because its a fighting game so its not that hard to run on cranked settings. But if you need a boost up-scaling is there with DLSS and FSR. I would recommend the game but maybe pick it up on sale if you only plan on doing Singelplayer content since you can't really experience all the dialogue and cool stuff without doing PVP or earning no rewards. If I could give a Yes and No option I maybe would but for now I do enjoy the game so its gets a Yes from me.

Good game in terms of gameplay, but good lord is it overpriced. Why the hell do I spend 77 dollars for the premium edition ON SALE but also have to buy a 20 dollar pack of kameo characters that somehow are not included with a "premium" edition.  This game is good, but it is not good enough to warrant a premium edition that STILL has multiple things missing. Its like if you bought a toy that was already expensive, but it comes without batteries and without a head. If I buy a game for over the price of $70, and it has only half of the items within it, do not call it premium. With games like Injustice 2, if you bought the ultimate edition, you practically got everything, including the DLC characters. Calling a product "premium" when it is missing things is disingenuous. Besides, had there not been a sale, I would have paid $110 dollars for a game that comes with half the kameos. Overall, while the gameplay itself is fun, the overmonetization of this game makes it feel more like a pay to play rather than a game in and of itself. Do not buy unless on sale. Also, Shang Tsung is a seperate character that costs 8 dollars unless you preordered, even if you bought the premium edition.

The new Mortal Kombat 1 successfully marries nostalgia with innovation. The inclusion of kameo characters like fan favorites Scorpion and Sub-Zero alongside surprise appearances from 3D era fighters adds depth to the roster, pleasing both old-school and newer fans.

The multiverse-based storyline is a standout feature, weaving together familiar narratives with fresh twists. The game's narrative complexity keeps players engaged, offering a refreshing take on the classic Mortal Kombat lore.

In terms of gameplay, the controls are fluid, and the visuals are a stunning upgrade. The revamped fatalities maintain the series' trademark brutality, satisfying the cravings of long-time enthusiasts.

Overall, Mortal Kombat 1 for PC successfully revitalizes a classic while embracing new elements, making it a worthy addition to the franchise.

Let me go ahead and list what I like about Mortal Kombat 1: I really love how NRS brought in this new kameo system, I feel like this adds a good lot to the mechanics of the game. I also love how the krypt was replaced with invasions, gives you a lot more to accomplish and do instead of grinding for currency to get new items. With the addition of titan battles and replacing the challenge towers with the gateway, I feel like this game will continue to provide plenty of fun for a long time to come! 

There are a few cons though, however, as there are for any game. As for Mortal Kombat 1, I found times where loading into fights and cut-scenes took almost several minutes, but I did find a fix for it! All I had to do was verify the integrity of the files and move them onto my C: drive (or the drive where windows is installed on) and that fixed the long loading times!

My final rating: 8.5/10 
I can't wait to see what NRS does with the game in the future!

The game itself is awesome. My only real gripes with it are the grind to level up characters, which wouldn't be that big of a deal if fatalities were not locked behind mastery levels, and the daunting amount of micro-transactions in various currencies.

UPDATE: With season 2, character mastery experience gain is absolutely abysmal; it's been reduced five-fold. While in season 1 I managed to level up 1.5 characters and kameos, by the end of season 2 I could not even complete the remaining 0.5 of the second character and kameo. Given that game content is locked behind mastery level, I have no choice but to resort to MITM hacks to enjoy the full range of content that I paid for. This is the second MK game in a row that suffers from this problem, so I will absolutely not be buying more MK titles, going forward.

The original review was posted on 27.10.2023, this is an updated version (today is 22.11.2023)
After the outcry developers changed the contents of the "controversial" 12$ "Seasonal fatalities package". Previously you were paying 12$ (1200 dragon krystals) for one seasonal fatality, and now the bundle contains 3 fatalities (Halloween, Thanksgiving, Christmas). And the people who bought the original bundle will also receive the other 2 fatalities.
It's a 1/7th the price of the entire game for 3 fatalities. This bundle is more expensive than GODLY "Separate Ways" (RE4 story DLC) that have hours of gameplay!!!
But let's put things into perspective, 10$ is a cost of a DLC character. You know what else costs 10$ in the premium ingame store? Announcers... Each announcer costs 10$! And if you bought Omni-Man DLC and like the character then you gotta buy the announcer separately! 10$ more please! And if I remember right the character costs 8-something $, that's cheaper than damn announcer! The pricing in this game is absolutely nonsensical!
Remember MK11? It got a FREE update where all of the characters got a whole "Friendship".
The game has "Blizzard level" of monetization. Hell, they are even selling stuff that could've been earned in the first season of the Invasions for Premium currency. What's worse however: 1) you can't refund; 2) you don't know what you're buying. I mean if you have something from the bundle you won't know what you already have and what you're buying; 3) Sometimes the contents are depicted wrong in the previews (Nitara's DA skin for example, 2 palettes were different).
And you can't earn premium currency in the game the way you could do it in MK11! You can earn about 5000 Dragon krystals through finishing the story, leveling up the profile and the character mastery (massive grind) but after that you can only buy it in the premium store.
Again, are we sure it's not a Blizzard game? 
Good fucking grief.
Oh, by the way, did I mention MK1 is a live service game? What does it mean? That means you can't do s#it without connection to servers. And once the developers pull the plug on the game you're gonna lose everything. "Buuuut they're gonna patch it!" No they won't. They removed their "GOLDEN KOW" (MK9, the game that had chances of becoming the "Resident evil 4" of the franchise) from the stores because of the stupid Freddy Krueger. And believe me they are not gonna renew the licences for all of the guest characters, so eventually once the servers go down the game will be unplayable. Just fantastic! It's a game with an expiration rate (just like MK11!) 
And I am not even mentioning that it's practically a beta version (as of now: 22.11.2023). The game with a bare bones content, horrible netcode, no crossplay, lots of bugs and glitches, and yeah, no Krypt!
That hurts. That really hurts. Because I loved the new story and revamp of most characters. The game features THE BEST versions of many characters. I am not gonna spoil the story, all I can say is that I've really enjoyed it, it's a huge upgrade from MK9-11.
Sadly, let's summarize the review.
If you don't have the game, DO NOT BUY IT. Wait the for the "Ultimate Edition" 2 years from now with everything included in it and a discount (60-85%).
And if you have the game like me, DO NOT BUY Dragon Krystals! Vote with your wallet! Over the top aggressive monetization in the game is absolutely outrageous and inexcusable!

Title: A Classic Brawler That Still Packs a Punch - Mortal Kombat 1 Review

Rating: 9.3/10

Mortal Kombat 1 is a timeless classic that has left an indelible mark on the fighting game genre, and even after all these years, it continues to stand tall as a testament to the golden age of arcade gaming.

The first installment of the Mortal Kombat series, released in 1992, introduced us to a world of intense martial arts battles, unique characters, and groundbreaking digitized graphics. One of the game's standout features is its iconic and now legendary fatalities, which were a groundbreaking and controversial addition at the time. These finishing moves added an extra layer of excitement and strategy to the gameplay, setting Mortal Kombat apart from its contemporaries.

The character roster, while not as extensive as later iterations, is diverse and memorable. Each fighter comes with a distinct set of moves and special abilities, making the game enjoyable for both casual players and seasoned fighting game enthusiasts. From Scorpion's spear to Sub-Zero's freezing techniques, the characters are brimming with personality and style.

The gameplay itself is fast-paced and responsive, with a smooth combo system that allows for satisfying and strategic combat. Mortal Kombat 1 struck a balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for those looking to master the intricacies of each character. The difficulty curve is well-designed, providing a challenge that keeps players engaged without becoming frustrating.

The digitized graphics, although dated by today's standards, were groundbreaking at the time and contributed to Mortal Kombat's distinctive visual identity. The character sprites are large and detailed, showcasing the effort put into creating a visually striking and memorable gaming experience.

The atmospheric soundtrack adds to the overall intensity of the game, with each character having their theme that perfectly complements their persona. The sound effects, especially the bone-crushing punches and kicks, further enhance the visceral and impactful nature of the battles.

While Mortal Kombat 1 may lack some of the bells and whistles of more recent entries in the series, its historical significance and enduring appeal make it a must-play for anyone interested in the roots of the fighting game genre. Whether you're a nostalgic fan reliving the glory days of the arcade or a newcomer curious about gaming history, Mortal Kombat 1 is a true classic that deserves its place in the pantheon of great video games. With a rating of 9.3/10, it stands as a testament to the enduring quality of this iconic title.

Mortal Kombat 1 is a thrilling reboot that revitalizes the iconic series with a charismatic cast and stellar gameplay mechanics. The game introduces a fresh narrative where Liu Kang strives to foster a kinder Mortal Kombat tournament, adding a compelling twist to the classic tale​​.

The gameplay is fluid and intuitive, yet offers depth for those eager to master it. The fantastic story mode alongside superb visuals provides an engaging experience that's hard to put down​​.

With the upcoming DLC, Kombat Pack 1, the excitement continues to build, promising more action-packed content for players to delve into. Mortal Kombat 1 is a modern-day classic that pays homage to its roots while boldly advancing the franchise into a promising future.

MK1 has been a money hungry cash grab from day one. Im not going to claim to be a MK expert cause ive only played about 3 of their games. Im going to compare MK1 to MK11 in this review. First off the campaign. If you want to start the story over and clean slate it, then do just that! The story is so bent on its head for trying to restart and trying to continue. PICK A SIDE! Also to have all of these cool skins and variations in the story, to not have anything like that in the customization sucks. The game launched with barley any customization so I feel that would have been a smart play to add in the beginning. Now the invasion game mode. You can tell alot of work went into it for like 4 months then they just said Ctrl+C Ctrl+V. Its extremely repetitive. I hate how they got rid of the freeze frame on fatalities, so now every end is just a generic stand behind a pile of meat with the word fatality in the corner. Now my biggest issue is the actual fighting part of the game. They got rid of krushing blows, for whatever reason. Interacting with the arena is not there anymore. Cameos were such a good idea, but the execution is kinda trash imo. The only this the cameo feels like its there to do is to ruin the game by giving players endless combos. Like hitting combos are cool, but when you loose 70% of your health in one chain the game is kinda broken. So many characters can get you in an insane >50% health combo because of cameos, like I get you should play to not get hit in those but the initial attack can be a instant jab. You only get ONE combo break every THREE bars. That right there I see as a big problem. If every character has a super easy combo that starts high goes low and hits an overhead after to chain into a longer combo that can be spammed cause it has a start up of 10 so there is no way to punish..... THEN WHY TF CAN I ONLY COMBO BREAK 1 TIME EVERY 3 BARS. In MK11 you had a 1 to 1 ratio, and that was good cause not only were the combos not >50% health, but if there was the occasional high damage combo you could break it 3 times. I get that this game you gotta play to master, but these combos are just too much damage. Either lower the damage a combo does, or give me more options to combo break. Until they fix that this game feels unplayable to me. Every match people are playing as if they are going for the championship with these combos. This dosent sound like a big issue, but this is a FIGHTING game. When my character is stuck in the air getting juggled for 10 sec while my health depletes, and I already broke the same combo right before. It tends to ruin the experience. Also to top it off there are already skins and fatalities in the game that the only way to get is to pay real money after spending 70$ for the game feels like a slap in the face.
 3/10 Do better.
has its problems but its pretty solid

It is obvious to me they put a lot of time and effort in re-imagining Mortal Kombat and, in my opinion, they have done an excellent job. The character appearance, the story line, even the detail to the background seems like an improvement.

Two of my concerns are the flow of the moves and the text-to-speech accessibility. The moves, to me, don't seem to go together as well as they could. The different moves to make up the combination almost seem separate of each other. Dead or Alive 6 seems to flow better. The text -to-speech is very good, but very bad. Don't get me wrong, I am among those who are most grateful to have it work in every menu option throughout the game. But I don't want to guess what it is saying. 

There is something going on with the graphics. Although great, i feel that they could be better. I don't know what it is. Perhaps someone else would have the words to explain it

That being said, $69 is far too much. I could not resist any longer and bought it for 30% off. I should have waited for 50%.

The introduction of kameo characters and aerial combos gives a nice twist on a classic game. It doesn't feel gimmicky at all which was my biggest worry, and makes it feel more fast paced and relentless than mk11.

The only negative from me is... the Krypt is no more, which is sad to see considering how good it was in MK11 :(

Also note most the negative reviews on Steam appear to all be related to graphic/technical issues which were quite minor and were resolved by me updating nvidia drivers.

Mortal Kombat 1 through the eyes of a kasual player of fighting games. (SPOILER FREE)

Honestly, I was expecting to not really like this game much. I rarely play fighting games because it has always been frustrating to learn moves and kombos, but to put it simply, this game has changed my entire opinion on fighting games.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Discovery and gameplay.

Kombat is fast, snappy, easy to grasp for beginners and hard to master for seasoned fans like myself. 
Even in regular gameplay you will manage to learn something new about whatever character you play.
Like this morning for example. I was running some Towers as Raiden when i discovered that you can chain cartwheels together as a kombostarter. 

Every character has moves that perfectly kounter and chain the moves of other characters and really makes kombat feel more thorough and knowlage based than "press button and thing happen".

Half of discovery in this game is based on your Kameo fighter that you select with your roster character before every match. A lot of Kameo and roster picks have synergy with moves and kombos. 
For example, Raiden's cartwheels bounce opponents into the air slightly, leaving just enough time to summon Jax as a Kameo to break their back for 90 damage. Its all about testing and knowledge. 

The FATAL BLOW system is back from MK11, but in a more digestible way.
No longer are late-match Fatal Blow attacks a death sentence, but more of a tool for intense pressure.
Some Fatal Blow moves have special attributes, most notably Johnny Cage's parry Fatal Blow.
It acts as a cure-all Kounter attack to almost every other Fatal Blow, meaning you need actual strategy to time and chain Fatal Blow moves, instead of just chucking them out whenever available. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Consumer Info. 

Micro-transactions are available but like most paid games there are ways to get cosmetics without spending a dime more than the cost of the game, but they take a LOT of time, patience, and even luck at times. 
One of the ONLY ways to get in-game premium currency is to complete character and Kameo mastery which takes weeks.
Theres about 200 "Dragon Krystals" per character mastery meaning you will eventually run out of spendable currency, which is a shame for players who don't have expendable money outside of what they saved for the games initial purchase, or just don't feel like wasting real money on cosmetic items in a game. With only two or three hundred per character mastery you will only be able to buy a skin for a character after mastering four characters, which is a lot to ask for kasual players who don't have the time or desire to sink weeks into a game that they only play on the side.
Another issue with transactions and skins is the Shrine. The Shrine is like the Krypt of MK past, but significantly more like gambling than before. Spend 1000 Koins (earned by playing matches) and get a random prize. Concept art, Music, Skins, Gear, the whole works. However every season there is a very limited amount of items available in the shrine's gambling system. This conflicts with the Weekly and Daily quests available in-game with some quests requiring you to spend koins in the shrine, effectively locking you out of skins and profile rewards PUNISHING you for completing a major part of the game making it utterly impossible to 100% complete the season.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

KONCLUSION

Mortal Kombat is innovative to the fighting genre.
The story is an incredibly well put together semireboot, the gameplay is snappy and thorough, the graphics are stunning and really bring color back to Kombat, and most importantly, its f*ckin fun to play, mate.

Here we are, another NRS release, another port done by QLOC. While the results in my own experience have been mixed, this has ultimately been a more stable port then MK11.

Most importantly, the game is LEAPS AND BOUNDS more fun then the previous installment.
---

PROS;
- The most fun MK game since MKX/9. Gameplay is wild and freedom of player expression is on display with the "Kameo" system. While neutral/footsies are still important, the overall design of the gameplay system(s) along with the Kameo system makes for a much more engaging and frantic experience.
- While the visual fidelity of the game is ultimately on-par/practically on parity as MK11 purely speaking from a technical standpoint, the art-style/color scheme this game uses is absolutely gorgeous. The one big standout that is certainly better is the lighting used as this is UE4, rather then UE3 as previous NRS titles have been on.
- Easily the best stages NRS has ever designed in any MK game, ever. I'd argue they're some of the best stages in *any* fighting game I've ever played. They're spectacular.
- Strong/Robust initial roster with plenty of fan favorites and some welcome "new" additions to the modern era of MK games with some of the 3D characters from Deadly Alliance/Deception. 
- Pretty fantastic musical score. For once, I'm actually interested in the OST in an NRS game. Well done on this front.
- True to NRS form, another good story mode entry. Doesn't take itself too seriously, and is hilarious at various points.
- Invasions mode, allbeit grind-y, is a better/more interesting addition to the single player content in the game rather then the "Towers of Time" from MK11.
---

CONS;
- First and foremost being a PC port, this has been hit/miss for many people, and is reflected in the reviews. My experience initially was God-awful and I refunded the game. After 2 days of FOMO (30 year MK fanboy here with the Dragon tattoo.) I was determined to troubleshoot the game and get it functional. I ultimately did. 

YOU MUST ensure your drivers are up-to-date with the latest "Game Ready Driver" from nVIDIA (or AMD equivalent.) The game also has some odd frame-pacing/timing issues, regardless of graphical options in-game from all the testing I've done and playtime. To eliminate this issue almost entirely, I used nVIDIA Profile Inspector to ensure Ansel in any/all capacity is completely disabled, FPS locked to 60 (this can be done through the base driver software.) and ensured that FAST VSYNC/GSYNC is enabled. Don't buy into the 60hz refresh rate nonsense you might of read, that makes 0 difference.

In-Game Settings || AMD FSR 1.0 - Quality / All settings Very High/On
i76800K OC'd 4.0/1080 STRIX/32G DDR4-2400

A lot of the issues I've read are actually effecting people with much higher-end hardware then my own. QLOC has acknowledged the performance woes thus far, a patch/update however remains to be seen.

FPS stayed locked at this point to 60 at nearly all times, with only minor hiccups which became very rare. The game *does* pre-cache/cook shaders on initial boot, but it still has some shader hiccups. 

I'm also using Process Lasso to give the game access to as much horsepower as I can to further bolster performance.

Stability has been mostly acceptable in my 25~ hours of playtime with only a few crashes. A few times during invasions, and once during netplay online. I've had 2 8+ hours sessions of playtime with 0 issue thus far.

Lastly on the presentation/performance front - as with MK11 (until it was patched out) menus, cutscenes, fatalities, fatal blows, essentially anything that isn't gameplay with fighting is locked at 30FPS. This is extremely jarring and I'm a little baffled QLOC went this route again on the PC release. This will likely be patched/updated as it was in MK11... I just don't understand why it wasn't designed this way in the first place. Modders are already correcting the FPS for the menus.

- Online in this game is ultimately disappointing and fairly bare bones in it's implementation. Ranked matches FORCE you into playing who the game ultimately matches you against, regardless of their connection type as long as the ping is less then 150ms~. This means, if you're paired against someone on wireless, even if you simply sit at the queue screen and don't accept, the game will eventually *force* you into playing against said player, with no option to decline or back out. You'll also receive a loss if you close the game in the interim/DC if you don't want to play against said player. This is backwards game design. SF doesn't do this. Tekken doesn't do this. GG doesn't do this.

Wireless in fighting games is unacceptable as far as a competitive environment is concerned. If anyone tells you otherwise, they're low in the IQ department. Go purchase an Ethernet cable and wire your setup. It isn't difficult. The netcode in this game is acceptable for people on wired connections but it's not going to do you any favors whatsoever against those on wireless.

NRS - you missed here. This sorely needs to be updated. *no one* likes how you're handling the matchmaking implementation in this game in regards to connection types. Either allow your player base to filter wireless users, or back out of wireless matches.

There are no lobbies as far as casual matches are concerned, or King of the Hill. The game simply performs it's matchmaking query, then connects you to someone. It does have private rooms however for KOTH.

- I'm not a tournament level player of NRS games so perhaps I don't really have any room to complain about this, but this game is *VERY* unfriendly to T/Os looking to run it at their event(s). Save data must be established and story-mode must be completed to unlock Havik, and your profile level must be level 25 to unlock all of the base kameo roster. This is another backwards, out of touch design choice made.

- While there is plenty to unlock in the game from a cosmetics/flare standpoint with skins, color pallets and brutalities, it's still excessively grind-y in NRS fashion and doesn't respect the players time. Hell, using the "Shrine" is a practice in time-vampirsm as you can only consume one stack of 1K currency and must wait before you can consume another stack.
---

INDIFFERENT;

- I miss the Krypt.
- The controls in this game like any other NRS titles have that level of "NRS-Jank" to them where the input buffer/accuracy is concerned. I don't love it. I don't hate it. The inputs at times however can feel *very* strict.
- Crossplay is missing at launch. For me personally I couldn't care less right now as the online experience is sub-par but this will be a huge miss for a lot of people.
---

Ultimately at the end of the day, this game is leaps and bounds more fun then the previous installment. The Kameo system allows for some awesome player expression, gameplay feels fast and engaging, and the presentation is world-class. It isn't without it's flaws however, with in classic NRS fashion, numerous sub-systems that don't respect the player's time, and a woefully sub-par online experience thus far.

It's also a QLOC PC port, so mileage as evidenced by countless others WILL vary.

If you're a diehard NRS/MK fan like myself and you've got the hardware and some minor PC technical knowledge to combat any issues you might come across, pick it up now. Otherwise, just wait until it's on sale.

If you have a console (baring the SWITCH :kekw:) just get it on console.

Game - 8/10 || PC Port - 7/10

Mortal Kombat 1 graphics are a flawless homage to the original, enhanced with today's technology to create a visually stunning spectacle. Combat mechanics are fluid and intuitive, ensuring that both newcomers and veterans can enjoy the thrill of battle. The character roster is meticulously crafted, offering a diverse range of fighters each with unique styles and moves.

However, there's a significant thing that detracts from the overall experience – the item pricing model. In an unexpected twist, players are required to purchase both fatalities and skins, which are traditionally integral components of the Mortal Kombat experience. This decision not only impacts the game's accessibility but also detracts from the sense of achievement and progression. Unlocking fatalities and skins through gameplay achievements has always been a rewarding aspect of the series, and shifting this to a pay-to-access model feels like a step back from the franchise's player-centric values.

Even though I am recommending this game, it does not come flawlessly into the market. Game needs a few more touches before it can be called great (not talking about the story-line, whatever happened in there).

1) I don't know if I didn't search enough and whatnot but comparing to MK11, we can't pick our intro and outro moves or cutscenes), still, correct me if I'm wrong here.

2) Season story is a mess. It needs a total overhaul. Basically you jump into season journey having the narrator explaining the story and then you just walk, fight and loot in a board-game like map which gets really old at a certain point because the story is already told and then it's just a mindless, monotone grind for cosmetics without having any additions to the season story whatsoever.

5) Shrine. The shrine is a place where you can trade some in-game currency for a variety of cosmetics, sure it's good but it takes literally 36,5 hours for it to unlock, what's the problem here ?

6) Kameos. Kameos are okay but a mode without them would be great, I for one am not a fan of Kameos and I rarely used them so far and my games are going great anyway.

7) In invasions which basically is the season thing, there can be some modifiers for the NPC enemy fighter. There's a specific one, the armor which is waaay out of control. Every move, every hit, armor. I swear I played a game with enemy being Sub-Zero with armor and a map modifier for freezing, I didn't move until it was too late, the map literally came into me through the back door. Also the bosses in there, boring. Just a foe with 3 lives and a s**tload of armor.

I like the game so far but I'm not crazy over it like MKX or MK11. You just need to hear out your fan-base to make it a better game. After all, it was meant for us.

P.S: Fix Reptile, and fix Ermac's face before releasing him, like, what is that face lol.

Thanks for your time reading.

One thing I love in this game is the face models for the characters. All of them look amazing. I think we've gotten the best faces for every character in this game. Liu Kang is probably the best looking one as well.
I'm happy they brought back the meter system into the game, very much preferred than the offence and defence bars from 11.
I really do like the story for this game. Not only a reboot, but still a sequel to the previous timeline. What I Love in this game is seeing the recreated origins in different contexts. My favourite would have to be Kenshi's blindness, watching that blindfold slowly tied around his eyes was awesome! Kenshi's relationship with Johnny is still the best in the franchise, from MK X all the way to MK 1. Many characters were once evil are now with the good guys. A sight to behold!
Gameplay is the same to me other than the inputs for moves and the return of the meter system. I love it all the same however.
I do prefer the the customisation in this game for than MK11. Having a skin and one item for good for me. MK11 Had three items you could change, with many characters a third item seemed almost pointless to change. But here in MK1 just one item looks better.
I will say the soundtrack is as always the best. I think for this game the soundtrack fits so perfectly. A game set in peace, yet the hint of danger or mysterious malice at hand. Listening to it brings peace of mind while going through the menu.
Jean-Claude Van Damme being in the game as a Johnny Cage skin is by far the best choice Netherrealm have made for Johhny Cage! Giving him a skin of the man who inspired the character AND wearing the attire from the movie that Started the very inspiration of the Mortal Kombat franchise as a whole! Always loved Van Damme and to have him in the game Voiced by the man himself is a dream come true! A prize over 30 years in the making finally came!
The voice acting is incredible, both new and returning voices. Everyone plays their part Very in character and bring them all to life in All the right ways! Megan Fox however has me conflicted. Her acting in Mortal Kombat 1 sounds almost lifeless. You especially hear the difference when she speaks just before or just after another character speaks. But I don't hate Megan Fox for it, there should have been a direction to point her towards to win a better audience for this game. It confuses me more than anything since Megan Fox has been in voice acting roles before and she sounds just fine, but here she sounds like she's simply reading the lines from the paper and that's it. Strange but not a deal breaker for me.

I absolutely Love Mortal Mortal 1 and can't wait for the DLC packs to arrive overtime. The game had a great story, soundtracks designs and overall aesthetics! Cannot wait for another game in the next 4 years!
Highly Recommended to try for all fighting game fans.
awesome fighting game with awesome characters and fun single player content

I do recommend this game as a long time fan of Mortal Kombat and a fighting game enthusiast. That being said, this game is missing a lot, a disturbing amount. 

The story of the game is quite fun and is over 4 hours of cut scenes. Like 11, it felt like a movie with parts I get to play. The timeline reset story is fine and I enjoy most of the characters and how they are portrayed. I do miss the conflicts and changes of sides during the previous on going story line. Starting at the beginning again means some characters will be missing from the roster. No Noob Sibot, No robo smoke or Sub-Zero and several more. But the beauty of starting over allows for new ways to introduces those characters. speaking of introducing characters there are ZERO new characters as of currently. The only hope we have is for DLC to bring in new characters but I would assume they would use that for third party characters like Omni-man and bringing in characters that didn't make it in on release like Ermac and Quan Chi whom by the way are fully put together, working characters that are in the story mode but are not playable. Also on the character front, say good-bye to some of your favs because they have been pushed aside as 'Kameo' characters, who you pick along side your playable character who can be used for small boosts, hits and combos but have no use as characters otherwise. The list includes Jax, Sonya, Kano, Sektor, Cyrax, Motaro and frickin' GORO, and more. What makes little sense is that some of the Kameo characters are also playable, Scorpion, Sub-Zero and Kung Lao all have both Kameo and Playable character fighters. I'm so bummed that I cant play some of my favorites now that they have been demoted to kameo characters. Mortal Kombat 11 had 25 playable characters on launch while Mortal Kombat 1 has 23 playable characters and 16 wasted Kameo characters. I can only hope they will add some of them as both Kameo and playable. Also characters I hope for are maybe coming based on rumors like Cassie Cage and Noob Sibot but no confirmation. You can also say good-bye to the possibility of the Kollecter being playable, as he is the shop merchant in the story game mode invasions. At the very end of the story *SPOILERS* Liu Kang brings in other elder god, time lords from other timelines to fight off the army of Shang Tsung's time lords and undead foes. during this segment and ensuing fights there are all kinds of characters that we will never get to play who have full move sets, Like a female version of Kano or a merge between Sub-Zero and Scorpion a Sonya who uses Kitana's blades and MANY MANY MORE! Its like they're teasing us with custom characters and playable fighters who we will never get to play. That is unless they add any of this in the future. We can hold out hope I guess.

I know I've talked a lot of negative but there is also a lot to love about this game. Its plays well, combos are fun to pull off, hearing people rage into their microphones when I win. Just some of the few things you can love about this game. Again the story is super entertaining and friendly to old and new Mortal Kombat players alike. And with the story ending in a large cliff hanger (where Jax is missing his arms, very cool) who knows if we'll see more in a DLC or free update. I have high hopes for the future of MK1. Started rocky but a possible uphill climb to perfection.

    Current Condition 9/24/2023:  6.9/10

I bought this game on the PS5 first. Since I was having fun with the story and the achievements seemed relatively doable, I decided to buy it on Steam.

I don't know why I thought performance would be the same as a PS5's. Now, I'm no PC master race enthusiast; I only have a Steam Deck to play this game on, but 30 FPS is very annoying! The loading times make grinding for kameo XP feel longer than on the PS5. The invasions section would very often crash. The seasonal tower would glitch at the end where after the "Finish Him!" came on and I executed the final hit, somehow the match would continue. Since the timer was already stopped, there was nothing for me to do other than exit out of the match and lose my tower progress. Sometimes even doing long combos would cause the game to freeze, meaning that I had to force shutdown the game. Also, the graphics would sometimes drop to the point where I thought I was playing the Switch version of the game!

Honestly, if you just HAVE to play this game, buy it on either PS5 or Xbox Series X.

First of all, I am so so tired of being surprised at every turn, wondering how they could screw up the script even more. Let me shove the pens of the writing team up their asses. Being this clueless and directionless requires an immeasurable amount of special effort.

Then, second of all, the main villain of the story (Shang Tsung) is a pre-order dlc which is also later purchasable. Alright... Not new. They did the same trick twice in a row, huh? Old habits die hard.
Ermac, one of the helpers of Shang Tsung, will come along with Kombat Pack. Okay.
Havik, a returning character afters a decade or so, who is also included in the story is also a DLC character and does not even unlocked with the kombat pack. As far as I know neither Shang Tsung or Havik should be unlockable in-game.
And then, Takeda out of nowhere.
And of course, 3 popular superheroes in one single DLC pack to milk them effectively. Feels (thematically) ironic. Where is Injustice when you badly need it? 

This amount of greed... It just cannot be understood. Whole new cameo system with a random bullshit go roster. I do not believe it adds much depth into the game. Incredibly awful final boss, incredibly awful last chapter which acts like it was a fanfic of a kindergarten kid who combines his fav. characters into one single being. 4 years later we are still struggling with this whole multiverse and alternate timelines shit. Invasions are unintuitive and incredibly repetitive. Why does it even last a month? 5 hours of shit content. I'd rather have a battle sim and let it play itself lmao. Skins are god awful. Would not spend a dime on them. 
Just fuck off. Where'd you learn to be this sob netherrealm? As long as they insist on not making IJ3 and keep milking MK, I am simply out. I was angry with MK11 already but this game is outright disgracious. Even a soft reboot cannot save the franchise. All they do is cutting and adding characters back and forth until it stop making sense at all. It's a loop, it's a nightmare. The game's forgotten in a span of a week. SF6 torn it apart, simply and beatifully. 

7/10, for the animation and visual team.


Footnote: I am well aware that many of the fighting games do these 'dlc tricks' but since when it became an exact norm to sell/give as a pre-order bonus the characters where they use them in story actively. It's impossible to not grow sick of these antics. Reserve the DLCs for guest characters and legacy characters that are not in the game. Takeda is acceptible in that sense although him as a choice does not make sense to me. Everything else is ridiculous so far.

With 220 Hours now under my belt, I think its safe to say I have had enough time with the game to form a pretty extensive review:

"The Bads"
To get them out of the way, the recent prices of skins in microtransacations has been nothing short of terrible. To pay 10 dollars for one skin is a ridiculous amount of money to anyone, and I hope this part of the review ages poorly and they fix it in the future. Customization now is also a giant step down from the last game, with only one customization gear piece and roughly three skins per character you can get for free. Its simply a bad system and I hope in the next game, they can fix it.

"The Goods"
This game has to have one of the best storymodes in any Mk game. Not only is it written well with great homages to the past while also being extremely welcoming to new players, but it also fixes problems with both the last game while improving on characters like Reptile and Baraka who have had less than favorable times in the MK story before this. The twist was something I genuinely didn't see coming, and offers an ultimate bit of fanservice.

This game also just might have the best gameplay since MKX. While it doesn't outright beat MKX in terms of fun fast gameplay, it still offers a lot of strategy and setplay using the brand new Kameo system. Having a set of new moves you can swap between with any Kameo can make characters be played completely differently depending on the kameo you have. Matches can be fun and intense and offer a deep sense of unique gameplay, something that was missed in MK11.

Overall, while the weakness are definite, the main gameplay and story truly make it a fantastic package. I highly recommend this game with an 8/10, I really hope they fix the skin price issue, and I can't wait to see the future seasons of DLC!

The game's story is awesome, and trying out different character combinations with kameos feels cool. But I'm not feeling too positive about it right now because the Invasions mode, meant for people who like fighting but not PvP, isn't done well. Also, it costs a lot for what you get. I might change my mind later and give it a good review.

Invasions sounded good in theory, but how it actually works isn't great. You can easily speed through it by putting all your points into attack and special abilities, making it too easy. Except for a few tough boss fights, it's a breeze.

Two big problems really bug me about this game: the long wait times when loading and the micro transactions. Even on a decent computer, I had to wait up to 2 minutes sometimes just to start playing. When Invasions are already too easy, this waiting makes the game not fun. Waiting a minute for a short 25-second battle feels frustrating.

For a Mortal Kombat fan this is amazing, for a casual enjoyer who wants to get the bang for their buck wait until changes are made.

Let me give a review of Mortal Kombat 1

First of all, I will start with the graphics:

- The graphics of the game are generally much better on the faces and face animations are better than before!
But the biggest improvement in the game's graphics are the game's animations, which I think have become much better than 11

- Smooth and natural motion captures are done in the best way
In terms of execution, the game does not have any stutters (I am playing without the day one patch and this patch has not been released for PC yet (first day of early access), the configuration of my rig is 11 gen i5 , GTX 1650 and 16 gigs of ram.
On 1080p resolution, medium and FSR 2.0 quality, I get between 48 and 60 frames depending on the game location, and of course, the majority of the game is the 50fps and above, and the game runs very cleanly, and I did not see any stutters, bugs, or lags. 

- The graphical arts of the game are awesome.


- In terms of story, I have been playing for about three hours
So far, I think it is more interesting than Kombat X and 11


- The cut-scenes and filming have become much, much better.
One of the faults that I personally had for 11 was the terrible filming in the cut-scenes.

- In the voice department, I must say that it is very perfect and I did not see any special defects in it

- In the fight itself, the characters talk to each other and sing to each other, and we don't see repetitive dialogue anymore.

- The music of the game awesome, and each stage has its own music, which is very pleasant.


But The Gameplay itself:
So far, I have seen a smooth renders and smooth fighting.
In terms of gameplay speed, the game is something between 11 and X, I think, it is not as tactical as 11 and not as aggressive and fast as X. and I really haven't gotten used to the cameo system yet, the combos are easier to hit compared to 11 and are much smoother and so on. The characters have many different techniques. 


- And lastly I still don't have an opinion to compare MK 1 with the Street Fighter 6 and I have to play more to give an opinion.

After spending almost 71 hours in this game, I can confidently say that it is absolute misunderstanding and a terrible failure.
-invasion movement, fatalities, intros, outros, are locked at 30 FPS.
-since release, the developers are focused more on adding microtransactions than patching the game. Patches supposedly fixed some problems if you check the official patch notes but from my point of view, a lot of bugs appeared after patching. I have mixed feelings on this point because, on the one hand we have patch notes that are extensive, but I have been playing this game since its release and I wouldn't say that anything has been fixed. I experience the same bugs and even more, not to mention that we still have a 30 FPS lock. :(
-unlike MK 11, micropayment currency cannot be earned in-game, you can unlock some of it by grinding levels for your characters, but compared to the prices in the premium shop you can't buy much with it. And of course, taking into account the grinding time, once you collect it, the item will no longer be available in the store. Prepare real money.
-the content of this game is a complete joke. It constitutes maybe 20% of the mk 11 content. But don't worry, the creators have already added some outfits/fatalities for micropayments. 1000 Dragon Crystals for one outfit, so about 10 $ if I calculated correctly.
-invasion seasons, forcing you to grind extremely hard because, after it ends, items from the invasion shop will no longer be available for unlocking. For now it looks like this, we have an invasion season that lasts 30-40 days. During this time, we go through the invasion zones to reach the last boss whom we defeat to unlock 1 "unique" outfit, color palettes for it and palettes for other "standard" outfits. Unlocking palettes for standard outfits involves an incredible grind for silver, which can then be redeemed in the seasonal shop. After the first season, I managed to unlock all palettes and I was still grinding for silver to have it for the next season. Then game's creators decide to clear all the players' "savings" from the first season. Great !!!!
-invasions are extremely tiring due to enemy modifiers such as shields - especially for bosses, burning floors, life draining, blinding, etc. It is also worth mentioning survival games, where the difficulty increased significantly in the second season. Invasions do not have a difficulty level, so if we get stuck at one point, we will not proceed further, and therefore we will not unlock anything This applies to players who are taking their first steps in fighting games or are simply not skilled at it. In this game there is no auxiliary AI that we send to get a reward like in MK 11.
-each character has something like a mastery tree where we gain experience, unlock new levels that give us new color palettes, and a few items to change the appearance of our character. The experience grind for the characters is out of this world and the rewards compared to the grind are worth nothing !!!!!
-during season two, the developers decided to reduce the amount of silver and experience awarded by increasing the grind.
-outfits from the first season appeared in the store. Reducing the amount of silver earned by a player in season two will lead to an increase in the percentage of players who will not have time to grind out all the outfits. Then this will force them to buy the outfits from the store. Special thanks to the creators !!!!
-the Kamo system is overrated as hell. These are nothing more than boosters taken from MK 11 and formed into a rooster, only worse in terms of the actions and attacks they perform.

To sum up, for 110 $ we get a game with microtransactions, small amount of content and insane big grind for minimal rewards. It's a pity because the gameplay is quite nice. In my opinion, this part of Mortal Kombat is simply a rip-off for fans of the series and new players. A lot was promised, and in fact, we players paid a lot and we were given some onion peels.
Blegh !!!!!!

Editing my review after another 150 or so hours.  It is the best gameplay a MK game has had in a very long time, but every other aspect of the game is half-assed and under delivered.  No crossplay, no wifi filtering, black screen bugs in kombat league, etc.

One thing you'll be happy to know is that the real money shop works perfectly and gets updated regularly with $12 fatalities.  By the time all the characters are released, I'll probably have $200+ in this game and it's not worth it.  The only way to justify the predatory microtransactions would be to make the game free to play, but it's a $70 title, more expensive than competitors will better games right now.  

NRS/WB hasn't shown much effort in addressing the community's problem so I'm starting to lose hope that the game will be brought up to the standards of other games in the fighting game genre.  If you aren't a hardcore MK fan, just wait until the complete edition comes out with everything for $20 in a couple years.

All of these are my opinions.

Pros:
Improved air combat from previous games.
Returning of old characters from the early 2000s.
Fresh new beginning for the story.
Excellent character choices for Kombat Pack 1.
Improved on Scorpion's "GET OVER HERE!" since it was quiet in MK11. Along with giving him a rope spear.
Shao and Geras are not as annoying to me unlike the last game.
Invasions are a breath of fresh air, but they're alright as a game mode.

Cons:
Currently the PC port has a locked frame cap at just 30 fps outside of fighting gameplay.
Microtransactions.
Megan Fox's voice acting for Nitara.
Havik as a purchasable character despite you can just play the story and get him for free.
Shang Tsung still being behind a paywall.
EVERYONE online keeps playing as Smoke, Raiden, Baraka, Geras, or Johnny Cage.
Sub-Zero was nerfed so badly a 10 hit kombo could deal like 1%.
Having cosmetics for fighters at an average of 10 USD.
Standard edition costing $70 dollars. Loving 2023!

So, if you are not bothered by any of the cons I have to mention, you can definitely have fun playing!

This game is fun! I recommend it. BUT only after they drop the price a bit. This game is not worth the price it's at currently. Mainly because the lack of content, bugs, lack of quality of life features, and microtransactions. I will go into more detail in this review. That being said, I've had a lot of fun playing all the characters in this game! Honestly I've never tried so many characters in a fighting game like I did in this one. With maybe Sub-Zero being the most boring one to play. Let's go ahead and start with the "Story Mode".

-STORY MODE-
- To no surprise, Netherealm Studios is known to make the best stories in the fighting game genre. You get to connect with most of the cast as they journey together to participate in the Mortal Kombat tournament which is only hosted once every century. MK1 starts off after the end of the "Aftermath" story in MK11 with a cinematic approach. The store puts focus on developing it's characters in Liu Kang's new timeline. Having talented voice actors, and stunt performers on the fighting choreography of the game. The MK1 story is of good quality, with the story falling off a bit towards the end. If I were to compare the story to MK11, I would most certainly say that the MK11 fighting choreography was much more entertaining. MK1 has more focus on developing the rosters story more than the fighting. Makes sense, being that this is KIND OF a new start but the fighting choreography was till good.

- I do have some complaints about the direction of some of the characters, like Shang Tsung. In this story, Shang Tsung is not as intimidating as he is in MK11. He's a lot more soft and fruity. Lacking the brutality of how he was previously. I didn't like this direction for the character, it made him a less compelling villain than how he was in MK11. Perhaps the director was just trying to appeal to a particular audience by making him... colorful without the extra color. One could imagine, being that nowadays we are surrounded by a generation full of leftist influencers that are much like the Mileena fans who will try to kill you like poor Kenshi in the story. Mostly virtually and anonymously at least. Or perhaps the director willingly made Shang Tsung a less intimidating character. Now speaking of... it is almost as if today's Disney made changes to the story and some of it's characters. With the new timeline being used to make the changes on how those characters are.

Also Mileena is not really Mileena anymore, not that I am a Mileena fan but I will miss her former self... Part of why I liked her so much was because of her seductive essence, her ability to fool you with her body language and her ways to make her voice sound seductive, only to spook you once she takes off her mask where you're like "Woah!  Eww nevermind!". Gonna miss her teases like "wanna have fun?" and the guys are like "oh no... no no no. I'm good"

Still... cool story! 7/10 Yes! 7 because there's way too many multiverse movies. It's so saturated now that I was about to give it a 6 on the "story mode" or even a 5. It's so much like Marvel that it was almost like watching another Marvel movie.

-VERSUS MODES- 
- Online! We are missing A LOT of stuff and we are talking quality of life stuff even. Like Match History, Online Modes, Report System, Hide Selection option, Mute on Select Screen, Practice mode, Practice Mode on KOTH, Mute Self on KOTH, emojis and text chat for KOTH, Crossplay, Lobbies, and Friends List for those who want to play with their friends on Epic Games and potentially others like PlayStation and Xbox. Yeah! It sucks! But fighting against other players is probably one of the better experiences in the game after completing "Story Mode". That is until you come across a Sindel with an unblockable infinite combo with Jax or whatever. Even so! Online is the only mode you can play right now where you can enjoy a more dynamic gameplay experience! Since we barely got any modes anyway. 4/10 what happened here?

-INVASION-
- Want palettes for your skins? Seasonal Premiere skin? Titan Skins? You play THIS! Invasion mode... The most BORING monotonous mode in the game that you only play cause you really want that premiere skin. And the grind is absolutely dreadful... You have to go through 5 full mesa maps just to get to the premiere skin in the 6th map and then complete a series of other lame unrewarding fights with the occasional secret fights that get in your way. This mode made me feel so bored of Mortal Kombat that I don't believe I can tolerate it enough to get through the upcoming seasonal premiere skins. This is the "Towers of Times" rewards replacement of MK11. And the actual "towers of time" are on their own Mesa Map as well. And... I don't seem to get anything interesting in those either. Titan skins are obtained on the Armageddon Mesa and it pops up randomly and it's suppose to only last 4 or 5 days, but it's bugged so it lasts longer than that.  Fighting a large Baraka while he spins at you all crazy, is a bit funny.  Invasion Rating is a 2/10  for me.

-TOWERS-
Well... It's just classic tower mode, nothing special to it.

-MONETIZATION-
- This is $70 game to over $110 if you got the premium edition and you're telling me that we have a store with some expensive exclusive items as if this was a F2P game?! This is was obviously a terrible idea! I do not support it, and I suggest you don't as well but if you want to see something like that added in future games in this fashion, that's up to you. I will buy nothing from the store cause it's obviously greedy Bull Shih-Tzu... wtf dude 1/10, WB games is trash for that.

-CONTENT-
- Barely any modes. Only Story, Versus, Invasion, and Practice (or impossible combo mode) 

-CONTENT THAT'S NOT IN MK1
No Tag Team, No KOTH Survival, No Co-op Tag Team towers or Co-op Tag Team vs Other players, No modifier game modes for versus and online, no group battle, no konquest mode, no elemental reaction mode, no party modes.  Lack of finishers, No Frienship, No Stage Fatalities, No interactable brutalities, no Fatal Blow animation kustomize options which sucks cause a lot of the Fatal Blows are nowhere near as cool as in MK11. Fatal Blows are now like you go punch face, now I punch face... Look up Shang Tsung fatal blow in MK11. Gimme something stylish NRS.

-ENDING-
Hope this helps on your decision in making a purchase. The game is fun to play, but I suggest you wait until the price drops. $70 is way too much for what it offers... If you want a more complete game with less bugs, try out Street Fighter 6.

Yeah it's fun. Yeah it's better than MK11. Improved story mode. Good roster. Interesting combat, and a cool cameo system. It even looks great and runs well on my 1650. But something is off, don't you agree? Only 22 fighters in the base roster? A weird number, right? Well there's a reason for that.

#23 is Shang Tsung- A pre-order bonus despite being a central character in the main game ($8 if you missed your chance). #24 and 25 are Ermac and Quan Chi- Fully implemented, fully completed, featured side characters in the story that you face more than once. They will be in Kombat pack 1 ($40).

We are fast approaching the logical conclusion of Warner Brothers bs and I am not thrilled at how normalized this behavior is becoming. AAA games are officially $70... fine, it can't be helped. But to ride the standardized price raise while being more aggressive with the nickel/dime tactics is just insulting.

Abysmal and insulting PC port. main menu, Fatal Blows, fatalities are capped at 30fps. While the gameplay can go to 60. This makes it extremely jarring when mid match the game suddenly drops from 60 to 25, as well as constant frame dips and poor general performance. Wait for a patch to fix these issues. It's a shame considering the gameplay and fighting systems themselves are phenomenal, the most interesting, fun and dynamic MK has ever been.

A good amount of tweaking is needed to make this run somewhat properly, and even then it feels like it's holding on by a thread.

Worst MK to date everything is pay for unlike the previous MK which had free earning for most in game items. Balancing is horrible so many characters dominate while others are left in the dust lacking damage and any suitable combo that doesn't require 3 bars. Perfect example would be Raiden vs Sub Zero, Sub Zero has been horrible and has not gotten a buff on damage since the game came out. On the other hand Raiden has like 5 strings and combos which are all barless netting him 40% while sub uses all three to get 35-38%. Same can be said for Geras and many more. Why they have such a damage disparity is beyond me. I have played almost 100 hours on this game and Honestly can safely say they took a huge step back since MK11.

I am a huge fan of MK, especially since MK II, and it is frustrating to see how this franchise has turned into FIFA: it's the same game as the previous one, with a few changes here and there, and that's it. Of course everyone is ranting about WB charging for silly, unnecessary fatalities. And I even felt pity when someone did that fatality on me cause I felt really sad thinking "poor guy, he has spent 10 dollars, he has to do it". But I really want to address gameplay and balancing:

- When almost EVERYONE you play against online uses the SAME character (Johnny Cage) and with the SAME kameo it gets tiring. This also happened with the mass of Scorpions in MK 11. It seems like everyone chooses the character/kameo combination with the longest combos just to win, or at least they watch who the pros play with, copy their combos and do the same thing. If everyone decides to choose the best character, with the best strategy, then that is actually bad design: barely no one uses Tanya, Sindel, Rain, Ashrah or Kung Lao. If they choose the other characters, prepare to see the same combo over and over again. There were lots of times that I won against Johnny Cage players, or Raiden, or Baraka/Cyrax, but it didn't feel rewarding at all to win in those cases: it made me feel exhausted, and not wanting to go through the same ordeal again

- Netcode works REALLY bad: my character (mainly Sindel) kept doing things online which I specifically haven't asked, making me doubt that my controller wasn't working correctly or that I was not pressing the right buttons. But then I realized that when the ping was lower, I was able to play correctly. And I didn't have those issues when practicing or playing the towers

- Kameos are a lazy Tag system that is poorly balanced. They had a similar kameo system in the Towers of Time in MK 11 and for some reason they thought it would be a good idea, but nothing is better than tag combat as in MK 9: the combos were limited and you could tag whenever you want if you wanted to change your strategy. I feel like this is like having some extra special moves added to your own character. It doesn't even make sense story-wise

- Combos are VERY repetitive and extremely long and boring: it's annoying for both players to wait for the other to finish their 20 hits combo, to make a mistake and then see the exact same combo. Instead of making players be creative, it restricts everyone to choose the best strategy and use that same thing each time. Also, the animations in some cases are so long that they affect the dynamics of the combat itself: you have to wait for the other to see a combo or for the fatal blow to end to keep playing, as if you are watching a cinematic. I think they should include a system like "Maximum Damage" from MK 4, limit the amount of hits or damage per combo, add systems like stamina or maybe increase the difficulty of extending a combo after a certain time.

- There are no rewards for taking major risks during battles: it seems that if you make a mistake, you are bound to see a minute-long combo while realizing that your meter is slowly increasing. You can only break from a combo after your meter is full, but that will happen after the combo ends. So am I supposed to carefully control my meter and not use it to enhance special moves? I thought I didn't like the two-meter system from MK11, but seeing this I realize that it was much better as it separated attack and defense. Also, the meter fill rate should be higher after a certain number of hits. It seems like the game is made not to let the other play, but to play alone.

Overall, I loved it and played a lot, probably due to nostalgia and fanaticism, but the gameplay imbalance, with the addition of bugs, poor ping, bad netcode and lousy monetization and economy decisions (I lost count of how many currencies you can manage in the play, and how some are really unnecessary and inflationary) make me not recommend MK 1, at least until they fix it properly. When that day comes, I will reinstall it for sure.
