First of all the campaign is interesting and kinda fun excluding the annoyance with the combat system which I will cover later. I played and completed the campaign on the easiest difficulty within a day.

My main annoyance with this game is the seasonal bull crap (apparently seasonal stuff will return so it's not as bad when it comes to you only have X amount of time to do everything since it will return. But still it's basically do the same thing for every season). So they have a game mode thing that the closest thing that came to my mind is Mario Party. Basically they have 6 maps filled with dots that are different activities but you are given lines you have to follow and complete a node before going to the next one (you have to complete the boss of each map to get to the next one). The biggest pain in the butt with this is the map has random scenery that blocks the view not allowing you to see some paths. Also they block off paths with dumb hints on how to unlock them (like one of them that I looked up online is Fengjian Village Klue the clue they give you is "Klue: ESDORYT TEH DWLOR" Solution: Destroy The World Solve: Use Cyrax Kameo finisher Annihilation to win the fight). One annoying thing is there are areas on the map that require an item to unlock which apparently you get the item after getting to the end of the seasonal mission (have to beat the final boss then go back through every mission again to fight more difficult versions of the characters you have been fighting the entire time in order to get the last bits of loot).

On gameplay the kameos are dumb. Basically 15 characters that you just call in to do an attack, counter/block an attack or they have their own fatalities. You cannot play as any of them but only 3 of them are different versions of playable characters (Sub-Zero, Scorpion and Kung Lao). Hopefully one day we will get the rest in game as actual playable characters but who knows. Also in combat there are dumb things like when an enemy glows white they're invulnerable and when they're blue they take more damage. The issue with this is they somehow spam the glow white attacks/abilities to then make it that you're fighting a tank which is frustrating/annoying to say the least. Also they have a lethal attack or whatever where whenever an enemy or you get low on health you can do a lethal attack which obliterates the victim's health bar if it hits. The issue with this is when the enemy ai do it it's completely random, annoyingly hard to block and takes out about/over half your health.

On character design I think the only really bad one was Tanya. She went from straight hair with white eyes in every other game to now a weird haircut and regular eyes. They did make several of the female characters uglier than their designs from previous games (like Tanya and Li Mei).

Also it seems like they're just using the same few outfits over and over again. Like last season they had them in more fire based colors/effects and now they are more blood colors/effects. But most characters have like 3 outfits the starting one, another one which I don't remember when/where you get and the final cool one which you can get early through invasions or I believe you get it through leveling up the character. From what I can tell really cool/interesting outfits are stuck in the premium store (some outfits with cool effects or old outfits... not sure how many there are since I have only seen 3 and they have a stupid rotating store aka you see one outfit for some amount of time then it's gone until it rotates back in).



Biggest issue is this game needs to be online and connected to servers for a majority of the content.... so I started changing/writing this when I lost connection in the middle of an invasion. What happened was I went into my "inventory" to change my Kameo back to a character I was working on or something and now i get "There was an error contacting the Mortal Kombat TM  1 Server. If you exit now you will lose any unsaved changes. Do you still wish to exit?" When I started playing this also seemed to be an issue which diudn't allow me to enter Invasions or go to their stupid Shrine. The Shrine is also annoying because it's where you spend Koins to get random loot (images, music and cosmetics for characters). It's annoying because you can only buy 1 at a time and have to watch a dumb animation every time. Last time I used it I had like 15,000 Koins.... it costs 1,000 koins to buy something and I had to sit there for several minutes watching the same animation 15 times. Also going off of the watching stuff every time I wish could skip the short cutscene after every fight where it's just your character doing the same thing every time.

I am sadly one of the saps that were hopeful and foolish enough to buy this product for "Early Access" and ultimately regretted it. At "Early" launch, the game was unbearable and almost unplayable. Took around a month to receive an update to fix the issues but also not fix them cause they are still present now in some fashions. Be it random crashes, poor connections in supposedly "good" connection lobbies, move list being incomplete or missing details or wrong information provided, the Player 1 and 2 hitbox/HurtBox bug (Giving Player 1 the advantage), Invasions Crashing, Stages crashing (Mainly Tea House Day Time and Tarkoton Colonie maps), Missing subtitles, Story mode bugs and crashes. Hot mess at launch, after a month a lot of improvements but a lot of damage was already done and in addition with the improvements brought more problems. Still crashes randomly, still missing information, connection issues, list goes on.
Aside from the buggy release and still buggy presence, we now reach the other problems with the game, False Advertisement's, Overpriced DLC's, Overpriced Micro-transactions for In-Game items, Overpriced event/seasonal themed game play items (Halloween Fatality's and ect. as of current), Invasions Mode being awful to play, Invasions Mode holding players hostage to unlock seasonal event cosmetics through absurd EXP grinding to progress through the game mode, still missing or misleading information in game be it in the move list or other areas of the game, misleading information and advertisement of the game itself (Worse for the Nintendo Switch Player's with what they had to deal with).
This is after just the first big update, where are we at after today's big update on 11/15/2023? Not much improvement aside from more poor balancing tactics and finally almost 2 months or basically 2 months they corrected more move list information. Otherwise they still haven't addressed or done anything about the across the board general EXP problems, and they made exp worse in Invasions Mode for Invasions EXP hence why it feels like I am taken hostage when wanting to unlock stuff in the game. I as a casual player feel taken hostage and advantage of when it comes to the Invasions Mode as it is enforcing even more of my time with a mode that's filled with nothing but un-fun, annoying game play gimmicks, enforcing me to grind money, grind exp, this game has more grinding than some JRPG's I have played in the past year but at least with a RPG/JRPG at least the grind is rewarding and depending on said grind can be fun. Invasions is what a lot of this game circles around for its content and player expected game time to go and it is miserable, if I could get every penny back I have spent on the game and within, I would but unfortunately can't.
My recommendation, avoid this game entirely OR if you really want it, wait till its like 50% off or more on everything as nothing involving this game is worth it's price, or earned it's price. $70 USD for mediocre at best game, $110 USD for a mediocre game and a season pass, $40 USD for a Season Pass where nearly half it's content clearly was supposed to be in the base game but was made dlc instead, $8 USD for a character who should of been base game (especially since you play as him during the story mode) and a character is not worth 8 bucks on its own, $8 USD to unlock an existing character in the game to avoid playing the story mode, and another 20$ USD to unlock the 5 locked Cameo characters. Lastly another $5 USD for some in-game currency and a couple recolors themed around Season 1's Invasions theme and is a 1 time application.

I hate doing this with a franchise, and a game, that I love. The game is fun. It is fast paced and it is challenging. I was hyped and hopeful for the first month about what was to come. In the second month, I became tentative and nervous. Now I find myself disheartened. They are selling a premium priced game that has all the micro-transactions of a FTP game. And it is going to get worse. The CEO of WB has stated they want more money for everything. He didn't hint about it, he didn't use some mixed message coding in his speech - he straight out said that they want more money for everything they add to the game. They are selling fatalities now! The hallmark - the trademark of MK is up for sale - $10 for a "holiday" fatality. It's a sad day when I have to leave a negative review on MK - I grew up playing the very first one in the arcade, and now it seems they killed it with the appropriately named MK1. It started at one and it has now ended at one as well. 
I cannot recommend anyone buy this game nor any other WB property going forward since they have said this is the direction they want to go with all of their major titles - MK, DC, Harry Potter and Game of Thrones. If they make them FTP and then have content that is purchased, that's fine, but don't charge me $70 and then charge me $10 for new announcer, $10 for an new skin and $10 for another fatality!!!
Overpriced!

The good:
Core gameplay is smooth and fun, probably the best of the NRS era

The bad:
Outrageously predatory macrotransactions. A full priced game where any decent new content is gated behind $10+ dollar purchases. They only release recolored palettes for free in updates, anything thats a new skin (and they purposely withheld decent skins for this and launched mediocre base skins on many characters) is $10 for a single character.

This cannot be tolerated. Unless they make dragon kyrstals a resource you can obtain via gameplay that doesn't have a cap, it's unacceptable to gate any decent new content in a game that released with hardly any content behind large additional cash purchases. A typical new skin is 1000 krystals. In the game you can earn 500 for beating campaign the first time (easiest path), which is now half a skin. Then if you get your profile level up to 100 (lets say about 60-100 hours of gameplay) you get 600 more. All that gets you one skin. The remaining finite krystals you can earn is 200 per launch roster character, which there are 23 of (they also lied in a pregame video that there would be 24). So that's 4600, but to get those is an immeasurable grind, likely several hundred hours of specific grinding. In the end all that will net you 5,700 krystals and you will never earn anymore. They're already released more skins than you could buy with that. Skins used to come with Kombat Packs or be sold in sets of multiples for $5 and be infinitely earnable through gameplay grind.

I pre-ordered the game because I've always had a good experience with the prior Mortal Kombat entries, but this release has changed my mind.

This is somewhat hard to judge objectively but I am very certain that the game has problems interpreting the inputs. Combo execution seem very inconsistent too me. 

With the keyboard, it is almost impossible to do ex moves. I eventually changed to a gamepad, and with it, the ex moves work fine. However, the directional inputs are way more imprecise, e.g. doing diagonal jumps without moving in a direction first is very difficult.

Mortal Kombat 1 in sostanza non sarebbe un brutto gioco, il gameplay è il solito, i kameo sono la novità del momento, sono una buona aggiunta ma sarebbe stato meglio un tag team come in MK9. La più grande pecca di questo gioco è il Live Service dietro di esso, una volta finita l'invasione sostanzialmente c'è poco da fare e le torri nella Mesa dei portali non sono per niente soddisfacenti quando vengono completate. Il problema più grande di tutti sono i prezzi assurdi nel premium shop le skin non vengono più date come ricompense praticamente, ma sono bloccate dietro pagamento, le skin che si possono ottenere sono solo palette diverse di skin già esistenti da inizio gioco. WB ha chiaramente spinto per far si che il gioco uscisse prima del previsto, NRS credo l'avrebbe fatto uscire verso primavera come accaduto in precedenza; ciliegina sulla torta mi ripeto sono tutti i prezzi assurdi per skin e fatality.

The single-player journey has been expanded, revealing more of the intricate web that binds us in this eternal battle. The story mode is a cinematic odyssey that explores the depths of our struggles and rivalries, adding layers to the Mortal Kombat lore that even Raiden couldn't have foreseen.

The gameplay, my brethren, is a sublime dance of combat. The controls respond with the precision required to execute a flawless victory, and the combos flow like the fires of the Netherrealm. The essence of Mortal Kombat is preserved, and yet, new mechanics breathe fresh fire into the fray, creating a scorching experience for players old and new.

Online multiplayer, my allies, is where the true test of strength lies. Engage in battles across realms with warriors from every corner of Earthrealm and beyond. The netcode ensures a seamless experience, allowing you to 'Get Over Here!' and face opponents as if they were standing right in front of you.

Visual is a masterpiece that brings each fighter to life with an intensity that would make even the Netherrealm shudder. The details in my iconic spear toss and Sub-Zero's chilling maneuvers are so vivid, it's like watching our battles play out in a realm beyond the realms. The arenas are more dynamic than ever, and the flames of our eternal rivalry have never burned brighter.

For those who have been with me since the beginning and for those stepping into the arena for the first time, this game is a scorching testament to the legacy of Mortal Kombat. 'Finish Him!'—or her—because this is a kombat experience not to be missed!

This is a cash-grabby game at a premium price. Keep in mind I have the Kombat Pack AND the one time Dragon Krystal bundle. This is $70 for the BASE game with a finite resource for in game currency. the Kombat pack is $40 and all you get with them is Characters, Kameos, and ONE premiere skin. they have skins in this game that are 1,000 Dragon Krystals. That translates to $10 of real world money if you've already gone through the 6,000 Dragon Krystals in the base game which is a PAIN to grind through. As of posting, there are 5 premiere skins that all cost 1,000 DK, and two Fatalities that also cost 1,000 DK. Need I mention that the previous installment gave you skin PACKS for less? $5.99 and if you didn't have money but it could be unlocked with time Krystals, there were grindy, yet INFINITE Time Krystals. They're charging a premium price for a game they want you to pump out three times the base price just to have everything. This is not okay. I'd be fine with it if it were a free to play game BUT IT'S NOT. DON'T BUY DRAGON KRYSTALS, IT'LL ENCOURAGE WB TO CONTINUE THESE CASH-GRABBY PRACTICES!!!

Stunning graphics with a balanced and complex fighting system. What more do you really need from a Mortal Kombat game? I encountered my personal skill ceiling about halfway up the ranked ladder and that is where I am happy to stay. I believe this mindset is important to prevent getting too frustrated which is something many people tend to struggle with when playing online multiplayer. The story is goofy, entertaining and relatively short which is exactly what I expected. I found invasions mode to be good mindless fun with little to no challenge, although it can get repetitive it is good fun if you just want to relax or take a break from kompetitive. Other game modes like towers and test your might are exactly what you expect if you already have experience with the franchise. Overall this game delivered exactly what I expected and wanted.

TL;DR
You either release the game for free and have the free to play cash shop model or you sell the game for $110 and have everything in game able to be unlocked reasonably.

I cannot recommend this game for a simple reason. NRS is charging $70 for this game. $110 for those of us who bought the premium edition. This is a AAA Title being sold at the new inflated full price. Despite that they've gutted the game of content and are selling that back to you piecemeal through a cash shop at premium prices. Tired of uninspired palette swaps for scorpion? Well spend $10 on this single skin where he actually looks different. Want an extra fatality? $12 dollars. If you bought a single skin at that price for every character you'd spend more than twice the cost of the game for a drop in the bucket's worth of content that MK11 would have had for free.

This game is predatory and it shouldn't be accepted. The original MK is the game that got me into gaming and it's such a shame to see it devolve into a disgusting example of the problem with the gaming industry of today. The foundation of this game is solid but everything else around it is lackluster because they pulled nearly everything worth getting from the game and slapped it into the cash shop. This is why they got rid of the kypt. Why spend koins to unlock content when you can spend cash. 

NRS, you should be ashamed. Ed Boon, we expected and deserved better.

i want to be able to recommend the game. it is fun and it has potential, but i will not.

Y’all… I had a proper review going with some laudatory wordsmithing. Something clever. Something fun to read. I wanted to highlight what I thought were some legitimate strengths and weaknesses of this game. I had a lot to say, and I was taking a large chunk of my own time to say it right.

Then they dropped a ten-dollar fatality and my 25+ year MK veteran ass said “Why bother? Why waste the time?” I’m so tired my brothers and sisters. I’m so done. Ultra condensed version of the review coming your way.

I kinda love this game. I love the lore. I loved the story. It was better than most. I didn’t mind most of the changes. It was more fun than not. As a fan, I was very pleased.  I genuinely geeked out on the last chapter and played it over an over. 

I don’t play online. I’m that guy. I know that’s a decent chunk of the game, and I know I’m paying money to not use that feature. I’m fine with that. I look forward to the other things that give the game it’s replay value.

In MK1, those other things are the Invasion Mode. And that Invasion Mode was built at the intersection of janky and broken. (I swear, I spent no extra time on that quip. It just came off the top of my head. That one’s free. Unlike most content in this game.) It’s passable. I play it. It’s still broken. It’s repetitive and things just don’t work. The last season’s tower had you grinding for an hour then getting nothing for your effort because you lost a Test Your Might at the top. Insulting and time wasting. This season is a new flavor of broken. Still. It’s passable and fixable.

There's no Crypt at all. Just some boring ass shrine grinding out pallet swaps and concept art. Another victim of the monetization.

And the monetization has gotten absolutely disgusting. I never wanted to be the guy that critiques a game on the company’s business practices rather than the game itself. But here we are. I can’t defend or ignore it anymore. I let “pay for EZ Fatalities” slide on X because I really didn’t care if people with more dollars than sense wanted to buy them. I didn’t mind DLC through MK11 because I thought it was reasonably priced for what genuinely felt like extra content.

But 40 dollars for six characters? Two of which are in the story mode? And we’re gonna act like 5 Kameo characters make that worth it? I’m pretty sure the entire Aftermath DLC was cheaper than that. It was definitely larger on content. Maybe MK11s Kombat Packs cost that much. I don’t remember. But it feels jarring this time.

And that 10-dollar Halloween themed fatality? No. Walk it back all you want, I’m done. People who want to defend it, do it on your own time, because mine is worth more than WB thinks it is. I legitimately like this game and I still wish I hadn’t bought it. I had to go into a media blackout bubble for weeks leading up to the release because of all the advanced copies they gave out and all the streams that already had the entire story mode and every Fatality, Brutality, and voice line on display. Little did I realize those streamers were doing me a favor. 

Next time I’m gonna do what I should have done this time. Watch the spoilers and skip the game, and the grind, until it reaches the 75% off mark a couple years later. There are so many more rewarding gaming experiences out there than this right now and my fandom is no longer enough to pull me through.

[h1] A Decent Game. Disappointing PC Port. [/h1]

[h3] The Great! [/h3]
The gameplay of this game is absolutely a huge step up compared to 11's, it's fairly fast but not to the extreme of 10's, combo potential has excelled much more than 11's with how limiting it felt, the removal of Krushing Blows fixes the odd pacing from it's previous installment. Variations are now removed as the base roster of characters come COMPLETE with their whole moveset now, instead of picking & choosing what specific special moves you want present.The Kameo system, while skeptical at first before release, ended up being IMO, a welcoming new system that helps with creativity and fun fighter comp's for your playstyle. 
The current base roster is great with plenty of OG characters as well as welcoming a handful from the 3D era of games (Deadly Alliance/Deception/Armageddon) which does excellent in their redesigns & gameplay approach. 

[h3] The Downsides. [/h3]
The story wasn't exceedingly groundbreaking and revolutionary as per usual of the MK games usually go with their storytelling, being pretty mediocre like usual, and fell ESPECIALLY flat come near the middle and onto the ending chapters. What coherence is sort of had in the beginning would come to crumble into the overused trope of 'multiverses' that honestly lost my interest very fast. Single player content is... Okay for what it is. It's honestly rather lackluster. Invasions is a cool concept at first until you get to the point of late fights are just loaded modifiers galore which honestly... Makes it not fun. The lack of a map for each mesa makes it a slog to traverse through as you backtrack back & forth between areas you've yet to explore. (The 30FPS lock makes it even more gross...). There's really no challenge but instead just plain annoyance of how the fights perform where you have back to back ridiculousness of absurdity the modifiers will bring to each fight that just makes it a complete chore to play rather than a interesting challenge. Instead of just boosting the enemy NPC's difficulty as you progress further, their "playstyles" will remain the exact same by doing like, 2/3 of their basic string, sit and eat your moves, and just will play like dunces in the fights, as most of the damage taken are strictly from the random modifiers occurring all over the place anyways. It's bad and most of the time, just really gross to look at as your screen is plastered in random special effects going on. It's honestly kind of lazy... Invasion's also a strictly Online only thing too, so if the servers are down and you are wanting to just casually do those for leveling & unlocks... Tough, as you need to be online for this anyways.

The Kustomization is a little limiting compared to 11's with a few steps back. The process of unlocking the skins you'd want is also rather tedious & boring, as you're either grinding high amount of hours upping each mastery level per character for the rewards locked behind the mastery rewards, or gambling your Koins in the awfully slow Shrine system (More info below about that...) or the Season Specific Skins that will be available each season using the specific Kurrency for that season which you can obtain via multiplayer or Invasions.

The shrine, another method to unlocking stuff (mostly boring and uninteresting stuff such as Music, Artwork, stage art, etc.) that's usually unobtainable via character mastery leveling or Invasions, the system that's made to redeem your Koins is rather timewasting and tedious, as you're only able to redeem 1,000 Koins at a time in this shrine. Mind you, for each time you redeem those 1,000 Koins, you HAVE to sit through the disintegration animation of your Koins being melted down for like, 10 seconds to see what reward (Mostly something boring...) you've obtained. Why can't we just redeem all our Koins at once? I have 21,000 Koins... Let me put in 21,000 Koins, redeem, present me 21 rewards... It's a small nitpick but still something to point out considering how time wasting & grueling it is to just sit and see one reward pop up at a time, when I truly want to play the meat & bones of the game a little more.

[h3] The Actual Bad. [/h3]
The biggest things that are preventing me overall from giving it a positive review is the PC port for this game is not that great. MK11 had almost the same issues upon it's own release; Locked 30 FPS in certain areas aside from gameplay itself, stuttering issues, graphical issues, insane useage of your VRAM in random Tower Fights, especially ones with Endurance Mode that would just randomly crash your game (It crashes in other areas too like its own Main Menu...), It just somehow... Looks worse than it's console released ports. (We don't include Nintendo Switch's port.)
The team responsible for the PC port had plenty to learn from their MK11 release on PC and after a few patches over time... It's actually very well now as is today! FPS/Graphics look great, no random crashes, freezing, stuttering, it's actually... Great. If only this could be said about MK1, and actually be steps ahead on release. Unfortunately it'll look to be something that's going to be tweaked over time to wait for once again.

[h3] The Verdict? [/h3]
If you were to ignore the lackluster singleplayer content aside from the passable but not very great story mode, MK1 I can say is a pretty great game compared to the last installment, with the noticeable improvements coming to it's CORE gameplay overall. It brings a fine base roster and the additional interesting twist of Kameo fighter assists that makes the game more dynamic to creating fun & crazy fighter pairs. 

However, I honestly would hold off from obtaining this until the patches actually fix the game's functionality on PC. It's really great, fun, exciting, but the PC Port is just absolutely disappointing once again and has shown room for improvement. Perhaps a little sale will come by along with the game's fixes that would justify your purchase for this actually good game that's unfortunately plagued behind a unoptimized mess the PC version is.

I love and hate MK1 at the same time.
LOVE - MK1 makes me feel like playing MK9 for the first time again. Two thing stands out most in MK1. Gameplay and stages. The STAGES! MK1 has the most beautiful, colorful and background reactive stages of all fighting games. The stages here are even prettier than SF6. The GAMEPLAY! Love that every character plays significantly different and the variety of combat styles. CAMEO system also adds infinite possibility to game play.
HATE - I absolutely hate the GRIND system, locking game play features behind the awful character leveling system. The new invasion initially feels fun but gets old after 2 hours. From then on it felt more like a chore to get skins and colors. I just want a simple fighting game like MK9 that I can spend my time in practice mode rather than doing uppercut a million time to get skins, gear, brutality and taunts.

UPDATE: So one season of grind is NOT enough for them, they decided to implement a second season of even worse grindess, with reduced Kredits gain. Absolutely hate this repetitive invasion mode. I gave up. NOT going to touch this tedious grind fest. Oh and did I forget to say they are selling $10 skins and fatalities? So anti-customer.

I will preface this by saying I enjoy mk1 however I do not believe it to be worth the $70 price tag. It's lacking of basic fundamental qol features in a modern day fighting game alone speaks in regard to that. There are plenty of reasons that while having solid and rewarding gameplay this game fails at being a triple A fighting game experience. I'll go over the pros and cons.
Pros:
 -Solid gameplay foundation with exciting pressure sequences, fun and unique setup opportunities, cool combos, and overall great design in the visual aspect as well. 
-The game is gorgeous with stunning stages and absolutely amazing character renders that trump even mk11's graphics. 
-Mk1's story is an overall improvement in writing quality compared to mk11 and is the same fun we have come to expect from NRS story campaigns. 
- The new/returning characters are all welcome additions that add a lot of fresh faces to the mix
- The kameo system is robust and fluid allowing for creative gameplay for a variety of different characters. A character can be impacted by a single kameo in similar ways that they would differ in variations (ofc this depends on the kameo/character synergy)
-character taunts are a major improvement and many have fun unique ones
-fatalities are absolutely gorgeous in this game and pound for pound are an improvement over mk11's fatalities
-Brutalities, while still not as good as mkx, are better implemented in mk1 than mk11 with many characters having organic brutalities you can easily fit at the end of combos for cool finishes as well as challenge brutalities that require more setup. 
Cons:
-The netcode of this game is not good. It is rollback netcode however it is more comparative in quality to sf5's original "rollback" rather than say mk11's rollback. This was worsened by the recent omniman patch,
-The gear system in general has taken a huge step back in this game. The gear system has been relegated to a singular piece of gear that can either significantly alter your character's look (havik helmet) or make a change that is hardly noticeable in moment to moment gameplay (geras chest piece). 
-The collection system in mk1 has also taken a step back from mk11. There are no more towers and there is no more krypt. The Krypt has been replaced by a gamemode called invasions which is a glorified challenge tower stretched into several board game styled maps. The maps themselves do offer variety in terms of looks and approach  as well as secrets obtainable. However these positives apply to the krypt as well so as a replacement it does not improve on what was already established in my eyes. 
-The training mode.
-Character interactions and presentation have taken a step back. What I mean by this is the presentation and interaction of characters in this game has been stripped. Intro dialogue has been relegated to one phrase for each character as well as being separated from the characters respective intro animation (characters will talk shit to each other and then walk in all cool instead of doing it at the same time.) Round end taunts also are a little worse. while animations for round end taunts are still fantastic I find that there's a lot less dialogue for the characters between rounds with most resorting to grunts, laughs, war cries, or simply silence. 
-Premium currency in a $70 fighting game title. It began with SF6 and it's continued into mk1. It's one thing to have skin packs for characters however it's another to introduce a premium currency with a rotating shop that's overpriced. (Halloween fatality looking at you) 

Mk1 is a great gameplay foundation with a lot of hanging qol, netcode, and gear issues. The good news is many of these can be fixed with updates adding new gear, netcode fixes, training revamp, and general qol improvements to ui and other aspects. However in it's current state I would not recommend mk1 for it's $70 price tag and would suggest waiting for a sale or at least a patch to fix the current performance issues plaguing the game since the omni-man update.

I am a lifelong MK fan and love everything MK. Not just the lore or the mechanics but the whole package. I dig the concept and was heavily invested in this new timeline story as it unfolded over 4 games. I don't want to seem overtly negative but here are the main bullet points you need to know:

-Cosmetics are limited and you grind to get everything in game modes that aren't really interesting or fun. 
-The Story mode is disappointing but looks great. 
-The Kameo system is great if you are a competetive fighting game player who knows how to use them. For us noobs, they are likely not good. 
-The air combat is sweet but tricky to master. 
-The combat feels clunky for the most part. Only a few characters did I find a way to string combos with. In all other games 
 I was able to learn the strings without watching videos  or grinding practice mode.

Oh Boy, where to begin...

Negatives:
- False marketing: We were promised a Johnny Cage Kameo but aparently that got scrapped and we end up getting a female version. Crossplay was featured on the steampage but got removed last minute, so basically people got scammed.

- Kombat Kast: an opportunity to promote their game but there's no interraction with the audience and there isn't even a Q&A. They seem to neglect addressing a lot of issues. All they care about is selling their product, with other words it is a waste of time because it doesn't give anything back to the consumer when it comes to providing us with answers, info etc.

- Ed Boon tweeting a post on Twitter claiming that they are working on these features below (which should have been in the game by default according to nowadays standards)
     - Crossplay
     - Wifi Filter
     - Ping filter
     - FT3 now changed to FT2 

The FT2 feature was one of the least desired features according to this poll but we end up receiving this anyway, goes to show that NRS and WB don't listen to their audience (why bother asking your audience if you are going to neglect our opinion anyway?)
It is more likely that PC version of the game wont get crossplay yet AGAIN.

- Lack of music that set the dark tone that for example mk4 had.

- I feel more terrified playing mk 1-4, the tone was set, you knew it was a battle to the death but now I start yawning and I feel i'm punching rubber bags because there's no blood splatting like there used to be.

- They take feedback from casual players (who will give up on this game after a few months) and add those changes to the game.


Positives:
- Better roster than MK11 (it's not a big of an accomplishment because anything else besides that roster would have been an improvement regardless)
- Longer combos that don't consists just out of 2-4 hits and a special.
- You don't need a brain to play this game and it's accessable for anyone to play.

Its like mk but with no content

The Good and the Bad: 

Good: 
- Gameplay is very fun and satisfying in general terms.
- No more boring standardized wake-ups 
- Flawless Block mechanic improved and makes more sense
- The graphics are stunning
- The roster is refreshing and will likely have many many more awesome characters
- DLC content seems really sick so far
- Kameo system brings a refreshing level of depth to the game
- Characters are no longer boring and limited like in MK11
- Story mode is of significantly higher quality in terms of writing and direction
- You will always discover something new in this game in terms of combos and tech
- Shrine has a diverse variety of cosmetics and generally the cosmetics are very appealing

Bad: 
- Warner Bros is one of the greediest publishers ever
- Micro-transactions for a 90$ game (that are also extremely expensive)
- Skin Packs are no longer free
- Balance is (understandably) kind of wacky 
- The player-base all have severe anger issues and are generally unskilled
- Premium currency in a fully-priced game is annoying
- You cannot farm premium currency like in MK11
- Lack of content diversity (as of writing this review at least) 
- There is no cross-play yet (especially bad for a new game)
- Micro-transactions do not fund game events like in previous MK titles

Overall: 
The game is fun. If you enjoy fighting games and Mortal Kombat games, this game is for you. The story mode and online multiplayer are fun, even with no crossplay. Seeing as this game is still in its infancy, I don't think it is fair to immediately label it as bad or good, but the gameplay - which is the most important part - is very good. I do not regret paying the full amount so far, but the micro-transactions are the most infuriating part of this game. If those get sorted out (which honestly would mean getting rid of Warner Bros.) then the game will be truly amazing. Overall if you are not someone who is concerned particularly about cosmetics, this game is really fun and enjoyable - even when you encounter a very toxic player. 

I cannot *strongly* recommend the game, but I do for sure recommend it and find it more enjoyable than MK11. GLHF!

But fucking hell, EVERYTHING I try to do takes forever to load, everything. midfight can freeze for a second, throwing off combos, even waiting for the main menu to load in takes fucking forever. I have yet to really have any enjoyment, I held off on a review, because rocky launches can happen, I am fine with it, but my pc is fine on the requirements but still this game struggles to even pull up the basic shrine to spend my gold.

The combat system is fine to me, and when I get matches that run smooth enough, I can somewhat enjoy it, even if everything feels like it is downgraded gore wise.
Even the story is barely logical.
"Oh hey, this character is stabbed through the stomach, don't worry they are your backup in the fight, even if the next cutscene will show they are barely alive on the fucking ground."

This may be the second biggest disappointment from buying a game in preorder, only one that topped it was Babylon's Fall, since it was shut down in less than a year, but even that game offered enjoyment for me compared to this.

there is nothing here that makes me want to stay, all I can do is hope Tekken 8 isn't as big of a disappointment. I hope they fix the game up properly for everyone who still has issues, but after 50 hours, I am uninstalling and forgetting this ever existed.

Bought the game and then the kombat pack... why do you still want me to pay for costumes and voices.  $120 is still not enough to get a premium experience. Also making kombat league from set of 3 wins to set of 2 wins is kin d of an iffy move in general, but the inconsistent and shoddy netcode and filtering makes this a bad idea to me.

As a long time fan of the franchise since MK was released on the SNES I couldn't wait for MK1. unfortunately like every game nowadays, the optimization of the game wasn't that great. It was playable for me. But they should have waited a few months with the release so they could fix the issues. 

Even though I liked the story mode in the game, it's still a big disappointment to me when comparing MK1 with MK11. Also WB got greedy by asking €40,- for a ****ing DLC pack on a €70,- game, which includes just 6 characters and 2 of them are already in the storymode. No way I'm buying th DLC for that price. The game alone wasn't even worth buying it for €70,- for the state it was released.

I really wanted to like MK1 and it breaks my heart to write a negative review about MK. I think WB just got to greedy. My advice, skip this one and just play MK11 or wait a few years untill the game is cheaper or on sale. And I hope the devs will learn from this mistake for the next MK game.

This is the only MK I have played since 9 that has kept my attention. I'm a casual player, nothing more, but the kombat and the kommunity is so much fun to fuck around with online that I cannot resist playing kombat league. 

My biggest issue is the lack of... anything really. I unlocked everything in the shrine a week into the game, got all the seasonal items in less than a month, and have been awaiting to be drip fed content from a near non existent dev. This sucks, because what I played made me fall in love with MK again. Maybe it isn't NRS, maybe its WB, idk, but because of that I can't recommend anyone buy this for 70 USD, or in my case 110 USD in the games current state. If you're a hardcore fan and don't mind the drip, go right ahead.

If you're even a bit skeptical or unsure, hold off until NRS communicates better.

Pro's of MK 1

- beat everyone to a pulp
- new Kombo's and easy Brutality's 
- Kameo Kombat is a fun new twist on the mk9 team fights
- Invasions is good and it works in  seasons wich is something to look forward too every season
- Wel written story with amazing quality transmission form to kombat cinematic looks exactly the same wich is amazing
- fun with friends a hard learning curve online because some characters feel incomplete (see cons)
- Towers never dissapoints and keeps being tough on very hard ( CPU has amazing combo's)


Cons

- Short story mode, normally this would not be so bad but with only invasions and towers left, it feels like it could have had something extra.
- No Krypt (known beforehand it stil dissapoints)
- No friendship? or Babality? (thus far known)
Some characters have diffrent moveset's than before like scorpion, he misses his fire kick combo, as that i have tried every combo and special move with him this move is gone, wich would be okay if in invasions this seasons end boss, DOES have the move.
this kinda sucked from my PoV feeling like i had a lesser scorpion. (for new players probably not that big of a deal?)
- Characters like Ermac, Quan chi should already be implemented in the roster because they are in story mode ( they wil be DLC)
game just misses extra content, wich wil come in DLC form sadly as i have kombat pack 1 because of the great line up of chars. but henceforward it wil take sometime till they drop, first up is OMNI man wich is a pro

STOP PAYING TO BE BETA TESTERS. This is a fun game, no doubt. This is also an unfinished, unpolished game. The technical errors this game suffer from at this point in no way make this a truly fair competitive game, which is what this should be. I can already see invasion mode being the equivalent of a season pass, following the trend of many of other games to microtransaction your ass as frequently as it lines up with the parent companies quarterly reviews. Look at street fighter 6 and its's game model now. Watch your fav Streamers, pick up the base game when it goes on sale a month after release but PLEASE do not buy any preorders or engage in seasonal cosmetic microtransaction sprees. This game already displays a large amount of what I would consider to be Time trap sales practices. Finishing how I started. I'll start by saying that this game is very good, gameplay wise. It's got one of the best rosters and characters, with every single one of them being very unique and feeling very fun to play. I've never wanted to play so many different characters in an MK game before. The new kameo system is also a lot more fun than i originally thought. The story mode is also great, better than the MKX and MK11 ones.
I also play this game actively, and will continue to do so for a while.

But this game's launch has probably been NRS' weakest one. The blatant lack of content is very noticeable, and the single-player content is lacking severely. The new 'Invasions' mode is not fun at all, it's very tedious and gets old very fast. The downgrade in customization from MK11 is also ridiculous. We went from about 3-4 default skins and 3 gear slots, to about 2-3 and 1 gear slot for every character. Most of the cosmetics are obtained in either the Shrine (which is very lacking) and the Story mode. 

Then there's the sheer amount of corporate greed that is unmissable. Every MK1 player saw the disaster that was the ''Halloween Fatality''. A cutscene which they sold for 1200 ''Dragon Krystals'' which amounts to about 12 euros or 13 dollars. An insane microtransaction in an already expensive game. Then there's the fact that they said that the Jaune Claude van Damme skin would be exclusive to people who bought the Premium Edition. It then proceeds to show up in the Premium Shop, for Dragon Krystals. They lied. 

I can't give this product a positive review at this point in time. This game has so much potential, but it's getting buried by it's developers.

Yes, it is my favorite game next Mortal Kombat X.
Yes, i love it a lot, it's superior to MK11 and it rights a lot of wrongs that game had.
HOWEVER! Check the game details box on the store page, what does it say at the bottom? Ah yes, "Denuvo".
If you're one of those people with performance issues, there's your reason. I'll maybe consider changing my review to a positive one once they remove that piece of sh!t from the game because as it stands, my PC is between the specs on minimum and recommended, yet it runs like @ss even WITH upscaling and the likes.

EDIT

So i went ahead and played some more, because at its core, the game is alright and can be fun. I also upgraded my computer slightly in the process and it runs ... ehh ... decently, it still chugs along here and there. Why am i adding an edit to an already negative review? Well, while the chaps i play with were offline, i meddled with offline offerings from the game ( Which are amazingly scarce for a game at this price ). So i finished the basic tutorials around week 1 of pre-launch when i got the game, and today i decided to do some combo challenges for the characters i play frequently ... and i reached Sub-Zero ... and he has an EX Ice Clone combo ... but wait, his EX Ice clone is glitched! HURRAY! Good job NRS! I knew of the ice clone issues but i didn't know that one of the combo challenges uses a glitched move. Which by the waaaaaaaaaaaaaaay, the combo challenges are the most awkwardly imagined combo scenarios i ever seen ... while creative ... they are purposefully made difficult for no reason, not to mention plenty of which are unoptimal for PvP. Load times are a bit long for me, but that's a small price to pay to play what is, in my opinion, the best feeling Mortal Kombat game to date, at least in the Netherrealm era. It's on par if not better than MKX, definitely better than MK9, and MILES better than MK11. It feels fast paced without feeling overwhelming, the tutorial does a fantastic job teaching you EVERY minute mechanic and for the first time in MK history (i believe, though i could be wrong) Kombo Challenges for each character! My only gripe is that Havik is locked by story mode, which is fine normally, but charging to unlock him immediately feels a bit bad to me. I understand wanting to have the character immediately unlocked even on a fresh save for tournament reasons, but it just leaves a bad taste in my mouth. The Kameo system gives the game a fresh feel from every other game in the franchise.

also it has my 3 favorite characters in some capacity and my most favorite character is the playable one leggo (rain, shujinko, and soon tremor)

A worthy Mortal Kombat game, is the best way to describe this game. THIS is what a AAA game looks like. 

YOU HEAR THAT BETHESDA?!?!? 

Netherrealm Studios has put together some great games in the past and this game raised the bar again. The story is innovative, and a clever way of using the multiverse/timeline trope to do some creative things with character designs. The game is nearly 30 years old, and has tons of backstory that no longer matters, but in a good way. The new character designs are fantastic, the move-sets are both familiar and innovative, and there is so much content that you would not feel cheated even paying full price. 

YOU HEAR THAT BETHESDA?!?!? 

The game is fun. The true "King of Fighters" is back. And in a BIG way.
Its fun

Single player content is kinda bad. The story mode is fine, the same kind of fare from the last 3 games. The Invasion mode is incredibly dull, grindy, and uninteresting. It is essentially a board game leading to fights with different gimmicks or modifiers, but these are either completely ineffective or so disruptive they ruin the game.  Navigation on the board is tedious and lacks any real map or zoom out feature to make navigation reasonable.

Actual gameplay vs other players has high highs, but low lows. Balance is all over the place between characters AND assists, and there are still various bugs in place since launch and even new ones introduced in an emergency balance patch with no acknowledgement from the devs as to what they plan to fix, if anything at all. But if you can find someone you like to play that isn't a dumpster-tier non functioning mess you can manage to have some fun. 

Don't buy this for full price, wait until next year when they inevitably release an updated version that actually functions like a full video game instead of a glorified beta test for a premium item store.

A true minimalist's Mortal Kombat.  Removes a lot of unnecessary fluff from previous MK games, such as environmental strikes, X-ray attacks, character move variations,  several different forms of currency, and a slow grinding Krypt.  In it's place are essential game modes, sparse customization, and an easy to understand method for unlocking items.  

The true star of the show is the combat itself.  Never has a Mortal Kombat game felt so smooth, creative, fluid, and action packed.  Movement and reflexes never felt as important as they do now, and combat does not feel nearly as stiff as MK11.  Mortal Kombat can finally go toe-to-toe in the gameplay department with icons Tekken and Street Fighter.  I was initially skeptical of the new assist based Kameo system, but after spending time learning the system, I find it to be a genius addition to the series.  The Kameo system is much more interesting to me than bland move variations.  It leaves a lot of room for creativity, and rewards the player for experimentation and creativity.  

The roster is another major boon for MK1.  While some characters are arguably more useful than others, every character feels viable and useful.  You have a unique mix of series icons (Johnny Cage, Scorpion, Sub-Zero), returning fan favorites (Smoke, Reptile), and a few throwbacks from the 3D fighting days (Reiko, Tanya, Li Mei). The character design is brilliant, and it makes grinding for skins and experimentation a real treat.  

MK1 has the best story mode of any fighting I've played to date.  While it perhaps leaves room for innovative storytelling from games like Baldur's Gate 3, the story it tells is intriguing, entertaining, and easy to understand.  It has moments that hit you over the head with exposition, but it makes up for it with its intriguing characters, superb voice acting (save for Megan Fox's awful Nitara performance), and surprising character development.  I hope to see future MK games add more innovations for better replayability, but what is here is great!

Some things I wish were a little better are the customization being very bare-bones, online matches tending to be a little laggy, and the overpriced DLC.  The customization doesn't give you the option to have preset skins, which is a major bummer.  I would have been cool with NRS giving up 3 profiles for each customized character, but instead we have to go into Customize each time we want to change up the skin.  The online infrastructure needs work, as about 15% of my games are laggy to the point of unplayable.  A wider variety of online game modes and options wouldn't hurt either.  Lastly, $12 fatalities, $40 fighter packs, and $10 skins are bordering on disrespectful to the people who dropped $70 on their game.  If they want to charge outrageous prices, they should go free-to-play.  

Conclusion:  MK1 is the best Mortal Kombat ever released.  It addressed a lot of major gripes I have had with the series, and provides the smoothest kombat to date.  Highly recommended, worth the money, and I look forward to what they do with the game in the future.

Pros:
-Gorgeous game. The stages are amazing and the characters look fantastic. Their designs are top-notch and I really appreciate how they were able to take some previous characters such as Li Mei and Ashrah and make them look and play fantastic. 

-The fighting feels smoother to me than previous MK games- I actually enjoyed playing some characters that I despised playing as before. 

-Audio is really good. (This is for the sound effects and music, not the voice acting.)

Cons:
- story mode. This is obviously subjective to the player; there are quite a few who liked it and this review is not a knock against them enjoying it. I did not like the story- I feel that several very key elements were left out; even if this was supposed to be an opening for future games, I felt like there was a lot that was missing. While I did like the attempt and new and different directions for some characters (particularly Li Mei and Reptile), others were taken in a direction that just didn't feel right for the character even if it was an alternate timeline. Perhaps that's just my personal bias from having played since the original Mortal Kombat. 

- voices- in particular one- Megan Fox as Nitara. This felt like it was phoned in and could have used a coach or someone for vocal direction to keep the character feel consistent. I feel that for her to actually perform the character well, someone to go behind and listen to the lines and steer her in vocal directions would have been very helpful. 

- one thing that bothers me about the offline towers- no character banter. I'm not sure if they have plans to fix this or are planning on just keeping this for online. This is more of a dislike rather than anything that actually impacts the game, but it does feel like the banter set up the conflict for a match very well. 

- my biggest dislike, and ultimately the one that pushed this to a negative review: the steep price behind skins and fatalities. I've already dropped money on the base game as well as the first Kombat Pack. If it was something along the lines of a dollar per skin and fatality, maybe that would be on the upper end of what I would be willing to work with. But what basically amounts to $10-$12 for a fatality? No thank you. While I do think the idea of unlocks for characters by using them and the invasions mode are a good idea, as well as the seasonal unlocks, the price is steep for the crystals to unlock. 

 Is this a bad game? No. If you are a Mortal Kombat fan, I would feel comfortable saying that this would be a decent buy. As a casual player or if you are one who doesn't have a lot of money and not a lot of time, the monetization practices are what would push me to tell you to go play something else. And lets be clear- what is in place right now at this time isn't exactly terrible compared to some games, but it is a slippery slope for pricing and if no one says anything, it will get worse.

This game constantly has to stop in the middle of the story to load a single cutscene, it regularly stutters and lag in the middle of a decently long combo and to top it all of the game just looks unfinished with white pixels showing up on the outline of characters among other issues.

They cut out a main character just to sell him to you for an additional $10. Now they are selling a single fatality as a $10 DLC!  Outside of story mode (which is very short) there is a half-baked single player "invasion" mode that is hot garbage, and that is it besides multiplayer... I want to like this game but it feels like a rushed cash-grab.  Shameful

Let me start off by saying that MK1 has the best story mode out of the entire NetherRealm catalogue so far. A very interesting reboot of the franchise that does a lot of interesting stuff with the old characters to make them interesting. Reptile and Mileena are highlights. The ending is rushed though and probably could have been an entire game on it's own, but is serviceable I suppose.

However, outside of the story there's a lot that doesn't work for me in the new game. Kameos are a pointless addition. MKX introduced the ability to summon a fighter to perform an attack nearly 10 years ago. This isn't new. Removing things like character variations and stage interactions has further hamstrung the kombat mechanics. Kombat is the least varied in the series since MK9 (at least in 9 you had two fighters at once).

The only meaningful single player experience is the new invasions mode. Invasions aren't particularly interesting, amounting to short single round fights against the very small fighting roster with the occasional buff or debuff. A step backwards from the fun towers we had in the other games.

Finally, kustomisation and character intros/banter have been pretty much removed. Injustice 2 gave us five gear slots we could customise, MK11 had three, MK1 gives us one. The process of unlocking kosmetics is painfully tedious with several different currencies you don't know how to earn or spend. Intros and banter now only exist in multiplayer or single fight modes. Invasions for some reason do not include any character interactions.

In summary. The story is mostly great. Everything else is outdated to the point you'd probably have more fun with any other NetherRealm game from the past 15 years.

This hurts me deeply to leave this review. As someone who has been playing Mk since my Sega genesis days this is the worst time I've had playing a Mk game. For starters they have completely gave up on the PC gaming community of this game. The port is awful I currently have a high end gaming PC and this game runs terrible. Frames drop at all settings the hair texture looks like a ps2 game. Its the first game I've had any issues with so its not a my computer issue. The game stutters and freezes often too. The game was released incomplete with patches coming to console days before they came to PC. Besides the performance issues we were promised cross play this time and once again NRS didn't deliver. Match making takes several minutes to find a opponent and normally you're stuck facing the same person over and over again. At first week this game only had 15.000 active players on PC. NRS has gave up on PC and we still have to pay the same price... Invasions are super boring and dragged out the multiplayer is laggy and drops tons of frames it is impossible for me to recommend the game in the current state. We pre ordered the game and paid the premium to get the JCVD skin for it to be in the shop the next week too. Until they optimize the PC port and add cross platform this game is worth around 15 bucks for the story which is actually good if it Isn't playing at 20fps.

EDIT - After spending quite some time with the game..my opinion has not changed, infact, now they're just taking the piss with $12 fatalities...I'm done, thanks NRS/WB, you've killed my excitement for what was once one of my favourite game series with this greedy, over monetised, under developed crap...well done, flawless victory.

OG - THREE times now i've been locked out of playing a game I spent $150 dollars on because Denuvo has decided to crap the bed..STOP NORMALISING THIS MALWARE TRASH IN EVERY NEW FUCKING RELEASE.

Game's great otherwise....with the mess of framerate issues and weekly quest bugs aside. Either they did little to no testing, or they just didn't care at all about a quality PC release. Shame...Least we got premium coins and fomo skins though right?! I know I was clamouring for that.

In its current state, I wouldn't exactly toss this game a bouquet of roses and recommend it for a grand night of gaming. Let's start with the good stuff, though - the graphics? Yeah, they're snazzy. The game runs like a well-oiled machine, and the music? it's the best groove we've felt since the Deadly Alliance era.

But now, brace yourselves for the bad, and there's quite a laundry list. The single-player content, well, it's a bit of a joke. The story mode kicks off with some promise, but then it nosedives into the most absurd, asinine, recycled "writing" you'd swear was ripped straight from the newest Marvel movies. Invasion mode? it's like watching paint dry on a rainy day. Who in their right mind thought this was fun?
Online play? Prepare for a lag-fest that'll make you wish you were back in the dial-up era. And as of my writing, there are no lobbies to be found. The place is crawling with toxic players who've apparently made a pact with the devil to spam the same three characters, throw in a dash of Cyrax, and unleash long, repetitive combos that'll make your eyes roll back in your head.

In the end, it feels like NRS couldn't balance a game to save their lives. Maybe in a future patch, they'll sprinkle some magic fairy dust on this mess. Until then, might as well break out the old classics and give this one a rain check.

From a narrative perspective, I love it. The story is great. But as for everything else, theres tons that doesnt make sense to me. It feels like a step backwards from MK11, which that game already felt like a one step forward two steps back from MKX. Its EVEN slower, but, personally, i dont mind, though I know many will. Theres less personalization. Customization feels very limited compared to MK11, as well as the way intros were redone. It just feels like theres less, and for some reason, it feels like these characters are talking “blooper takes” instead of actual fighting-esk intros. It all felt more personal, more intense, but now they feel a bit too either over actiony, over cringe, or just too wholesome. The entire game feels a bit “softer” too, and i guess I should’ve expected that once Ed Boom started saying how he felt “we went too far” with Noob in MK9 leading to him being toned down for MK11. That shouldve been my red flag for things to come. Im not saying this is a bad fighting game, but, it feels like its trying to be a bit of something else, like an Injustice 3 with a fan made Mortal Kombat Mod, and honestly I wouldn’t be suprised if Injustice 3 was for all intents and purposes a reskin of this game. This game is a great fighting game in itself dont get me wrong, but its just an “okay” to “good” mortal kombat game.

[b] An amazing showcase of big lack of content. [/b]

It is not a bad game by itself, but it doesn't have too much to offer. It's very dissapointing, even if it isn't compared to the previous game.
Mortal Kombat 11 will bring you lots of hours of fights and challenges. This game just doesn't, and EVEN THEN they dare to cut content so you have to buy if you want to, for instance, perform another finisher.

The funny part is despite the game shows you only one finisher on the movements list, you can still perform the other ones. It's not even necessary to spend money that "dlc": the only thing you're purchasing is their appeareance on the list, but if you try one of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3035597325] these [/url] you will be entirely capable of perform them.

In spite of that, the game is not bad. It's good, but is has too little to offer.
Towers are boring.
Kameo fighters are a thing but I'd personally rather use them for actual fights.
Optimization is unfortunate. The game runs better than it did in the day one, but still.
Sometimes, the game doesn't even start. Most of times, you can't even play Invasions, which is like the main source of playable content for this game.
Also, progressing in this game is very slow. Maybe it is related to Netherrealm's tendency to turn everything into downloable content?

MK1 is a good and bad game in its core. For now I do not recommend the game but I am confident that it will get updated and be better just how they updated Mk11.

The good: 
The fighter roster is amazing as each fighter has unique move sets from other fighters.
Has a lot more game modes than mk11.
Caters to both online and single-player  players by being able to level up characters in all modes except story-mode and local fights.
New seasons can introduce a lot of new character inspired skins.

The bad:
There is less customisation where only 1 gear piece can be changed and only 1 intro and outro are available for all characters.
Brutalities and fatalities can only be unlocked trough levelling up specific characters rather through the krypt, AI perform the fatality or through the the tower of time like in MK11.
Character kombos are good, however very little defence against kombos is available, the barrel roll, get up attacks and stage interactions are gone and replaced with the kameo when reaching full special bars ,and uses them, can break opponent kombos and using your special moves as get up attacks which can result in your opponent using juggling kombos for the entire match or spamming down attacks.

I enjoy the gameplay, but what NRS has done with the monetization is unconscionable.  There's a $12 seasonal fatality in the shop right now.  If you buy the game + the first DLC pass you still have to buy another character for $8.  There's a FOMO shop with rotating premium skins.  This is a $70 game.  It's the most expensive fighting game ever released, and the MTX are insane.
It's missing basic features like training mode positional reset, training mode matchmaking waiting, and lobbies.  It's not a complete game, and the fact that features have had to trickle out in the weeks after release proves that.
I loved MK11.  I have hundreds of hours in it.  I already have like 60 hours in MK1 even though it hasn't been out that long.  But after that $12 fatality hit the shop my spirit was broken and I can't bring myself to boot the game any more.

Mortal Kombat, the legendary fighting franchise, has once again proven why it holds a special place in the hearts of gamers worldwide. This latest iteration brings a visceral and thrilling experience that both honors the series' roots and introduces new elements to keep it fresh.

Graphics and Animation:
The visual fidelity in Mortal Kombat is nothing short of breathtaking. Character models are incredibly detailed, and the attention to anatomical accuracy is commendable. The environments are richly designed, each with its own unique atmosphere. The animation is fluid, bringing every brutal move and fatality to life in horrifyingly vivid detail.

Gameplay:
Mortal Kombat strikes a balance between accessibility and depth. It caters to both casual players and hardcore enthusiasts. The extensive roster of characters offers a diverse range of fighting styles, ensuring there's a combatant to suit every playstyle. The addition of Fatal Blows adds a layer of strategy, creating opportunities for dramatic comebacks.

Character Design:
The character design in Mortal Kombat is a testament to the series' legacy. Each fighter is imbued with their own distinct personality and fighting techniques. The return of classic characters alongside fresh faces adds a dynamic element to the roster, offering a mix of nostalgia and excitement for long-time fans.

Fatalities and Brutalities:
Mortal Kombat has always been known for its over-the-top fatalities, and this installment does not disappoint. These finishing moves are a gruesome spectacle, showcasing the game's dedication to shock value. The variety of fatalities and brutalities ensures that every character has their own unique and satisfying way to finish off opponents.

Sound and Music:
The sound design in Mortal Kombat is masterfully executed. The visceral impact of punches and kicks, along with the bone-crunching sound effects during intense moments, creates an immersive auditory experience. The soundtrack complements the action, adding to the tension and excitement of each fight.

Online Modes and Community:
The online modes provide a solid multiplayer experience, allowing players to test their skills against opponents from around the globe. The community remains active and engaged, with regular updates and events ensuring that there's always something new to experience.

Conclusion:
Mortal Kombat delivers a blood-soaked, adrenaline-pumping fighting experience that pays homage to its legacy while embracing innovation. With its stunning visuals, deep gameplay mechanics, and a roster of iconic characters, it stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of the franchise. Whether you're a die-hard fan or a newcomer, Mortal Kombat is a must-play for any fighting game enthusiast.

Invasion mode, which replaces towers of time from mk11 (the mode you gonna spend most of your time unless you want to play ranked 24/7), is the worst thing ever. I have 50hrs in game and I can't play any of the characters. Why you would ask? Because in those 50hrs, mostly spend in invasion, I never had a chance to learn. Every (I mean every, not some, every) enemy has an armor activated randomly every few seconds, even mid combos, which mitigates all dmg and makes them totally immune. Which will just drop your combo, there's no point in learning. They are also very weak, they die to 3 uppercuts, if they don't have the armor at the moment of impact. There are some other modifiers, but armor is always on. If anything it made me a worse MK1 player as armor also slows down time a little so your timing on combos will be off, if you actually tried to pull them off, . You learn how NOT to play the game. It's a copy of Mortal Kombat mobile's Crypt mode, but done even worse.

Story mode is somehow enjoyable, 6+/10.

I really like Mortal Kombat 1. I really do. I like a lot of the characters, I like seeing old characters in new ways like Raiden and Reptile, but I cannot condone the in-game store they're pushing. I'll pay for the kombat packs and all that for new characters, sure, but I am NOT spending $10 for every single skin in the game. NOR will I support the fact that for fucking Halloween, the event is a map re-skin and all the Halloween recolors for characters are $5. The fucking fatality is $11 with tax! It's not even THAT special! They couldn't even make the pumpkin glow! Not to mention the horrible balancing of invasions. I like them, but the modifiers aren't unique enough to keep the combat fresh, and the main difficulty of the whole mode is hyper-armor, and everyone sure does LOVE hyper-armor and having control stripped of the player, just ask anyone!

Before going into detail about MK1, MK11 remains the best MK title (and FG title for me) of all time, it currently has 2x the amount of MK1 players, that says a lot.
So why do I give thumbs up? Well, it's good to compare titles of the same franchise, but at the same time, we need to judge a game on its own as well, and MK1 on its own is good. Nothing too fancy and nothing too trashy.

[i] MK1 does some things better than MK11 and other things worse, in order to be as precise as possible, I will compare it to MK11 but I will also judge some of its aspects on their own  [/i]
[u] The good ones [/u]
-Fast paced combat with depth and satisfying aerial combos
-Level design is out of this world
-Different variations of levels (night, dawn etc)
-Character design is top notch
-Roster is even better than MK11's (which I was a big fan btw)
-Story is great
-Audio design is good
-Graphics are beautiful
-Voice acting is great

[u] The bad ones [/u]
Let me start by saying that the game is clearly unfinished, it's lacking replay value and actual modes, other than that:
-Invasions are boring and tedious
-There are only the basic tower modes 
-Roster has less characters
-Character and Cameo progression systems are grindy as all hell and unfun
-Cameo system, whoever thought this was a good idea, should be fired immediately
-Customization is very limited
-Fatalities are a joke compared to MK11's

All in all, MK1 is a decent title, it totally doesn't worth 70 bucks and it needs a lot of work for someone to even think to compare it to MK11, but there is potential, the only unfixable thing is the cameo system, that's the 80% of MK1's problems, the rest will eventually come.
What I didn't expect was the devolution of the Fatalities, they are supposed to get better with each game, they are too simple and too fast in this one, some of them were simple brutalities back in MK11.

[b] Overall [/b]
6.5/10

100-hour review. I've played MK9, MKX, MK11, and now MK1.

This is an empty game. There is so little content that even the weekly shop recycles items. They are drip-feeding us skins over the span of weeks/months; skins that are already in the game's files. Invasions is a drag, forcing you to fight hundreds of opponents with super armour while scrambling your controls on a dark screen. The story's writing is on par with a highschool fanfiction. The frame data on some characters is straight up false. There was a daily quest to perform mercies when mercies aren't even a feature in the game yet. Private practice online is not an option, was in MK11. Lobbies aren't an option, was in MK11. No wifi filter. This game is EMPTY.

Yet, it's also full. It's full of microtransactions; a $12 CAD fatalty. It's full of gimmicks that break the game. Chip damage over 22% of your healthbar; unblockable setups with numerous characters; an overwhelming meta; easy-to-perform low investment combos on some characters that will do 55% while harder higher investment ones on other characters do 35%. It's no wonder Mortal Kombat is an embarrassment in the FGC compared to Street Fighter. 

If you're looking for an honest fighting game, this isn't it.

Well the story mode was pretty damn big, that's a good thing, the visuals combined with that, dazzling, the graphics are very nice. Music is on point.

27/10/2023 - Updating my review, as it seems a patch was dropped by the devs, and has thankfully stopped the crashing for me, and the audio doesnt crackle one bit now. Been playing the tower invasions for a few days now, and not once crash.

I still think charging for a character that you need to actually apply pallete parts, gear, etc, is out of order (Shang Tsung, your money is mine).

However, I do recommend the game, the fighting mechanics are fast, responsive, and alot of fun. I do miss the Krypt though.

Mortal Kombat 1, released in 2023, delivers a thrilling blend of nostalgia and modern gaming. The graphics are absolutely stunning, showcasing the power of contemporary hardware to bring characters and environments to life in vivid detail. The game's roster of characters, both classic and new additions, provides an exciting array of combat styles, ensuring that every player can find a favorite. The intricate combos, an essential aspect of the series, remain as satisfying as ever, offering a deep level of strategy and challenge.

However, the gaming experience is not without its blemishes. NeatherRealm Studios' sketchy business practices, including the presence of an item shop and Kombat Pack, are hard to ignore. The microtransactions and loot box-like elements within the item shop can feel intrusive and may tempt players to spend more money than they intended. Additionally, the Kombat Pack, while offering extra content, can create a division in the player community by gating certain characters and features behind a paywall. These issues, while disappointing, should not overshadow the fact that Mortal Kombat 1 in 2023 remains a visually impressive and mechanically captivating fighting game.

absolutely recommend it, it's such a blast :)

Ed Boon and his team love this franchise; but WB sees it as nothing more than another avenue to milk as much money as they can from the fans.  Story mode is great but has no replay value, invasion mode isn't great but it's something to do for a few hours until you finish that too and there's nothing left except online play.  Across all these modes you get trivial amounts of xp and even less xp when playing a normal match against the computer.  It makes unlocking character rewards extremely boring for solo players.  Characters have two sets of outfits that offer a bunch of pallet swaps, but any other "fun" skins are bought with real money.  I put almost 600 hours total into the pc and switch versions of mk11 and barely touched online, this one will likely stay at 30 hours unless they make some big changes.  I've been playing MK since the original MK1 and honestly this game makes me question that I'll even care about MK13 if WB is still pushing profits over fun.

MK1, This game rekindled my love of fighting games and I love it for that. 

The gameplay feels about as good as MK11 which was really enjoyable.

The Kameo system is a great addition in my opinion, a system that makes for some new innovations when facing fighters. It's not as simple as learning their move sets and other players will always surprise you with something you've never seen before that consistent new tech, new combos it can refresh a meta and that's good for a game's lifespan.

However NetherRealm being NetherRealm it's not perfect.

Adding in Invasions mode for single player is a nice touch MK as an RPG? I'm all in favour! If it were like MK Deception and Konquest mode, but annoyingly it's made a challenge only by super armour cheese and messing with the game as a whole in terms of frame timing, rather than making it an actual challenge of skill.
The hardest it gets is Test Your Might. That is not very fun. It would be much better if it rewarded the stuff that makes a difference in an actual match not relying on gimmicks. Now the elemental twist is nice but after a while stops being relevant

One mark off for the jittery PC cutscenes in story, that's pretty annoying AND exclusive to PC! (I'm on ultra settings on a high end PC with a 3080ti so I don't want to hear the 'inferior hardware' argument.)
One mark off for Invasions requiring very little skill and relying on cheese albeit in typical MK fashion.
One mark off for Micro-transactions, seriously. I get your game is a business but still, these things don't need to be omnipresent. What's wrong with DLC costumes over buying an in game virtual currency to buy them anyway?

As someone who plays this game for the online, I find it to be very disappointing.  Grinding to Elder god is EXTREMELY painful due to racking up free losses every other match from network disconnection issues.  You can have a wired connection, high speed internet, but none of that matters  because the netcode will disconnect you even if your stuff blips for a fraction of a second.  Never noticed an interruption in service during other online applications running at the same time such as discord, but have online matches disconnecting ever 5-10 minutes.  Don't recommend until they improve their netcode, or improve their online solution entirely.  Single player content is okay... but nothing really worth spending too much time into once you've completed the story.  Rather disappointing as I had thought the previous game to have ran just fine. Maybe it needed another couple months in the oven.
